<DOCUMENT>
<S><ORGANIZATION>EU</ORGANIZATION> rejects German call to boycott British lamb .</S>
<S><PERSON>Peter Blackburn</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>BRUSSELS</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>European Commission</ORGANIZATION> said on Thursday it disagreed with German advice to consumers to shun British lamb until scientists determine whether mad cow disease can be transmitted to sheep .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Germany</LOCATION>'s representative to the <ORGANIZATION>European Union</ORGANIZATION>'s veterinary committee <PERSON>Werner Zwingmann</PERSON> said on Wednesday consumers should buy sheepmeat from countries other than <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> until the scientific advice was clearer .</S>
<S>" We don't support any such recommendation because we don't see any grounds for it , " the <ORGANIZATION>Commission</ORGANIZATION>'s chief spokesman <PERSON>Nikolaus van der Pas</PERSON> told a news briefing .</S>
<S>He said further scientific study was required and if it was found that action was needed it should be taken by the <ORGANIZATION>European Union</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>He said a proposal last month by <ORGANIZATION>EU</ORGANIZATION> Farm Commissioner <PERSON>Franz Fischler</PERSON> to ban sheep brains , spleens and spinal cords from the human and animal food chains was a highly specific and precautionary move to protect human health .</S>
<S><PERSON>Fischler</PERSON> proposed EU-wide measures after reports from <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>France</LOCATION> that under laboratory conditions sheep could contract Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy ( BSE ) -- mad cow disease .</S>
<S>But <PERSON>Fischler</PERSON> agreed to review his proposal after the <ORGANIZATION>EU</ORGANIZATION>'s standing veterinary committee , mational animal health officials , questioned if such action was justified as there was only a slight risk to human health .</S>
<S>Spanish Farm Minister <PERSON>Loyola de Palacio</PERSON> had earlier accused <PERSON>Fischler</PERSON> at an <ORGANIZATION>EU</ORGANIZATION> farm ministers ' meeting of causing unjustified alarm through " dangerous generalisation . "</S>
<S>Only <LOCATION>France</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> backed <PERSON>Fischler</PERSON>'s proposal .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>EU</ORGANIZATION>'s scientific veterinary and multidisciplinary committees are due to re-examine the issue early next month and make recommendations to the senior veterinary officials .</S>
<S>Sheep have long been known to contract scrapie , a brain-wasting disease similar to BSE which is believed to have been transferred to cattle through feed containing animal waste .</S>
<S>British farmers denied on Thursday there was any danger to human health from their sheep , but expressed concern that German government advice to consumers to avoid British lamb might influence consumers across <LOCATION>Europe</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" What we have to be extremely careful of is how other countries are going to take <LOCATION>Germany</LOCATION>'s lead , " <ORGANIZATION>Welsh National Farmers ' Union</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>NFU</ORGANIZATION> ) chairman <PERSON>John Lloyd Jones</PERSON> said on <ORGANIZATION>BBC radio</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Bonn</LOCATION> has led efforts to protect public health after consumer confidence collapsed in March after a British report suggested humans could contract an illness similar to mad cow disease by eating contaminated beef .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Germany</LOCATION> imported 47,600 sheep from <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> last year , nearly half of total imports .</S>
<S>It brought in 4,275 tonnes of British mutton , some 10 percent of overall imports .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S>Rare <PERSON>Hendrix</PERSON> song draft sells for almost $ 17,000 .</S>
<S><LOCATION>LONDON</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S>A rare early handwritten draft of a song by <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> guitar legend <PERSON>Jimi Hendrix</PERSON> was sold for almost $ 17,000 on Thursday at an auction of some of the late musician's favourite possessions .</S>
<S>A <LOCATION>Florida</LOCATION> restaurant paid 10,925 pounds ( $ 16,935 ) for the draft of " Ain't no telling " , which <PERSON>Hendrix</PERSON> penned on a piece of <LOCATION>London</LOCATION> hotel stationery in late 1966 .</S>
<S>At the end of a January 1967 concert in the English city of <LOCATION>Nottingham</LOCATION> he threw the sheet of paper into the audience , where it was retrieved by a fan .</S>
<S>Buyers also snapped up 16 other items that were put up for auction by <PERSON>Hendrix</PERSON>'s former girlfriend <PERSON>Kathy Etchingham</PERSON> , who lived with him from 1966 to 1969 .</S>
<S>They included a black lacquer and mother of pearl inlaid box used by <PERSON>Hendrix</PERSON> to store his drugs , which an anonymous Australian purchaser bought for 5,060 pounds ( $ 7,845 ) .</S>
<S>The guitarist died of a drugs overdose in 1970 aged 27 .</S>

<S><LOCATION>China</LOCATION> says <LOCATION>Taiwan</LOCATION> spoils atmosphere for talks .</S>
<S><LOCATION>BEIJING</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S><LOCATION>China</LOCATION> on Thursday accused <LOCATION>Taipei</LOCATION> of spoiling the atmosphere for a resumption of talks across the <LOCATION>Taiwan Strait</LOCATION> with a visit to <LOCATION>Ukraine</LOCATION> by Taiwanese Vice President <PERSON>Lien Chan</PERSON> this week that infuriated <LOCATION>Beijing</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>Speaking only hours after Chinese state media said the time was right to engage in political talks with <LOCATION>Taiwan</LOCATION> , <ORGANIZATION>Foreign Ministry</ORGANIZATION> spokesman <PERSON>Shen Guofang</PERSON> told <ORGANIZATION>Reuters</ORGANIZATION> : " The necessary atmosphere for the opening of the talks has been disrupted by the <LOCATION>Taiwan</LOCATION> authorities . "</S>
<S>State media quoted <LOCATION>China</LOCATION>'s top negotiator with <LOCATION>Taipei</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Tang Shubei</PERSON> , as telling a visiting group from <LOCATION>Taiwan</LOCATION> on Wednesday that it was time for the rivals to hold political talks .</S>
<S>" Now is the time for the two sides to engage in political talks ...</S>
<S>that is to end the state of hostility , " Thursday's overseas edition of the <ORGANIZATION>People's Daily</ORGANIZATION> quoted <PERSON>Tang</PERSON> as saying .</S>
<S>The foreign ministry's <ORGANIZATION>Shen</ORGANIZATION> told <ORGANIZATION>Reuters Television</ORGANIZATION> in an interview he had read reports of <PERSON>Tang</PERSON>'s comments but gave no details of why the negotiator had considered the time right for talks with <LOCATION>Taiwan</LOCATION> , which <LOCATION>Beijing</LOCATION> considers a renegade province .</S>
<S><LOCATION>China</LOCATION> , which has long opposed all <LOCATION>Taipei</LOCATION> efforts to gain greater international recognition , was infuriated by a visit to <LOCATION>Ukraine</LOCATION> this week by Taiwanese Vice President <PERSON>Lien</PERSON> .</S>

<S><LOCATION>BEIJING</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>

<DOCUMENT>
<S>German July car registrations up 14.2 pct yr / yr .</S>
<S><LOCATION>FRANKFURT</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S>German first-time registrations of motor vehicles jumped 14.2 percent in July this year from the year-earlier period , the <ORGANIZATION>Federal office for motor vehicles</ORGANIZATION> said on Thursday .</S>
<S>The office said 356,725 new cars were registered in July 1996 -- 304,850 passenger cars and 15,613 trucks .</S>
<S>The figures represent a 13.6 percent increase for passenger cars and a 2.2 percent decline for trucks from July 1995 .</S>
<S>Motor-bike registration rose 32.7 percent in the period .</S>
<S>The growth was partly due to an increased number of Germans buying German cars abroad , while manufacturers said that domestic demand was weak , the federal office said .</S>
<S>Almost all German car manufacturers posted gains in registration numbers in the period .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Volkswagen AG</ORGANIZATION> won 77,719 registrations , slightly more than a quarter of the total .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Opel AG</ORGANIZATION> together with <ORGANIZATION>General Motors</ORGANIZATION> came in second place with 49,269 registrations , 16.4 percent of the overall figure .</S>
<S>Third was <ORGANIZATION>Ford</ORGANIZATION> with 35,563 registrations , or 11.7 percent .</S>
<S>Only <ORGANIZATION>Seat</ORGANIZATION> and <ORGANIZATION>Porsche</ORGANIZATION> had fewer registrations in July 1996 compared to last year's July .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Seat</ORGANIZATION> posted 3,420 registrations compared with 5522 registrations in July a year earlier .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Porsche</ORGANIZATION>'s registrations fell to 554 from 643 .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S><LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION> plays down fears of war with <LOCATION>Syria</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Colleen Siegel</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>JERUSALEM</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S><LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION>'s outgoing peace negotiator with <LOCATION>Syria</LOCATION> said on Thursday current tensions between the two countries appeared to be a storm in a teacup .</S>
<S><PERSON>Itamar Rabinovich</PERSON> , who as <LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION>'s ambassador to <LOCATION>Washington</LOCATION> conducted unfruitful negotiations with <LOCATION>Syria</LOCATION> , told <ORGANIZATION>Israel Radio</ORGANIZATION> it looked like <LOCATION>Damascus</LOCATION> wanted to talk rather than fight .</S>
<S>" It appears to me the Syrian priority is still to negotiate .</S>
<S>The Syrians are confused , they are definitely tense , but the general assessment here in <LOCATION>Washington</LOCATION> is that this is essentially a storm in a teacup , " he said .</S>
<S><PERSON>Rabinovich</PERSON> is winding up his term as ambassador .</S>
<S>He will be replaced by <PERSON>Eliahu Ben-Elissar</PERSON> , a former Israeli envoy to <LOCATION>Egypt</LOCATION> and right-wing <ORGANIZATION>Likud</ORGANIZATION> party politician .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION> on Wednesday sent <LOCATION>Syria</LOCATION> a message , via <LOCATION>Washington</LOCATION> , saying it was committed to peace and wanted to open negotiations without preconditions .</S>
<S>But it slammed <LOCATION>Damascus</LOCATION> for creating what it called a dangerous atmosphere .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Syria</LOCATION> accused <LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION> on Wednesday of launching a hysterical campaign against it after Israeli television reported that <LOCATION>Damascus</LOCATION> had recently test fired a missile .</S>
<S>It said its arms purchases were for defensive purposes .</S>
<S>" The message that we sent to ( Syrian President <PERSON>Hafez al-</PERSON> ) <PERSON>Assad</PERSON> is that <LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION> is ready at any time without preconditions to enter peace negotiations , " Israeli Foreign Minister <PERSON>David Levy</PERSON> told <ORGANIZATION>Israel Radio</ORGANIZATION> in an interview .</S>
<S>Tension has mounted since Israeli Prime Minister <PERSON>Benjamin Netanyahu</PERSON> took office in June vowing to retain the <LOCATION>Golan Heights Israel</LOCATION> captured from <LOCATION>Syria</LOCATION> in the 1967 <LOCATION>Middle East</LOCATION> war .</S>
<S>Israeli-Syrian peace talks have been deadlocked over the <LOCATION>Golan</LOCATION> since 1991 despite the previous government's willingness to make <LOCATION>Golan</LOCATION> concessions .</S>
<S>Peace talks between the two sides were last held in February .</S>
<S>" The voices coming out of <LOCATION>Damascus</LOCATION> are bad , not good .</S>
<S>The media ...</S>
<S>are full of expressions and declarations that must be worrying ...</S>
<S>this artificial atmosphere is very dangerous because those who spread it could become its prisoners , " <PERSON>Levy</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>" We expect from <LOCATION>Syria</LOCATION> , if its face is to peace , that it will answer <LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION>'s message to enter peace negotiations because that is our goal , " he said . "</S>
<S>We do not want a war , <PERSON>God</PERSON> forbid .</S>
<S>No one benefits from wars . "</S>
<S><LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION>'s <ORGANIZATION>Channel Two</ORGANIZATION> television said <LOCATION>Damascus</LOCATION> had sent a " calming signal " to <LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>It gave no source for the report .</S>
<S><PERSON>Netanyahu</PERSON> and <PERSON>Levy</PERSON>'s spokesmen said they could not confirm it .</S>
<S>The television also said that <PERSON>Netanyahu</PERSON> had sent messages to reassure <LOCATION>Syria</LOCATION> via <LOCATION>Cairo</LOCATION> , the <LOCATION>United States</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S>Polish diplomat denies nurses stranded in <LOCATION>Libya</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><LOCATION>TUNIS</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S>A Polish diplomat on Thursday denied a Polish tabloid report this week that <LOCATION>Libya</LOCATION> was refusing exit visas to 100 Polish nurses trying to return home after working in the North African country .</S>
<S>" This is not true .</S>
<S>Up to today , we have no knowledge of any nurse stranded or kept in <LOCATION>Libya</LOCATION> without her will , and we have not received any complaint , " the Polish embassy's charge d'affaires in <LOCATION>Tripoli</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Tadeusz Awdankiewicz</PERSON> , told <ORGANIZATION>Reuters</ORGANIZATION> by telephone .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Poland</LOCATION>'s labour ministry said this week it would send a team to <LOCATION>Libya</LOCATION> to investigate , but <PERSON>Awdankiewicz</PERSON> said the probe was prompted by some nurses complaining about their work conditions such as non-payment of their salaries .</S>
<S>He said that there are an estimated 800 Polish nurses working in <LOCATION>Libya</LOCATION> .</S>

<S><PERSON>Hassan Hafidh</PERSON></S>

<S>A <ORGANIZATION>Mujahideen Khalq</ORGANIZATION> statement said its leader <PERSON>Massoud Rajavi</PERSON> met in <LOCATION>Baghdad</LOCATION> the Secretary-General of the <ORGANIZATION>Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iran</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>KDPI</ORGANIZATION> ) <PERSON>Hassan Rastegar</PERSON> on Wednesday and voiced his support to <LOCATION>Iran</LOCATION>'s rebel Kurds .</S>
<S>" Rajavi emphasised that the Iranian <ORGANIZATION>Resistance</ORGANIZATION> would continue to stand side by side with their Kurdish compatriots and the resistance movement in <LOCATION>Iranian Kurdistan</LOCATION> , " it said .</S>
<S>A spokesman for the group said the meeting " signals a new level of cooperation between <ORGANIZATION>Mujahideen Khalq</ORGANIZATION> and the Iranian Kurdish oppositions " .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Iran</LOCATION> heavily bombarded targets in northern <LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION> in July in pursuit of <ORGANIZATION>KDPI</ORGANIZATION> guerrillas based in Iraqi Kurdish areas outside the control of the government in <LOCATION>Baghdad</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>Iraqi Kurdish areas bordering <LOCATION>Iran</LOCATION> are under the control of guerrillas of the <ORGANIZATION>Iraqi Kurdish Patriotic Union of Kurdistan</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>PUK</ORGANIZATION> ) group .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>PUK</ORGANIZATION> and <LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION>'s <ORGANIZATION>Kurdistan Democratic Party</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>KDP</ORGANIZATION> ) the two main Iraqi Kurdish factions , have had northern <LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION> under their control since Iraqi forces were ousted from <LOCATION>Kuwait</LOCATION> in the 1991 Gulf War .</S>
<S>Clashes between the two parties broke out at the weekend in the most serious fighting since a U.S.-sponsored ceasefire last year .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Mujahideen Khalq</ORGANIZATION> said Iranian troops had also been shelling <ORGANIZATION>KDP</ORGANIZATION> positions in <LOCATION>Qasri</LOCATION> region in <LOCATION>Suleimaniya</LOCATION> province near the Iranian border over the last two days .</S>
<S>It said about 100 Iraqi Kurds were killed or wounded in the attack .</S>
<S>Both <LOCATION>Iran</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Turkey</LOCATION> mount air and land strikes at targets in northern <LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION> in pursuit of their own Kurdish rebels .</S>
<S>A U.S.-led air force in southern <LOCATION>Turkey</LOCATION> protects Iraqi Kurds from possible attacks by <LOCATION>Baghdad</LOCATION> troops .</S>

<S><LOCATION>MANAMA</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S>The spot Saudi riyal against the dollar and riyal interbank deposit rates were mainly steady this week in quiet summer trade , dealers in the kingdom said .</S>
<S>" There were no changes in Saudi riyal rates .</S>
<S>The market was very quiet because of summer holidays , " one dealer said .</S>
<S>The spot riyal was put at 3.7504 / 06 to the dollar .</S>
<S>One-month interbank deposits were at 5-1/2 , 3/8 percent , three months were 5-5/8 , 1/2 percent and six months were 5-3/4 , 5/8 percent .</S>
<S>One-year funds were at six , 5-7/8 percent .</S>

<S><LOCATION>JERUSALEM</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S><LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION> gave Palestinian President <PERSON>Yasser Arafat</PERSON> permission on Thursday to fly over its territory to the <LOCATION>West Bank</LOCATION> , ending a brief Israeli-PLO crisis , an <PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> adviser said .</S>
<S>" The problem is over .</S>
<S>The president's aircraft has received permission to pass through Israeli airspace but the president is not expected to travel to the <LOCATION>West Bank</LOCATION> before Monday , " <PERSON>Nabil Abu Rdainah</PERSON> told <ORGANIZATION>Reuters</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> had been scheduled to meet former Israeli prime minister <PERSON>Shimon Peres</PERSON> in the <LOCATION>West Bank</LOCATION> town of <LOCATION>Ramallah</LOCATION> on Thursday but the venue was changed to <LOCATION>Gaza</LOCATION> after <LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION> denied flight clearance to the Palestinian leader's helicopters .</S>
<S>Palestinian officials accused right-wing Prime Minister <PERSON>Benjamin Netanyahu</PERSON> of trying to stop the <LOCATION>Ramallah</LOCATION> meeting by keeping <PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> grounded .</S>
<S><PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> subsequently cancelled a meeting between Israeli and <ORGANIZATION>PLO</ORGANIZATION> officials , on civilian affairs , at the <LOCATION>Allenby Bridge</LOCATION> crossing between <LOCATION>Jordan</LOCATION> and the <LOCATION>West Bank</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Abu Rdainah</PERSON> said <PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> had decided against flying to the <LOCATION>West Bank</LOCATION> on Thursday , after <LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION> lifted the ban , because he had a busy schedule in <LOCATION>Gaza</LOCATION> and would not be free until Monday .</S>

<S><PERSON>Yasser Arafat</PERSON> will meet <PERSON>Shimon Peres</PERSON> in <LOCATION>Gaza</LOCATION> on Thursday after Palestinians said the right-wing Israeli government had barred the Palestinian leader from flying to the <LOCATION>West Bank</LOCATION> for talks with the former prime minister .</S>

<S>Afghan <LOCATION>UAE</LOCATION> embassy says Taleban guards going home .</S>
<S><PERSON>Hilary Gush</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>DUBAI</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S>Three Afghan guards brought to the <LOCATION>United Arab Emirates</LOCATION> last week by Russian hostages who escaped from the Taleban militia will return to <LOCATION>Afghanistan</LOCATION> in a few days , the Afghan embassy in <LOCATION>Abu Dhabi</LOCATION> said on Thursday .</S>
<S>" Our ambassador is in touch with the <LOCATION>UAE</LOCATION> foreign ministry .</S>
<S>Their return to <LOCATION>Afghanistan</LOCATION> will take place in two or three days , " an embassy official said .</S>
<S>" The embassy is issuing them travel documents for their return to their homeland .</S>
<S>There is no objection to their travel , " he added .</S>
<S>The three Islamic Taleban guards were overpowered by seven Russian aircrew who escaped to <LOCATION>UAE</LOCATION> state <LOCATION>Sharjah</LOCATION> last Friday on board their own aircraft after a year in the captivity of Taleban militia in <LOCATION>Kandahar</LOCATION> in southern <LOCATION>Afghanistan</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>The <LOCATION>UAE</LOCATION> said on Monday it would hand over the three to the <ORGANIZATION>International Red Crescent</ORGANIZATION> , possibly last Tuesday .</S>
<S>It has since been silent on the issue .</S>
<S>When asked whether the three guards would travel back to <LOCATION>Kandahar</LOCATION> or the Afghan capital <LOCATION>Kabul</LOCATION> , the embassy official said : " That has not been decided , but possibly <LOCATION>Kandahar</LOCATION> . "</S>
<S><LOCATION>Kandahar</LOCATION> is the headquarters of the opposition Taleban militia .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Kabul</LOCATION> is controlled by President <PERSON>Burhanuddin Rabbani</PERSON>'s government , which Taleban is fighting to overthrow .</S>
<S>The embassy official said the three men , believed to be in their 20s , were currently in <LOCATION>Abu Dhabi</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>He did not elaborate .</S>
<S>The Russians , working for the <ORGANIZATION>Aerostan</ORGANIZATION> firm in the Russian republic of <LOCATION>Tatarstan</LOCATION> , were taken hostage after a Taleban MiG-19 fighter forced their cargo plane to land in August 1995 .</S>
<S>Taleban said its shipment of ammunition from <LOCATION>Albania</LOCATION> was evidence of Russian military support for <PERSON>Rabbani</PERSON>'s government .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> said the crew's nationality was coincidental .</S>
<S>Numerous diplomatic attempts to free the seven failed .</S>
<S>The Russians , who said they overpowered the guards -- two armed with Kalashnikov automatic rifles -- while doing regular maintenance work on their Ilyushin 76 cargo plane last Friday , left the <LOCATION>UAE</LOCATION> capital <LOCATION>Abu Dhabi</LOCATION> for home on Sunday .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S><LOCATION>BAGHDAD</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S>Iraqi President <PERSON>Saddam Hussein</PERSON> has told visiting Russian ultra-nationalist <PERSON>Vladimir Zhirinovsky</PERSON> that <LOCATION>Baghdad</LOCATION> wanted to maintain " friendship and cooperation " with <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> , official Iraqi newspapers said on Thursday .</S>
<S>" President <PERSON>Saddam Hussein</PERSON> stressed during the meeting <LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION>'s keenness to maintain friendship and cooperation with <LOCATION>Russia</LOCATION> , " the papers said .</S>
<S>They said <PERSON>Zhirinovsky</PERSON> told <PERSON>Saddam</PERSON> before he left <LOCATION>Baghdad</LOCATION> on Wednesday that his <ORGANIZATION>Liberal Democratic party</ORGANIZATION> and the Russian <ORGANIZATION>Duma</ORGANIZATION> ( parliament ) " are calling for an immediate lifting of the embargo " imposed on <LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION> after its 1990 invasion of <LOCATION>Kuwait</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Zhirinovsky</PERSON> said on Tuesday he would press the Russian government to help end <ORGANIZATION>U.N.</ORGANIZATION> trade sanctions on <LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION> and blamed <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> for delaying establishment of good ties with <LOCATION>Baghdad</LOCATION> .</S>

<S>Three plugged water injection wells on the <LOCATION>Heidrun</LOCATION> oilfield off mid-Norway will be reopened over the next month , operator <ORGANIZATION>Den Norske Stats Oljeselskap AS</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>Statoil</ORGANIZATION> ) said on Thursday .</S>
<S>The plugged wells have accounted for a dip of 30,000 barrels per day ( bpd ) in <LOCATION>Heidrun</LOCATION> output to roughly 220,000 bpd , according to the company's <ORGANIZATION>Status Weekly</ORGANIZATION> newsletter .</S>
<S>The wells will be reperforated and gravel will be pumped into the reservoir through one of the wells to avoid plugging problems in the future , it said .</S>

<DOCUMENT>
<S>German farm ministry tells consumers to avoid British mutton .</S>
<S><LOCATION>BONN</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S><LOCATION>Germany</LOCATION>'s <ORGANIZATION>Agriculture Ministry</ORGANIZATION> suggested on Wednesday that consumers avoid eating meat from British sheep until scientists determine whether mad cow disease can be transmitted to the animals .</S>
<S>" Until this is cleared up by the <ORGANIZATION>European Union</ORGANIZATION>'s scientific panels -- and we have asked this to be done as quickly as possible -- ( consumers ) should if at all possible give preference to sheepmeat from other countries , " ministry official <PERSON>Werner Zwingmann</PERSON> told <ORGANIZATION>ZDF</ORGANIZATION> television .</S>
<S>" I do not want to say that there is a concrete danger for consumers , " he added . "</S>
<S>There are too many holes in what we know , and these must be filled very quickly . "</S>
<S><LOCATION>Bonn</LOCATION> has led efforts to ensure consumer protection tops the list of priorities in dealing with the mad cow crisis , which erupted in March when <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> acknowledged humans could contract a similar illness by eating contaminated beef .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>European Commission</ORGANIZATION> agreed this month to rethink a proposal to ban the use of suspect sheep tissue after some <ORGANIZATION>EU</ORGANIZATION> veterinary experts questioned whether it was justified .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>EU</ORGANIZATION> Farm Commissioner <PERSON>Franz Fischler</PERSON> had proposed banning sheep brains , spleens and spinal cords from the human and animal food chains after reports from <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>France</LOCATION> that under laboratory conditions sheep could contract Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy ( BSE ) -- mad cow disease .</S>
<S>But some members of the <ORGANIZATION>EU</ORGANIZATION>'s standing veterinary committee questioned whether the action was necessary given the slight risk to human health .</S>
<S>The question is being studied separately by two <ORGANIZATION>EU</ORGANIZATION> scientific committees .</S>
<S>Sheep have long been known to contract scrapie , a similar brain-wasting disease to BSE which is believed to have been transferred to cattle through feed containing animal waste .</S>
<S>British officials say sheep meat is perfectly safe to eat .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>ZDF</ORGANIZATION> said <LOCATION>Germany</LOCATION> imported 47,600 sheep from <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> last year , nearly half of total imports .</S>
<S>It brought in 4,275 tonnes of British mutton , some 10 percent of overall imports .</S>
<S>After the British government admitted a possible link between mad cow disease and its fatal human equivalent , the <ORGANIZATION>EU</ORGANIZATION> imposed a worldwide ban on British beef exports .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>EU</ORGANIZATION> leaders agreed at a summit in June to a progressive lifting of the ban as <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> takes parallel measures to eradicate the disease .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S><LOCATION>YORK</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>England</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S>Sir <PERSON>Mark Prescott</PERSON> landed his first group one victory in 25 years as a trainer when his top sprinter <PERSON>Pivotal</PERSON> , a 100-30 chance , won the Nunthorpe Stakes on Thursday .</S>
<S>The three-year-old , partnered by veteran <PERSON>George Duffield</PERSON> , snatched a short head verdict in the last stride to deny <PERSON>Eveningperformance</PERSON> ( 16-1 ) , trained by <PERSON>Henry Candy</PERSON> and ridden by <PERSON>Chris Rutter</PERSON> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Hever Golf Rose</PERSON> ( 11-4 ) , last year's Prix de l ' Abbaye winner at <LOCATION>Longchamp</LOCATION> , finished third , a further one and a quarter lengths away with the 7-4 favourite <PERSON>Mind Games</PERSON> in fourth .</S>
<S><PERSON>Pivotal</PERSON> , a <PERSON>Royal Ascot</PERSON> winner in June , may now be aimed at this season's Abbaye , <LOCATION>Europe</LOCATION>'s top sprint race .</S>
<S><PERSON>Prescott</PERSON> , reluctant to go into the winner's enclosure until the result of the photo-finish was announced , said : " Twenty-five years and I have never been there so I thought I had better wait a bit longer . "</S>
<S>He added : " It's very sad to beat <PERSON>Henry Candy</PERSON> because I am godfather to his daughter . "</S>
<S>Like <PERSON>Prescott</PERSON> , <PERSON>Jack Berry</PERSON> , trainer of <PERSON>Mind Games</PERSON> , had gone into Thursday's race in search of a first group one success after many years around the top of his profession .</S>
<S><PERSON>Berry</PERSON> said : " I`m disappointed but I don't feel suicidal .</S>
<S>He ( <PERSON>Mind Games</PERSON> ) was going as well as any of them one and a half furlongs ( 300 metres ) out but he just didn't quicken . "</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S>SOCCER - <PERSON>DALGLISH</PERSON> SAD OVER <ORGANIZATION>BLACKBURN</ORGANIZATION> PARTING .</S>
<S><LOCATION>LONDON</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S><PERSON>Kenny Dalglish</PERSON> spoke on Thursday of his sadness at leaving <ORGANIZATION>Blackburn</ORGANIZATION> , the club he led to the English premier league title in 1994-95 .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Blackburn</ORGANIZATION> announced on Wednesday they and <PERSON>Dalglish</PERSON> had parted by mutual consent .</S>
<S>But the ex-manager confessed on Thursday to being " sad " at leaving after taking <ORGANIZATION>Blackburn</ORGANIZATION> from the second division to the premier league title inside three and a half years .</S>
<S>In a telephone call to a local newspaper from his holiday home in <LOCATION>Spain</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Dalglish</PERSON> said : " We came to the same opinion , albeit the club came to it a little bit earlier than me . "</S>
<S>He added : " If no one asked , I never opened my mouth .</S>
<S>I have stayed out of the way and let them get on with the job .</S>
<S>The club thought it ( the job ) had run its course and I came to the same conclusion . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Dalglish</PERSON> had been with <ORGANIZATION>Blackburn</ORGANIZATION> for nearly five years , first as manager and then , for the past 15 months , as director of football .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S><ORGANIZATION>Glasgow Rangers</ORGANIZATION> striker <PERSON>Ally McCoist</PERSON> , another man in form after two hat-tricks in four days , was also named for the August 31 World Cup qualifier against <LOCATION>Austria</LOCATION> in <LOCATION>Vienna</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Ferguson</PERSON> , who served six weeks in jail in late 1995 for head-butting an opponent , won the last of his five <LOCATION>Scotland</LOCATION> caps in December 1994 .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Scotland</LOCATION> manager <PERSON>Craig Brown</PERSON> said on Thursday : " I've watched <PERSON>Duncan Ferguson</PERSON> in action twice recently and he's bang in form .</S>
<S><PERSON>Ally McCoist</PERSON> is also in great scoring form at the moment . "</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Celtic</ORGANIZATION>'s <PERSON>Jackie McNamara</PERSON> , who did well with last season's successful under-21 team , earns a call-up to the senior squad .</S>

<S>TENNIS - <PERSON>NEWCOMBE</PERSON> PONDERS HIS DAVIS CUP FUTURE .</S>
<S><LOCATION>SYDNEY</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S>Australian Davis Cup captain <PERSON>John Newcombe</PERSON> on Thursday signalled his possible resignation if his team loses an away tie against <LOCATION>Croatia</LOCATION> next month .</S>
<S>The former Wimbledon champion said the immediate future of <LOCATION>Australia</LOCATION>'s Davis Cup coach <PERSON>Tony Roche</PERSON> could also be determined by events in <LOCATION>Split</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" If we lose this one , <PERSON>Tony</PERSON> and I will have to have a good look at giving someone else a go , " <PERSON>Newcombe</PERSON> was quoted as saying in <LOCATION>Sydney</LOCATION>'s <ORGANIZATION>Daily Telegraph</ORGANIZATION> newspaper .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Australia</LOCATION> face <LOCATION>Croatia</LOCATION> in the world group qualifying tie on clay from September 20-22 .</S>
<S>Under <PERSON>Newcombe</PERSON>'s leadership , <LOCATION>Australia</LOCATION> were relegated from the elite world group last year , the first time the 26-time Davis Cup winners had slipped from the top rank .</S>
<S>Since taking over as captain from <PERSON>Neale Fraser</PERSON> in 1994 , <PERSON>Newcombe</PERSON>'s record in tandem with <PERSON>Roche</PERSON> , his former doubles partner , has been three wins and three losses .</S>
<S><PERSON>Newcombe</PERSON> has selected Wimbledon semifinalist <PERSON>Jason Stoltenberg</PERSON> , <PERSON>Patrick Rafter</PERSON> , <PERSON>Mark Philippoussis</PERSON> , and Olympic doubles champions <PERSON>Todd Woodbridge</PERSON> and <PERSON>Mark Woodforde</PERSON> to face the Croatians .</S>
<S>The home side boasts world number six <PERSON>Goran Ivanisevic</PERSON> , and <PERSON>Newcombe</PERSON> conceded his players would be hard-pressed to beat the Croatian number one .</S>
<S>" We are ready to fight to our last breath -- <LOCATION>Australia</LOCATION> must play at its absolute best to win , " said <PERSON>Newcombe</PERSON> , who described the tie as the toughest he has faced as captain .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Australia</LOCATION> last won the Davis Cup in 1986 , but they were beaten finalists against <LOCATION>Germany</LOCATION> three years ago under <PERSON>Fraser</PERSON>'s guidance .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>

<S>BASEBALL - <ORGANIZATION>ORIOLES</ORGANIZATION> ' MANAGER <PERSON>DAVEY JOHNSON</PERSON> HOSPITALIZED .</S>
<S><LOCATION>BALTIMORE</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Baltimore Orioles</ORGANIZATION> manager <PERSON>Davey Johnson</PERSON> will miss Thursday night's game against the <ORGANIZATION>Seattle Mariners</ORGANIZATION> after being admitted to a hospital with an irregular heartbeat .</S>
<S>The 53-year-old <PERSON>Johnson</PERSON> was hospitalized after experiencing dizziness .</S>
<S>" He is in no danger and will be treated and observed this evening , " said <ORGANIZATION>Orioles</ORGANIZATION> team physician Dr. <PERSON>William Goldiner</PERSON> , adding that <PERSON>Johnson</PERSON> is expected to be released on Friday .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Orioles</ORGANIZATION> ' bench coach <PERSON>Andy Etchebarren</PERSON> will manage the club in <PERSON>Johnson</PERSON>'s absence .</S>
<S><PERSON>Johnson</PERSON> is the second manager to be hospitalized this week after <ORGANIZATION>California Angels</ORGANIZATION> skipper <PERSON>John McNamara</PERSON> was admitted to <LOCATION>New York</LOCATION>'s <LOCATION>Columbia Presbyterian Hospital</LOCATION> on Wednesday with a blood clot in his left calf .</S>
<S><PERSON>Johnson</PERSON> , who played eight seasons in <LOCATION>Baltimore</LOCATION> , was named <ORGANIZATION>Orioles</ORGANIZATION> manager in the off-season replacing <PERSON>Phil Regan</PERSON> .</S>
<S>He led the <ORGANIZATION>Cincinnati Reds</ORGANIZATION> to the National League Championship Series last year and guided the <ORGANIZATION>New York Mets</ORGANIZATION> to a World Series championship in 1986 .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Baltimore</ORGANIZATION> has won 16 of its last 22 games to pull within five games of the slumping <ORGANIZATION>New York Yankees</ORGANIZATION> in the American League East Division .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S>BASEBALL - <PERSON>GREER</PERSON> HOMER IN 10TH LIFTS <ORGANIZATION>TEXAS</ORGANIZATION> PAST <ORGANIZATION>INDIANS</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><LOCATION>CLEVELAND</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S><PERSON>Rusty Greer</PERSON>'s two-run homer in the top of the 10th inning rallied the <ORGANIZATION>Texas Rangers</ORGANIZATION> to a 10-8 victory over the <ORGANIZATION>Cleveland Indians</ORGANIZATION> Wednesday in the rubber game of a three-game series between division leaders .</S>
<S>With one out , <PERSON>Greer</PERSON> hit a 1-1 pitch from <PERSON>Julian Tavarez</PERSON> ( 4-7 ) over the right-field fence for his 15th home run .</S>
<S>" It was an off-speed pitch and I just tried to get a good swing on it and put it in play , " <PERSON>Greer</PERSON> said . "</S>
<S>This was a big game .</S>
<S>The crowd was behind him and it was intense . "</S>
<S>The shot brought home <PERSON>Ivan Rodriguez</PERSON> , who had his second double of the game , giving him 42 this season , 41 as a catcher .</S>
<S>He joined <PERSON>Mickey Cochrane</PERSON> , <PERSON>Johnny Bench</PERSON> and <PERSON>Terry Kennedy</PERSON> as the only catchers with 40 doubles in a season .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Rangers</ORGANIZATION> have won 10 of their last 12 games and six of nine meetings against the <ORGANIZATION>Indians</ORGANIZATION> this season .</S>
<S>The American League Western leaders have won eight of 15 games at <LOCATION>Jacobs Field</LOCATION> , joining the <ORGANIZATION>Yankees</ORGANIZATION> as the only teams with a winning record at the A.L. Central leaders ' home .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Cleveland</ORGANIZATION> lost for just the second time in six games .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Indians</ORGANIZATION> sent the game into extra innings in the ninth on <PERSON>Kenny Lofton</PERSON>'s two-run single .</S>
<S><PERSON>Ed Vosberg</PERSON> ( 1-0 ) blew his first save opportunity but got the win , allowing three hits with two walks and three strikeouts in 1 2/3 scoreless innings .</S>
<S><PERSON>Dean Palmer</PERSON> hit his 30th homer for the <ORGANIZATION>Rangers</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Baltimore</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Cal Ripken</PERSON> had four hits and snapped a fifth-inning tie with a solo homer and <PERSON>Bobby Bonilla</PERSON> added a three-run shot in the seventh to power the surging <ORGANIZATION>Orioles</ORGANIZATION> to a 10-5 victory over the <ORGANIZATION>Seattle Mariners</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Mariners</ORGANIZATION> scored four runs in the top of the fifth to tie the game 5-5 but <PERSON>Ripken</PERSON> led off the bottom of the inning with his 21st homer off starter <PERSON>Sterling Hitchcock</PERSON> ( 12-6 ) .</S>
<S><PERSON>Bonilla</PERSON>'s blast was the first time <PERSON>Randy Johnson</PERSON> , last season's <PERSON>Cy Young</PERSON> winner , allowed a run in five relief appearances since coming off the disabled list on August 6 .</S>
<S><PERSON>Bonilla</PERSON> has 21 RBI and 15 runs in his last 20 games .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Baltimore</LOCATION> has won seven of nine and 16 of its last 22 and cut the <ORGANIZATION>Yankees</ORGANIZATION> ' lead in the A.L. East to five games .</S>
<S><PERSON>Scott Erickson</PERSON> ( 8-10 ) laboured to his third straight win .</S>
<S><PERSON>Alex Rodriguez</PERSON> had two homers and four RBI for the <ORGANIZATION>Mariners</ORGANIZATION> , who have dropped three in a row and 11 of 15 .</S>
<S>He became the fifth shortstop in major-league history to hit 30 homers in a season and the first since <PERSON>Ripken</PERSON> hit 34 in 1991 .</S>
<S><PERSON>Chris Hoiles</PERSON> hit his 22nd homer for <LOCATION>Baltimore</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>New York</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Jason Dickson</PERSON> scattered 10 hits over 6 1/3 innings in his major-league debut and <PERSON>Chili Davis</PERSON> belted a homer from each side of the plate as the <ORGANIZATION>California Angels</ORGANIZATION> defeated the <ORGANIZATION>Yankees</ORGANIZATION> 7-1 .</S>
<S><PERSON>Dickson</PERSON> allowed a homer to <PERSON>Derek Jeter</PERSON> on his first major-league pitch but settled down .</S>
<S>He was the 27th pitcher used by the <ORGANIZATION>Angels</ORGANIZATION> this season , tying a major-league record .</S>
<S><PERSON>Jimmy Key</PERSON> ( 9-10 ) took the loss as the <ORGANIZATION>Yankees</ORGANIZATION> lost their ninth in 14 games .</S>
<S>They stranded 11 baserunners .</S>
<S><LOCATION>California</LOCATION> played without interim manager <PERSON>John McNamara</PERSON> , who was admitted to a <LOCATION>New York</LOCATION> hospital with a blood clot in his right calf .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Boston</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Mike Stanley</PERSON>'s bases-loaded two-run single snapped an eighth-inning tie and gave the <ORGANIZATION>Red Sox</ORGANIZATION> their third straight win , 6-4 over the <ORGANIZATION>Oakland Athletics</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Stanley</PERSON> owns a .367 career batting average with the bases loaded ( 33-for-90 ) .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Boston</LOCATION>'s <PERSON>Mo Vaughn</PERSON> went 3-for-3 with a walk , stole home for one of his three runs scored and collected his 116th RBI .</S>
<S><PERSON>Scott Brosius</PERSON> homered and drove in two runs for the <ORGANIZATION>Athletics</ORGANIZATION> , who have lost seven of their last nine games .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Detroit</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Brad Ausmus</PERSON>'s three-run homer capped a four-run eighth and lifted the <ORGANIZATION>Tigers</ORGANIZATION> to a 7-4 victory over the reeling <ORGANIZATION>Chicago White Sox</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Tigers</ORGANIZATION> have won consecutive games after dropping eight in a row , but have won nine of their last 12 at home .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>White Sox</ORGANIZATION> have lost six of their last eight games .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Kansas City</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Juan Guzman</PERSON> tossed a complete-game six-hitter to win for the first time in over a month and lower his league-best ERA as the <ORGANIZATION>Toronto Blue Jays</ORGANIZATION> won their fourth straight , 6-2 over the <ORGANIZATION>Royals</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Guzman</PERSON> ( 10-8 ) won for the first time since July 16 , a span of six starts .</S>
<S>He allowed two runs -- one earned -- and lowered his ERA to 2.99 .</S>
<S>At <LOCATION>Minnesota</LOCATION> , <PERSON>John Jaha</PERSON>'s three-run homer , his 26th , capped a five-run eighth inning that rallied the <ORGANIZATION>Milwaukee Brewers</ORGANIZATION> to a 10-7 victory over the <ORGANIZATION>Twins</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Jaha</PERSON> added an RBI single in the ninth and had four RBI .</S>
<S><PERSON>Jose Valentin</PERSON> hit his 21st homer for <ORGANIZATION>Milwaukee</ORGANIZATION> .</S>

<S><PERSON>Knup</PERSON> was overlooked by <PERSON>Artur Jorge</PERSON> for the European championship finals earlier this year .</S>
<S>But new coach <PERSON>Rolf Fringer</PERSON> is clearly a <PERSON>Knup</PERSON> fan and included him in his 19-man squad on Thursday .</S>

<S>ATHLETICS - IT's A RECORD - 40,000 BEERS ON THE HOUSE .</S>
<S><LOCATION>BRUSSELS</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S>Spectators at Friday's <LOCATION>Brussels</LOCATION> grand prix meeting have an extra incentive to cheer on the athletes to world record performances -- a free glass of beer .</S>
<S>A Belgian brewery has offered to pay for a free round of drinks for all of the 40,000 crowd if a world record goes at the meeting , organisers said on Thursday .</S>
<S>It could be one of the most expensive rounds of drinks ever .</S>
<S>The meeting is sold out already .</S>
<S>Two world records are in serious danger of being broken at the meeting -- the women's 1,000 metres and the men's 3,000 metres .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S>SOCCER - <ORGANIZATION>UEFA</ORGANIZATION> REWARDS THREE COUNTRIES FOR FAIR PLAY .</S>
<S><LOCATION>GENEVA</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S><LOCATION>Norway</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>England</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Sweden</LOCATION> were rewarded for their fair play on Thursday with an additional place in the 1997-98 UEFA Cup competition .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Norway</LOCATION> headed the UEFA Fair Play rankings for 1995-96 with 8.62 points , ahead of <LOCATION>England</LOCATION> with 8.61 and <LOCATION>Sweden</LOCATION> 8.57 .</S>
<S>The rankings are based on a formula that takes into account many factors including red and yellow cards , and coaching and spectators ' behaviour at matches played at an international level by clubs and national teams .</S>
<S>Only the top three countries are allocated additional places .</S>

<S>CRICKET - POLICE COMMANDOS ON HAND FOR AUSTRALIANS ' FIRST MATCH .</S>
<S><LOCATION>COLOMBO</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S>Armed police commandos patrolled the ground when <LOCATION>Australia</LOCATION> opened their short tour of <LOCATION>Sri Lanka</LOCATION> with a five-run win over the country's youth team on Thursday .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Australia</LOCATION> , in <LOCATION>Sri Lanka</LOCATION> for a limited overs tournament which also includes <LOCATION>India</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Zimbabwe</LOCATION> , have been promised the presence of commandos , sniffer dogs and plainclothes policemen to ensure the tournament is trouble-free .</S>
<S>They are making their first visit to the island since boycotting a World Cup fixture in February because of fears over ethnic violence .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Australia</LOCATION> , batting first in Thursday's the warm-up match , scored 251 for seven from their 50 overs .</S>
<S><PERSON>Ricky Ponting</PERSON> led the way with 100 off 119 balls with two sixes and nine fours before retiring .</S>
<S>The youth side replied with 246 for seven .</S>
<S>Australian coach <PERSON>Geoff Marsh</PERSON> said he was impressed with the competitiveness of the opposition .</S>
<S>" We were made to sweat to win , " he said .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>ONE ROMANIAN DIES IN BUS CRASH IN <LOCATION>BULGARIA</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><LOCATION>SOFIA</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S>One Romanian passenger was killed , and 14 others were injured on Thursday when a Romanian-registered bus collided with a Bulgarian one in northern <LOCATION>Bulgaria</LOCATION> , police said .</S>
<S>The two buses collided head on at 5 o'clock this morning on the road between the towns of <LOCATION>Rousse</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Veliko Tarnovo</LOCATION> , police said .</S>
<S>A Romanian woman <PERSON>Maria Marco</PERSON> , 35 , was killed .</S>
<S>The accident was being investigated , police added .</S>
<S>-- <ORGANIZATION>Sofia Newsroom</ORGANIZATION> , 359-2-84561</S>

<S><ORGANIZATION>In Home Health</ORGANIZATION> to appeal payment denial .</S>
<S><LOCATION>MINNETONKA</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Minn</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>In Home Health Inc</ORGANIZATION> said on Thursday it will appeal to the <ORGANIZATION>U.S. Federal District Court</ORGANIZATION> in <LOCATION>Minneapolis</LOCATION> a decision by the <ORGANIZATION>Health Care Financing Administration</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>HCFA</ORGANIZATION> ) that denied reimbursement of certain costs under Medicaid .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>HCFA</ORGANIZATION> Administrator reversed a previously favorable decision regarding the reimbursement of costs related to the company's community liaison personnel , it added .</S>
<S>The company said it continues to believe the majority of the community liaison costs are coverable under the terms of the Medicare program .</S>
<S>" We are disappointed with the administrator's decision but we continue to be optimistic regarding an ultimate favorable resolution , " <PERSON>Mark Gildea</PERSON> , chief executive officer , said in a statement .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>In Home Health</ORGANIZATION> said it previously recorded a reserve equal to 16 percent of all revenue related to the community liaison costs .</S>
<S>Separately , <ORGANIZATION>In Home Health</ORGANIZATION> said the <ORGANIZATION>U.S. District Court</ORGANIZATION> in <LOCATION>Minneapolis</LOCATION> ruled in its favor regarding the reimbursement of certain interest expenses .</S>
<S>This decision will result in the reimbursement by Medicare of $ 81,000 in disputed costs .</S>
<S>" This is our first decision in federal distrct court regarding a dispute with Medicare , " <PERSON>Gildea</PERSON> said . "</S>
<S>We are extremely pleased with this decision and we recognize it as a significant step toward resolution of our outstanding Medicare disputes . "</S>

<S><LOCATION>RICHMOND</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Va</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Best Products Co</ORGANIZATION> Chairman and Chief Executive <PERSON>Daniel Levy</PERSON> said Thursday he expected the company's second-quarter results to be similar to the $ 34.6 million loss posted in the first quarter .</S>
<S>He also told <ORGANIZATION>Reuters</ORGANIZATION> before the retailer's annual meeting that the second quarter could be better than the first quarter ended May 4 . "</S>
<S>We could do even better , " he said .</S>
<S>The second-quarter results are expected to be released in September .</S>
<S><PERSON>Levy</PERSON> said seeking bankruptcy protection was not under consideration .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Best</ORGANIZATION> emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in June 1994 after 3-1/2 years .</S>
<S>" Bankruptcy is always possible , particularly when you lose what we are going to lose in the first half of this year , " <PERSON>Levy</PERSON> said . "</S>
<S>But this is not something we are striving to do . "</S>
<S>The Richmond-based retailer lost $ 95.7 million in the fiscal year ended February 3 .</S>
<S>That was the second-largest loss in the company's history .</S>
<S><PERSON>Levy</PERSON> said that <ORGANIZATION>Best</ORGANIZATION> planned to open two new stores this fall .</S>
<S>The company announced in March that it was closing seven stores and backing out of nine new lease agreements .</S>
<S>At the time , <ORGANIZATION>Best</ORGANIZATION> said it did not plan to open any new stores this fall .</S>
<S>It currently operates 169 stores in 23 states .</S>
<S>For last year's second quarter , which ended July 29 , 1995 , <ORGANIZATION>Best</ORGANIZATION> posted a loss of $ 7.1 million , or $ 0.23 per share , on sales of $ 311.9 million .</S>

<S>Measles exposure can lead to bowel disease - study .</S>
<S><LOCATION>LONDON</LOCATION> 1996-08-23</S>
<S>Women who get measles while pregnant may have babies at higher risk of <PERSON>Crohn</PERSON>'s disease , a debilitating bowel disorder , researchers said on Friday .</S>
<S>Three out of four Swedish babies born to mothers who caught measles developed serious cases of <PERSON>Crohn</PERSON>'s disease , the researchers said .</S>
<S>Dr <PERSON>Andrew Wakefield</PERSON> of the <LOCATION>Royal Free Hospital School of Medicine</LOCATION> and colleagues screened 25,000 babies delivered at <LOCATION>University Hospital</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Uppsala</LOCATION> , between 1940 and 1949 .</S>
<S>Four of the mothers had measles while pregnant .</S>
<S>" Three of the four children had <PERSON>Crohn</PERSON>'s disease , " <PERSON>Wakefield</PERSON>'s group wrote in the <ORGANIZATION>Lancet</ORGANIZATION> medical journal .</S>
<S><PERSON>Crohn</PERSON>'s is an inflammation of the bowel that can sometimes require surgery .</S>
<S>It causes diarrhoea , abdominal pain and weight loss .</S>
<S>The researchers said the three children involved had especially severe cases .</S>
<S>Exposure to viruses can often cause birth defects .</S>
<S>Most notably , women who get rubella ( German measles ) have a high risk of a stillborn baby .</S>

<S>Garlic pills don't lower cholesterol , study finds .</S>
<S><LOCATION>LONDON</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S>Garlic pills may not lower blood cholesterol and studies that show they do may be flawed , British researchers have reported .</S>
<S>A study by a team of doctors at <ORGANIZATION>Oxford University</ORGANIZATION> has found people with high blood cholesterol do not benefit significantly from taking garlic tablets .</S>
<S>The study involved 115 people with high blood cholesterol levels .</S>
<S>They were given 900 milligrams a day of dried garlic powder or placebo tablets . "</S>
<S>There were no significant differences between the groups receiving garlic and placebo , " they wrote in the <ORGANIZATION>Journal of the Royal College of Physicians</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>Those taking part were told to eat a low-fat diet for six weeks before they started taking the pills , and their blood cholesterol measured before and after the six-week period .</S>
<S>The researchers said this would make their findings more accurate .</S>
<S>Several studies have found garlic pills can lower blood pressure and blood cholesterol .</S>
<S>But the <LOCATION>Oxford</LOCATION> team disputed these findings and said either previous trials may have been interpreted incorrectly , those taking part were not given special diets beforehand or the duration of the studies may have been too short .</S>
<S>The six-month trial was funded by the <ORGANIZATION>British Heart Foundation</ORGANIZATION> and <ORGANIZATION>Lichtwer Pharma GmbH</ORGANIZATION> , which makes Kwai brand garlic tablets .</S>
<S>The study did not address whether whole garlic could affect cholesterol .</S>
<S>-- <ORGANIZATION>London Newsroom</ORGANIZATION> +44 171 542 7950</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S><LOCATION>LONDON</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S><LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> said on Thursday it would give 25 million pounds ( $ 39 million ) of development aid to the <LOCATION>Caribbean</LOCATION> island of <LOCATION>Montserrat</LOCATION> , where much of the population living in the south has fled to avoid a volcano .</S>

<S>" This assistance will provide a fast track development programme for the designated ( northern ) safe area , " <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION>'s <ORGANIZATION>Overseas Development Administration</ORGANIZATION> said in a statement .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> gave 8.5 million pounds ( $ 13 million ) to <LOCATION>Montserrat</LOCATION> , which is one of its dependent territories , when the volcano first became active .</S>

<S>Olympic champion <PERSON>Agassi</PERSON> meets <PERSON>Karim Alami</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Morocco</LOCATION> in the first round .</S>
<S>Surprise second seed <PERSON>Michael Chang</PERSON> , ranked third in the world , opens against Czech <PERSON>Daniel Vacek</PERSON> , while women's second seed <PERSON>Monica Seles</PERSON> drew American <PERSON>Anne Miller</PERSON> as her first victim .</S>
<S>Second-ranked Austrian <PERSON>Thomas Muster</PERSON> , who was seeded third , did not have the luck of the draw with him .</S>

<S>Perhaps the best , yet most unfortunate , first-round matchup of the men's competition pits eighth seed <PERSON>Jim Courier</PERSON> against retiring star <PERSON>Stefan Edberg</PERSON> .</S>

<S><ORGANIZATION>RTRS</ORGANIZATION> - Tennis - <PERSON>Muster</PERSON> upset , <PERSON>Philippoussis</PERSON> wins , <PERSON>Stoltenberg</PERSON> loses .</S>
<S><LOCATION>TORONTO</LOCATION> 1996-08-21</S>

<S>The tournament also lost its second seed on the third day of play when second-seeded <PERSON>Goran Ivanisevic</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Croatia</LOCATION> was beaten 6-7(3-7 ) 6-4 6-4 by unseeded <PERSON>Mikael Tillstrom</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Sweden</LOCATION> .</S>

<S>Eighth seed <PERSON>Marc Rosset</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Switzerland</LOCATION> was eliminated in a one hour , 55 minute battle by unseeded <PERSON>Mark Philippoussis</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Australia</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Philippoussis</PERSON> saved a match point at 5-6 in the third-set tie break before winning 6-3 3-6 7-6 ( 8-6 ) .</S>
<S><PERSON>Philippoussis</PERSON>'s compatriot , 13th seed <PERSON>Jason Stoltenberg</PERSON> , was not as fortunate .</S>

<S>" I knew I had to serve well and keep the points short and that's what I was able to do , " said <PERSON>Nestor</PERSON> , who ranks 10th in doubles .</S>
<S>There were only two service breaks in the match .</S>
<S>The lanky Canadian broke <PERSON>Muster</PERSON> at 4-3 in the first set and 5-5 in the second before ending the match on his third match point when the Austrian hit a service return long .</S>
<S>" I probably didn't hit five ground strokes in the whole match , " said <PERSON>Muster</PERSON> , only partly joking . "</S>
<S>The way he was chipping and charging and serving and volleying I didn't really get my timing playing from the baseline . "</S>
<S>" He played a good match , took a few chances , and every time he was down he was able to come up with a big first serve . "</S>
<S>Playing at night was not <PERSON>Muster</PERSON>'s preference . "</S>
<S>I asked for a day match and they gave me a night match , " he said . "</S>
<S>I don't like playing under the lights but maybe it would not have made any difference . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Ivanisevic</PERSON> rallied from a 2-5 deficit in the first set but then played erratically against the 44th-ranked <PERSON>Tillstrom</PERSON> , who was a surprise winner over his famous compatriot <PERSON>Stefan Edberg</PERSON> in the second round at <LOCATION>Wimbledon</LOCATION> .</S>

<S>The sixth-ranked <PERSON>Ivanisevic</PERSON> , who lost in the final at <LOCATION>Indianapolis</LOCATION> to world number one <PERSON>Pete Sampras</PERSON> of the <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> last Sunday , made a quick getaway after his loss but did say : " Something was not there when I arrived ( in <LOCATION>Toronto</LOCATION> ) .</S>
<S>I didn't feel good .</S>
<S>And I didn't have a good feeling as soon as I lost in my doubles ( on Tuesday ) . "</S>
<S>" I thought he looked a little unfocused at certain times on his ground strokes , " said <PERSON>Tillstrom</PERSON> .</S>
<S>The 19-year-old <PERSON>Philippoussis</PERSON> , who beat <PERSON>Sampras</PERSON> in the third round of this year's Australian Open , stayed calm in a nervy third-set tie break against <PERSON>Rosset</PERSON> .</S>
<S>" I'm pleased because I didn't play that great today , but I fought really well , " he said . "</S>
<S>When I was down 2-5 in the tiebreak ( in the third set ) , I just thought about winning my two serves and hoped that he might get tight .</S>
<S>Then he shanked a forehand at to make it 5-all and that helped me back . "</S>

<S>Nigerian Major General <PERSON>Sam Victor Malu</PERSON> took over on Thursday as commander of the <ORGANIZATION>ECOMOG</ORGANIZATION> peacekeeping force in <LOCATION>Liberia</LOCATION> , two days after the start of the latest ceasefire in the six-year civil war .</S>

<S>" The search for peace in <LOCATION>Liberia</LOCATION> has been difficult , challenging and sometimes painful .</S>

<S><ORGANIZATION>United Nations</ORGANIZATION> military observers travelling to the western town of <LOCATION>Tubmanburg</LOCATION> on Wednesday to monitor the ceasefire were delayed by shooting along the highway , <ORGANIZATION>U.N.</ORGANIZATION> special representative <PERSON>Anthony Nyakyi</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>They finally went ahead with an escort from the <ORGANIZATION>ULIMO-J</ORGANIZATION> faction .</S>
<S>Faction leaders who agreed a new peace deal in the Nigerian capital <LOCATION>Abuja</LOCATION> on Saturday have accused each other of breaking the ceasefire .</S>
<S>The latest peace deal foresees the disarmament of an estimated 60,000 combatants and sets a target date of May 30 next year for elections .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>ECOMOG</ORGANIZATION> force , currently 10,000 strong , was sent to <LOCATION>Liberia</LOCATION> by the <ORGANIZATION>Economic Community of West African States</ORGANIZATION> in 1990 at the height of the fighting .</S>

<S><LOCATION>CONAKRY</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>

<S>A government statement , broadcast repeatedly by state radio , said the two days of prayer were " for the dead , for peace and prosperity in <LOCATION>Guinea</LOCATION> , the victory of the new government and the health of the head of state " .</S>
<S>The precise reason for the call was not immediately clear .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Guinea</LOCATION>'s president , <PERSON>Lansana Conte</PERSON> , vice-president of the <ORGANIZATION>Organisation of the Islamic Conference</ORGANIZATION> , left for <LOCATION>Kuwait</LOCATION> on August 16 to prepare the next <ORGANIZATION>OIC</ORGANIZATION> summit in <LOCATION>Pakistan</LOCATION> in 1997 .</S>
<S>Koranic reading sessions and prayers were to be held in the farming town of <LOCATION>Badi-Tondon</LOCATION> , near his home about 60 km ( 40 miles ) from the capital <LOCATION>Conakry</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Conte</PERSON> , an army general , survived a February army pay revolt which at the time he described as a veiled attempt to topple him .</S>
<S>He has since named a prime minister for the first time since early in his rule and ordered a crackdown on corruption .</S>
<S><PERSON>Conte</PERSON> seized power in 1984 after the death of veteran Marxist leader <PERSON>Ahmed Sekou Toure</PERSON> .</S>
<S>He won elections in 1993 .</S>

<S><PERSON>Said</PERSON> , a <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> citizen of Palestinian origin , has been an outspoken critic of the 1993 Israeli-PLO self-rule deal and has written at least two books on the accord .</S>

<S><ORGANIZATION>Palestinian Information Ministry</ORGANIZATION> Director-General <PERSON>Mutawakel Taha</PERSON> denied that ministry officials forced anyone to sign any undertaking and insisted that the <ORGANIZATION>Palestinian Authority</ORGANIZATION> has no plans to censor books .</S>

<S>But <PERSON>Taha</PERSON> said that the absence of relevent legislations may have resulted in some mistakes by some security officials .</S>
<S>" This may explain some mistakes against some journalists and writers , " he said .</S>
<S><PERSON>Daoud</PERSON> said books by other authors , including British Journalist <PERSON>Patrick Seale</PERSON> , were also banned .</S>
<S>He said that security officials often visit his shop to make sure he was not selling the books .</S>
<S>" I think this is a bad beginning .</S>
<S>If we have confidence , why should we be afraid of the other opinion ? "</S>
<S><PERSON>Daoud</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>Thousands of books were banned from sale in the <LOCATION>West Bank</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Gaza Strip</LOCATION> by the Israeli military authorities before the Jewish state handed over parts of the two areas to the <ORGANIZATION>PLO</ORGANIZATION> under a self-rule deal in 1994 .</S>

<S><LOCATION>Egypt</LOCATION> says the Sudanese government helped the Moslem militants who tried to kill <PERSON>Mubarak</PERSON> in <LOCATION>Addis Ababa</LOCATION> last year .</S>
<S>It sponsored last week's <ORGANIZATION>U.N. Security Council</ORGANIZATION> resolution threatening a ban on Sudanese flights abroad if <LOCATION>Khartoum</LOCATION> does not hand over three men accused in the <LOCATION>Addis Ababa</LOCATION> incident .</S>
<S>The sanctions will come into effect in November if <LOCATION>Sudan</LOCATION> fails to extradite the men , but <LOCATION>Sudan</LOCATION> says it cannot hand them over to <LOCATION>Ethiopia</LOCATION> for trial because they are not in <LOCATION>Sudan</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" We are still eager that nothing should affect the Sudanese people but we will not deal with the current regime or the <PERSON>Turabi</PERSON> front or whatever , " <PERSON>Mubarak</PERSON> told a group of academics .</S>
<S><PERSON>Hassan al-Turabi</PERSON> is the leader of the <ORGANIZATION>National Islamic Front</ORGANIZATION> , the political force behind the Sudanese government .</S>
<S>" I don't want to go into more details than that but there are more details and they are bitter .</S>
<S>There are terrorists they are sheltering and they make Sudanese passorts for them and they get paid by them , " <PERSON>Mubarak</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>He did not say if <LOCATION>Egypt</LOCATION> would go so far as to break relations , a step it has been reluctant to take , ostensibly because it would affect ordinary Sudanese .</S>

<S>Turkish shares shed gains in profit-taking .</S>
<S><LOCATION>ISTANBUL</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S>Turkish shares ended lower on Thursday , shedding gains of earlier in the week amid profit-taking sales , brokers said .</S>
<S>The IMKB-100 lost 0.19 percent or 123.89 points to end at 64,178.78 .</S>
<S>Gains so far this week have totalled 2.92 percent .</S>
<S>Daily volume dropped to 7.2 trillion lira from Wednesday's 7.8 trillion lira .</S>
<S>" Profit-taking sales in the afternoon showed the latest gains of the index were actually a reaction rise .</S>
<S>I expect the market to go as far down as 63,000 tomorrow if sales continue , " said <PERSON>Burcin Mavituna</PERSON> from <ORGANIZATION>Interbank</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>Brokers said profit taking sales had come especially as the index approached the 65,000 resistance level .</S>
<S>They said the index could also rise towards 65,000 if the cheap share prices attracted buyers .</S>
<S>The market had its first resistance at 67,000 if it pierced 65,000 , they added .</S>
<S>The session's most active shares were those of <ORGANIZATION>Isbank</ORGANIZATION> gained 300 lira to 8,600 .</S>
<S>Shares of utility <ORGANIZATION>Cukurova</ORGANIZATION> lost 3,000 lira to 67,000 .</S>
<S>The 85-share industrial index lost 0.47 percent to 70,848.86 and the 15-share financial index rose by 0.55 percent to 55,929.89 .</S>
<S>Of the 218 shares traded , gainers outdid losers by 100 to 64 and 54 shares were stable .</S>

<S>In <LOCATION>Venezuela</LOCATION> , her mother told <ORGANIZATION>Reuters</ORGANIZATION> that <PERSON>Machado</PERSON> had a swollen face when she left home two weeks ago because she had her wisdom teeth extracted .</S>

<S>Dressed in a black strapless evening gown at Wednesday's pageant , <PERSON>Machado</PERSON> was clearly heavier than the contestants but still won rave reviews after her brief appearance on stage .</S>

<S>People close to her said she then eased up on her diet and indulged her passion for pasta and cake , but it was not clear how many pounds she gained and most people who saw her said she was still a long way from being fat .</S>
<S><PERSON>Martin Brooks</PERSON> , president of <ORGANIZATION>Miss Universe Inc</ORGANIZATION> , said he spoke with <PERSON>Machado</PERSON> to assure her that organisers were not putting pressure on her .</S>

<S>, at midday and told doctors that she had been paralysed by the disease .</S>

<S>Defiant <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> neo-Nazi jailed by German court .</S>
<S><PERSON>Andrew Gray</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>HAMBURG</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Germany</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S>A <LOCATION>Hamburg</LOCATION> court sentenced <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> neo-Nazi leader <PERSON>Gary Lauck</PERSON> on Thursday to four years in prison for pumping banned extremist propaganda into <LOCATION>Germany</LOCATION> from his base in the <LOCATION>United States</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Lauck</PERSON> , from <LOCATION>Lincoln</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Nebraska</LOCATION> , yelled a tirade of abuse at the court after his conviction for inciting racial hatred .</S>
<S>" The struggle will go on , " the 43-year-old shouted in German before being escorted out by security guards .</S>
<S><PERSON>Lauck</PERSON>'s lawyer vowed he would appeal against the court's decision , arguing that his client should have been set free because he had not committed any offence under German law .</S>
<S>The German government hailed the conviction as a major victory in the fight against neo-Nazism .</S>
<S><PERSON>Lauck</PERSON>'s worldwide network has been the main source of anti-Semitic propaganda material flowing into <LOCATION>Germany</LOCATION> since the 1970s .</S>
<S>" <PERSON>Lauck</PERSON> possessed a well-oiled propaganda machine , honed during more than 20 years , " presiding judge <PERSON>Guenter Bertram</PERSON> told the court .</S>
<S>" He set up a propaganda cannon and fired it at <LOCATION>Germany</LOCATION> . "</S>
<S>said <PERSON>Bertram</PERSON> , who also read out extracts from <PERSON>Lauck</PERSON>'s material praising <PERSON>Hitler</PERSON> as " the greatest of all leaders " and describing the Nazi slaughter of millions of Jews as a myth .</S>
<S>Eager to put <PERSON>Lauck</PERSON> behind bars quickly and avoid a long and complex trial , prosecutor <PERSON>Bernd Mauruschat</PERSON> limited his charges to offences since 1994 .</S>
<S>He had demanded a five-year jail term but said he was satisfied with the court's sentence .</S>
<S>Publishing and distributing neo-Nazi material is illegal in <LOCATION>Germany</LOCATION> but <PERSON>Lauck</PERSON>'s defence team had argued that <LOCATION>U.S</LOCATION> freedom of speech laws meant he was free to produce his swastika-covered books , magazines , videos and flags in his homeland .</S>
<S>Interior Minister <PERSON>Manfred Kanther</PERSON> said in a statement he " welcomed the prosecution and conviction of one of the ringleaders of international neo-Nazism and biggest distributers of vicious racist publications " .</S>
<S>" It is high time he was behind bars , " the opposition Social Democrats said in a statement .</S>
<S><PERSON>Lauck</PERSON> , dressed in a sober blue suit and sporting his trademark Hitleresque black moustache , showed no sign of emotion as <PERSON>Bertram</PERSON> spent more than an hour reading out the verdict and explaining the court's decision .</S>
<S>But as <PERSON>Lauck</PERSON> was about to be led away , he turned to reporters and blurted out a virtually incomprehensible quick-fire diatribe against the court .</S>
<S>" Neither the National Socialists ( Nazis ) nor the communists dared to kidnap an American citizen , " he shouted , in an oblique reference to his extradition to <LOCATION>Germany</LOCATION> from <LOCATION>Denmark</LOCATION> . "</S>
<S>That's the truth . "</S>
<S>His attorney , <PERSON>Hans-Otto Sieg</PERSON> , told reporters outside the courtroom that the judges had not explained how a German court could judge someone for actions carried out in the <LOCATION>United States</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Bertram</PERSON> said <PERSON>Lauck</PERSON> was obsessed by Nazism and devoted his life to leading his <ORGANIZATION>National Socialist German Workers ' Party Foreign Organisation</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>NSDAP-AO</ORGANIZATION> ) , which derives its name from the full German title of <PERSON>Hitler</PERSON>'s Nazi party .</S>
<S>During the three-month trial , the court dealt mainly with issues of the <ORGANIZATION>NSDAP-AO</ORGANIZATION>'s " <ORGANIZATION>NS Kampfruf</ORGANIZATION> " ( " <ORGANIZATION>National Socialist Battle Cry</ORGANIZATION> " ) magazine , filled with references to Aryan supremacy and defamatory statements about Jews .</S>
<S>The court rejected <PERSON>Sieg</PERSON>'s argument that <PERSON>Lauck</PERSON>'s extradition from <LOCATION>Denmark</LOCATION> , where he was arrested in March last year at the request of German authorities , was illegal .</S>
<S><PERSON>Lauck</PERSON> was also convicted of disseminating the symbols of anti-constitutional organisations .</S>
<S>He will probably be free in around two and a half years .</S>
<S>The court ruled that the 15 months he has spent in custody since his arrest should be subtracted from his prison term .</S>

<S><ORGANIZATION>Foreign Ministry</ORGANIZATION> spokesman <PERSON>Martin Erdmann</PERSON> said top <LOCATION>Bonn</LOCATION> diplomat <PERSON>Wolfgang Ischinger</PERSON> had been assured by senior Russian officials that the ultimatum to storm and take the Chechen capital of <LOCATION>Grozny</LOCATION> was not valid .</S>

<DOCUMENT>
<S><LOCATION>India</LOCATION> says sees no arms race with <LOCATION>China</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Pakistan</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><LOCATION>NEW DELHI</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S><LOCATION>India</LOCATION> said on Thursday that its opposition to a global nuclear test ban treaty did not mean <LOCATION>New Delhi</LOCATION> intended to enter into an arms race with neighbouring <LOCATION>Pakistan</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>China</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>Foreign Minister <PERSON>I.K. Gujral</PERSON> was asked at a news conference if <LOCATION>India</LOCATION>'s decision to block adoption of the accord in <LOCATION>Geneva</LOCATION> would lead to an arms race with <LOCATION>Pakistan</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>China</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" I don't see that possibility because <LOCATION>India</LOCATION> is not entering into any arms race , " he said . "</S>
<S>Our not signing a new treaty does not mean we are going in for any new kind of weapons , particularly nuclear . "</S>
<S><LOCATION>China</LOCATION> , along with <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>France</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Russia</LOCATION> and the <LOCATION>United States</LOCATION> , is a declared nuclear power .</S>
<S><LOCATION>India</LOCATION> carried out a nuclear test in 1974 but says it has not built the bomb .</S>
<S>Experts believe both <LOCATION>India</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Pakistan</LOCATION> could quickly assemble nuclear weapons .</S>
<S><PERSON>Gujral</PERSON> said he did not expect <LOCATION>India</LOCATION>'s veto of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty ( CTBT ) to damage bilateral ties with other nations .</S>
<S>" I do not visualise its straining our bilateral relations with any country .</S>
<S>The text has already been blocked , " he said .</S>
<S><PERSON>Gujral</PERSON> said <LOCATION>India</LOCATION> would re-examine its position if the treaty , particularly a clause providing for its entry into force , was modified .</S>
<S>Asked what <LOCATION>India</LOCATION> would do if the pact were forwarded to the <ORGANIZATION>United Nations General Assembly</ORGANIZATION> , <PERSON>Gujral</PERSON> said : " That bridge I will cross when I come to it . "</S>
<S>In a written statement released at the news conference , <PERSON>Gujral</PERSON> reiterated <LOCATION>India</LOCATION>'s objections to the treaty , under negotiation at the Conference on Disarmament in <LOCATION>Geneva</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" It is a sad fact that the nuclear weapon states show no interest in giving up their nuclear hegemony , " the statement said .</S>
<S><PERSON>Gujral</PERSON> said <LOCATION>India</LOCATION> had national security concerns that made it impossible for <LOCATION>New Delhi</LOCATION> to sign the CTBT .</S>
<S>" Our security concerns oblige us to maintain our nuclear option , " he said , adding that <LOCATION>India</LOCATION> had exercised restraint in not carrying out any nuclear tests since the country's lone test blast in 1974 .</S>
<S>He said : " We cannot accept constraints on our option as long as nuclear weapon states continue to rely on their nuclear arsenals for their security " .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S>" The current account deficit of around two percent of GDP is a sustainable level of deficit given the expected real growth rate and the trends in imports and exports , " <PERSON>Rangarajan</PERSON> said in an address to business leaders in <LOCATION>New Delhi</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Rangarajan</PERSON> said a current account deficit of two percent brought about by a 16-17 percent annual growth in exports and a 14-15 percent rise in imports along with an increase in non-debt flows could lead to a reduction in the debt-service ratio to below 20 percent over the next five years .</S>

<DOCUMENT>
<S><PERSON>Mother Teresa</PERSON> devoted to world's poor .</S>
<S><LOCATION>CALCUTTA</LOCATION> 1996-08-22</S>
<S><PERSON>Mother Teresa</PERSON> , known as the <PERSON>Saint of the Gutters</PERSON> , won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979 for bringing hope and dignity to millions of poor , unwanted people with her simple message : " The poor must know that we love them . "</S>
<S>While the world heaps honours on her and even regards her as a living saint , the nun of Albanian descent maintains she is merely doing <PERSON>God</PERSON>'s work .</S>
<S>" It gives me great joy and fulfilment to love and care for the poor and neglected , " she said . "</S>
<S>The poor do not need our sympathy and pity .</S>
<S>They need our love and compassion . "</S>
<S>The diminutive Roman Catholic missionary was on respiratory support in intensive care in an Indian nursing home on Thursday after suffering heart failure .</S>
<S>But an attending doctor said <PERSON>Mother Teresa</PERSON> , who turns 86 next Tuesday , was conscious and in stable condition .</S>
<S>The task <PERSON>Mother Teresa</PERSON> began alone in 1949 in the slums of densely-populated <LOCATION>Calcutta</LOCATION> , and grew to touch the hearts of people around the world .</S>
<S>When in 1979 she was told she had won the Nobel Peace Prize , she said characteristically : " I am unworthy . "</S>
<S>The world disagreed , showering more than 80 national and international honours on her including the Bharat Ratna , or Jewel of India , the country's highest civilian award .</S>
<S>Her health began to deteriorate in 1989 when she was fitted with a heart pacemaker .</S>
<S>A year later , the <LOCATION>Vatican</LOCATION> announced she was stepping down as Superior of her <ORGANIZATION>Missionaries of Charity</ORGANIZATION> order .</S>
<S>More than 100 delegates flew in from around the world to elect a successor .</S>
<S>They could not agree , so asked her to stay on .</S>
<S>She agreed .</S>
<S>In 1991 , <PERSON>Mother Teresa</PERSON> was treated at a <LOCATION>California</LOCATION> hospital for heart disease and bacterial pneumonia .</S>
<S>In 1993 , she fell in <LOCATION>Rome</LOCATION> and broke three ribs .</S>
<S>In August the same year , while in <LOCATION>New Delhi</LOCATION> to receive yet another award , she developed malaria , complicated by her heart and lung problems .</S>
<S>Last April she fractured her left collar bone .</S>
<S>But her increasing frailty , arthritis and failing eyesight has not stopped her travels around the world to mingle with the poor and desperate .</S>
<S><PERSON>Mother Teresa</PERSON> was born <PERSON>Agnes Goinxha Bejaxhiu</PERSON> to Albanian parents in <LOCATION>Skopje</LOCATION> , in what was then <LOCATION>Serbia</LOCATION> , on August 27 , 1910 .</S>
<S>She attended a government school and was already deeply religious by the time she was 12 .</S>
<S>At the age of 18 she became a Loretto nun , hoping to work at the Order's <LOCATION>Calcutta</LOCATION> mission .</S>
<S>She was sent to <LOCATION>Loretto Abbey</LOCATION> in <LOCATION>Dublin</LOCATION> and from there to <LOCATION>India</LOCATION> to begin her novitiate and teach geography at a convent school in <LOCATION>Calcutta</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>She said her divine call to work among the poor came in September , 1946 . "</S>
<S>The message was quite clear , " she told one interviewer . "</S>
<S>I was to leave the convent and help the poor while living among them .</S>
<S>It was an order .</S>
<S>I knew where I belonged . "</S>
<S>The <LOCATION>Vatican</LOCATION> and the mother superior in <LOCATION>Dublin</LOCATION> approved and after intensive training as a nurse with American missionaries she opened her first <LOCATION>Calcutta</LOCATION> slum school in December 1949 .</S>
<S>She took the name of <PERSON>Teresa</PERSON> , after <LOCATION>France</LOCATION>'s Saint <PERSON>Therese</PERSON> of the Child <PERSON>Jesus</PERSON> .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>India</LOCATION> she was simply called <PERSON>Mother</PERSON> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Mother Teresa</PERSON> set up her first home for the dying in a Hindu rest house in <LOCATION>Calcutta</LOCATION> after she saw a penniless woman turned away by a city hospital .</S>
<S>Named " <LOCATION>Nirmal Hriday</LOCATION> " ( <LOCATION>Tender Heart</LOCATION> ) , it was the first of a chain of 150 homes for dying , destitute people , admitting nearly 18,000 a year .</S>
<S>Her <ORGANIZATION>Missionaries of Charity</ORGANIZATION> , a Roman Catholic religious order she founded in 1949 , now runs about 300 homes for unwanted children and the destitute in <LOCATION>India</LOCATION> and abroad .</S>
<S>In 1994 a British television documentary called the myth around <PERSON>Mother Teresa</PERSON> a mixture of " hyperbole and credulity " .</S>
<S>Catholics around the world rose to her defence .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
