<DOCUMENT>
<S><LOCATION>South Africa</LOCATION> yet to hear from apartheid enforcers .</S>
<S><PERSON>Anton Ferreira</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>CAPE TOWN</LOCATION> 1996-08-25</S>
<S><LOCATION>South Africa</LOCATION>'s truth commission begins issuing subpoenas this week in a bid to dig beneath the political rationales and find the sinister figures who have the blood of the country's race war on their hands .</S>
<S>Leaders of the major parties involved , from right-wing whites to radical blacks , appeared before Archbishop <PERSON>Desmond Tutu</PERSON>'s <ORGANIZATION>Truth and Reconciliation Commission</ORGANIZATION> last week to paint the broad picture of their actions for or against apartheid .</S>
<S>Most , including former president <PERSON>F.W. de Klerk</PERSON> and <ORGANIZATION>African National Congress</ORGANIZATION> Deputy President <PERSON>Thabo Mbeki</PERSON> , offered apologies for any mistakes they had made and accepted broad responsibility for the actions of their foot soldiers .</S>
<S>But none named those guilty of ordering or carrying out any of the gross violations of human rights which <PERSON>Tutu</PERSON> is investigating .</S>
<S>Human rights lawyer <PERSON>Brian Currin</PERSON> said the hearings last week were not intended as a form of confessional and that those who personally committed crimes during apartheid would testify only before a separate arm of the commission , the amnesty committee .</S>
<S>" I don't think one should have expected more than what one got , " he said . "</S>
<S>That was not the amnesty committee where perpetrators are expected to open their hearts and souls and to tell it all . "</S>
<S>The commission , which has the power to grant amnesty to those who confess to abuses , has begun hearing the testimony from people already in jail for their deeds .</S>
<S>But others , such as self-confessed secret police hit-squad leader <PERSON>Dirk Coetzee</PERSON> , have yet to testify .</S>
<S><PERSON>Tutu</PERSON>'s deputy chairman , <PERSON>Alex Boraine</PERSON> , told reporters the commission would begin issuing subpoenas to suspects who refused to appear voluntarily some time this week .</S>
<S>He added that former hardline apartheid president <PERSON>P.W. Botha</PERSON> could be among those called .</S>
<S>But <PERSON>Currin</PERSON> , who is advising several people regarded as perpetrators , said this was not the best way to achieve the commission's aims .</S>
<S>" A person can be forced to appear , but the only way one is going to get to the truth in its totality is if people feel it is a good idea to go to the amnesty committee .</S>
<S>At the moment this is not the case . "</S>
<S>He cited <PERSON>Coetzee</PERSON> , who was charged with murder after confessing in media interviews to dirty tricks .</S>
<S>His trial is due to start in December but the truth commission intends to decide on his amnesty application before that .</S>
<S><PERSON>Currin</PERSON> said the law had to be changed so all judicial prosecutions were automatically suspended for those who approached the truth commission .</S>
<S>Last week's submissions to the commission by the <ORGANIZATION>ANC</ORGANIZATION> , <PERSON>de Klerk</PERSON>'s <ORGANIZATION>National Party</ORGANIZATION> and the right-wing <ORGANIZATION>Freedom Front</ORGANIZATION> of General <PERSON>Constand Viljoen</PERSON> left many South Africans unsatisfied .</S>
<S><PERSON>Boraine</PERSON> said the picture was incomplete because officers of the apartheid-era security forces had yet to make their scheduled , separate submission , but one black caller to a radio talk show declared :</S>
<S>" This whole thing is utterly useless , it doesn't help us at all .</S>
<S>What the people expect is to have houses , to have jobs . "</S>
<S>Political scientist <PERSON>Jannie Gagiano</PERSON> said he doubted that the <ORGANIZATION>National Party</ORGANIZATION> , which implemented apartheid in 1948 and began dismantling it in 1990 , felt it carried a burden of guilt and needed to be exculpated through the commission .</S>
<S>" Therefore I have some doubts about achieving some form of reconciliation .</S>
<S>One has to feel a bit guilty to feel the need for reconciling yourself to a historical adversary , " he said .</S>
<S>Professor <PERSON>Tom Lodge</PERSON> of the <ORGANIZATION>University of the Witwatersrand</ORGANIZATION> demurred , saying :</S>
<S>" In the irritation , in the jokes , in the anger that white South Africans express about the commission , I think there's a moral uneasiness , and I think that's healthy .</S>
<S>Responsibility is percolating downwards . "</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>Moslem refugees seek to vote in Serb-held town .</S>
<S><PERSON>Samir Arnaut</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>MATUZICI</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Bosnia</LOCATION> 1996-08-25</S>
<S>Thousands of Moslem refugees denounced <LOCATION>Bosnia</LOCATION>'s elections as a farce on Sunday because Serb incomers would be able to vote in their old home town , cementing partition of the country .</S>
<S>They said they were ready to force their way back across post-war ethnic lines to Serb-held <LOCATION>Doboj</LOCATION> , one of several towns where <ORGANIZATION>NATO</ORGANIZATION> troops fear violence involving refugees determined to vote where they once lived .</S>
<S>The refugees , rallying in <LOCATION>Matuzici</LOCATION> on government territory two km from <LOCATION>Doboj</LOCATION> in northeast <LOCATION>Bosnia</LOCATION> , waved banners calling the polls a farce staged by the <ORGANIZATION>United Nations</ORGANIZATION> and the <ORGANIZATION>European Union</ORGANIZATION> . "</S>
<S>We demand to vote in <LOCATION>Doboj</LOCATION> , " other banners said .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Bosnia</LOCATION>'s Moslem-led central government and many displaced Moslems are angered by a key provision of the Western-organised September 14 elections allowing people to vote in post-war " new places of residence . "</S>
<S>As a result , separatist Serb authorities have packed former Moslem majority towns with refugees of their own or registered other Serbs to vote there .</S>
<S>Critics say that what was billed as an electoral process to reintegrate <LOCATION>Bosnia</LOCATION> as a single , multi-ethnic state is shaping up as a referendum on partition , de facto or de jure .</S>
<S>" Only our physical presence in <LOCATION>Doboj</LOCATION> will mean that the <LOCATION>Dayton</LOCATION> peace treaty has truly been implemented , " <PERSON>Edhem Efendija Camdzic</PERSON> , <LOCATION>Doboj</LOCATION>'s Islamic imam-in-exile , told the refugees .</S>
<S>" The main point of this rally is to highlight to the world powers what misfortune they brought upon us , " said <PERSON>Reuf Mehemdagic</PERSON> , head of <LOCATION>Doboj</LOCATION> municipality-in-exile .</S>
<S>" Eleven thousand Serbs who came from elsewhere to <LOCATION>Doboj</LOCATION> will vote there .</S>
<S>How can we then expect the reintegration of <LOCATION>Bosnia</LOCATION> ?</S>
<S>But no one will stop us from returning to our homes . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Mirhunisa Komarica</PERSON> , a government refugee official , said : " We want to vote where we were thrown out from .</S>
<S>This is a protest of warning and the next step is entering our town using all means possible , so let them shoot . "</S>
<S>Bosnian Vice President <PERSON>Ejup Ganic</PERSON> , a Moslem , told the refugees : " We have a message for the Serbs who are now in our homes not to plan the future of their children there because there will be no good fortune in that . "</S>
<S>To loud applause , he added : " We will enter <LOCATION>Doboj</LOCATION> , untie the <LOCATION>Doboj</LOCATION> knot and ensure free movement for all .</S>
<S>We have to enter <LOCATION>Doboj</LOCATION> to free the Serbs from their own ( separatist ) politics . "</S>
<S>The <LOCATION>Dayton</LOCATION> peace accords guaranteed refugees the right to return to their homes and ensured freedom of movement across ethnic lines .</S>
<S>But local police , controlled by nationalist parties in Moslem , Serb and Croat sectors of <LOCATION>Bosnia</LOCATION> , and civilian mobs have turned ceasefire lines into virtually impassable borders .</S>
<S>The majority of refugees from <LOCATION>Bosnia</LOCATION>'s 1992-95 war are Moslems from the Serb-controlled north and east .</S>
<S>NATO-led peace troops beefed up their presence in the <LOCATION>Doboj</LOCATION> area on Sunday to deter any sudden emotional attempt by the refugees to cross the <LOCATION>Inter-Entity Boundary Line</LOCATION> into <LOCATION>Doboj</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>But the crowd dispersed without incident .</S>
<S>Moslems and Serbs have scuffled several times along the line in the past when Moslem refugees tried to surge into the town .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>Eight killed in <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> casino blaze .</S>
<S><LOCATION>MOSCOW</LOCATION> 1996-08-25</S>
<S>Eight people died on Sunday in a blaze at a <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> casino which the fire service said might have been started deliberately , <ORGANIZATION>Interfax</ORGANIZATION> news agency said .</S>
<S>The number of casinos has soared in <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> since the collapse of communism .</S>
<S>The mayor has said he wants to cut their number to five as part of a war against organised crime .</S>
<S>President <PERSON>Boris Yeltsin</PERSON> signed a decree on fighting crime in July and handed wide-ranging powers to security chief <PERSON>Alexander Lebed</PERSON> , currently engaged in making peace in breakaway <LOCATION>Chechnya</LOCATION> .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>Russian troops start pullout , but not in <LOCATION>Grozny</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><LOCATION>SHATOI</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Russia</LOCATION> 1996-08-25</S>
<S>Russian troops began to pull out from southern <LOCATION>Chechnya</LOCATION> on Sunday under a ceasefire agreement between Russian security chief <PERSON>Alexander Lebed</PERSON> and rebel leaders .</S>
<S>But in the capital <LOCATION>Grozny</LOCATION> , the commander of Russian Interior Ministry forces in <LOCATION>Chechnya</LOCATION> , General <PERSON>Anatoly Shkirko</PERSON> , told <ORGANIZATION>Interfax</ORGANIZATION> news agency he was delaying a pullout of troops there after a group of Chechens disarmed an armoured column .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Reuters</ORGANIZATION> cameraman <PERSON>Liutauras Stremaitis</PERSON> said a column of around 40 vehicles , including tanks , armoured personnel carriers , artillery cannons and lorries , escorted by Chechen rebels , pulled out of the village of <LOCATION>Shatoi</LOCATION> towards the border , around 50 km ( 31 miles ) to the north .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Grozny</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Shkirko</PERSON> told <ORGANIZATION>Interfax</ORGANIZATION> he was suspending the pullout of troops from the capital until weapons seized by the Chechens were returned .</S>
<S>Chechen rebel spokesman <PERSON>Movladi Udugov</PERSON> confirmed the weapons had been seized but that it was a maverick group of Chechens .</S>
<S>He said later that the rebels had handed them over .</S>
<S>The pullout of the Russian troops is a key element of the peace plan brokered by <PERSON>Lebed</PERSON> , which aims to end the 20-month <LOCATION>Chechnya</LOCATION> conflict .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>Leftist Mexican armed group says troops in capital .</S>
<S><LOCATION>MEXICO CITY</LOCATION> 1996-08-25</S>
<S>The leftist <ORGANIZATION>Popular Revolutionary Army</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>EPR</ORGANIZATION> ) in a published report on Sunday said it operated throughout <LOCATION>Mexico</LOCATION> , including the capital , and denied government assertions it was isolated to one state .</S>
<S>Commanders " <PERSON>Vicente</PERSON> " and " <PERSON>Oscar</PERSON> " , guarded by a dozen <ORGANIZATION>EPR</ORGANIZATION> gunmen , said in an interview with <ORGANIZATION>La Jornada</ORGANIZATION> outside <LOCATION>Mexico City</LOCATION> that the armed group was committed to overthrowing the government .</S>
<S>" They ( government officials ) want to present us before public opinion as a local problem , as just being from <LOCATION>Guerrero</LOCATION> and as irrational radicals , " Commander <PERSON>Oscar</PERSON> told <ORGANIZATION>La Jornada</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>They said the <ORGANIZATION>ERP</ORGANIZATION> , whose fighters first appeared wearing military fatigues and brandishing assault rifles in the southwestern state of <LOCATION>Guerrero</LOCATION> on June 28 , had a 23,000-strong membership , but this could not be confirmed independently .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>La Jornada</ORGANIZATION> also reported on Sunday that the <ORGANIZATION>Mexican Army</ORGANIZATION> has discovered a 37-page , <ORGANIZATION>EPR</ORGANIZATION> manual detailing guerrilla tactics and strategies .</S>
<S>It quoted the manual as saying : " The objective of the Basic Course on War is to provide for combatants of the <ORGANIZATION>EPR</ORGANIZATION> basic military knowledge for the armed conflict against the police and military apparatus of the bourgeoisie . "</S>
<S>It was the second time armed " commanders " of the <ORGANIZATION>EPR</ORGANIZATION> have granted interviews outside <LOCATION>Guerrero</LOCATION> state , an extremely poor and volatile region where leftist protesters often have clashed violently with authorities .</S>
<S>Unlike the better known and unrelated <ORGANIZATION>Zapatista</ORGANIZATION> rebels in southeastern <LOCATION>Chiapas</LOCATION> state , the <ORGANIZATION>EPR</ORGANIZATION> has never taken on the army in direct combat , according to official reports .</S>
<S>There have only been a few skirmishes in <LOCATION>Guerrero</LOCATION> in which a handful of police , soldiers and civilians have been killed or injured .</S>

<S>The two were wounded in the early hours of Sunday when some 30 members of the <ORGANIZATION>Democratic Karen Buddhist Army</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>DKBA</ORGANIZATION> ) ambushed their patrol on the Thai side of the border with <LOCATION>Burma</LOCATION> , to the north of the town of <LOCATION>Mae Sot</LOCATION> .</S>

<S><PERSON>Suvit</PERSON> said the motive for their intrusions was not clear but he had ordered reinforcements to beef up security along the porous frontier .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>DKBA</ORGANIZATION> was formed in late 1994 by hundreds of guerrillas who split from the anti-Rangoon <ORGANIZATION>Karen National Union</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>KNU</ORGANIZATION> ) and allied themselves with Burmese government army , their former enemies .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>DKBA</ORGANIZATION> members have since launched intermittent cross-border attacks on Karen refugee camps in <LOCATION>Thailand</LOCATION> , where the majority of inhabitants are <ORGANIZATION>KNU</ORGANIZATION> supporters , and on Thai villages and police posts near the border .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Bangkok</LOCATION> has complained to <LOCATION>Rangoon</LOCATION> about the raids but Burmese military authorities say they have no contol over the faction .</S>
<S>Thai army commanders reject the explanation , saying they have evidence the Burmese army supplies and directs the renegade ethnic minority splinter faction .</S>

<S><LOCATION>Egypt</LOCATION> hopes jars will reveal secrets of mummies .</S>
<S><LOCATION>CAIRO</LOCATION> 1996-08-25</S>
<S>Archaeologists in <LOCATION>Egypt</LOCATION> have found pots used by ancient Egyptians in burial rites that they say may reveal the secrets of mummification .</S>
<S><PERSON>Mohammed Saleh</PERSON> , director of the Egyptian Museum , told <ORGANIZATION>Reuters</ORGANIZATION> television a <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> team found the pots , some of which contain human intestines , in a tomb built into the rocks while digging in <LOCATION>Dahshour</LOCATION> , a village 40 km ( 25 miles ) south of <LOCATION>Cairo</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Dahshour</LOCATION> is the site of <LOCATION>Egypt</LOCATION>'s second largest pyramid , built for the pharaoh <PERSON>Seneferu</PERSON> more than 4,500 years ago .</S>
<S><PERSON>Saleh</PERSON> said the team -- from <LOCATION>New York</LOCATION>'s <LOCATION>Metropolitan Museum</LOCATION> -- found four Canopic jars and two unguent jars in the tomb , which belongs to an unidentifed person who lived during the 12th Dynasty ( 1991-1786 BC ) in the <LOCATION>Middle Kingdom</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" This finding is important because one of the jars still contains substances and materials used in the conservation of mummies and the conservation of the intestines and all the things which were in the cavity of a person we have not identified yet , " <PERSON>Saleh</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>" We hope that the analysis of such substances and liquids will reveal some secrets of the mummification process and materials used in this process , " he added .</S>

<S>Israeli president invites <PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> to home - paper .</S>
<S><LOCATION>JERUSALEM</LOCATION> 1996-08-25</S>
<S>Israeli President <PERSON>Ezer Weizman</PERSON> has invited <PERSON>Yasser Arafat</PERSON> to meet him at his private home , <LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION>'s biggest newspaper said on Sunday .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Yedioth Ahronoth</ORGANIZATION> daily reported that Prime Minister <PERSON>Benjamin Netanyahu</PERSON> , who has said he has no desire to hold talks with the Palestinian president , opposes the meeting due to be held this coming week .</S>
<S>The newspaper said <PERSON>Weizman</PERSON> scheduled the meeting at his private residence in the central Israeli village of <LOCATION>Caesarea</LOCATION> after <PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> sent him an emotional appeal " to save the peace process " .</S>
<S><PERSON>Netanyahu</PERSON> met <PERSON>Weizman</PERSON> last Tuesday and voiced his opposition , <ORGANIZATION>Yedioth</ORGANIZATION> said .</S>
<S>" I am prepared to postpone the meeting under one condition -- that you give me a commitment right now to meet <PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> yourself within 10 days , " the paper quoted <PERSON>Weizman</PERSON> as telling <PERSON>Netanyahu</PERSON> .</S>
<S>It said <PERSON>Netanyahu</PERSON> had yet to give <PERSON>Weizman</PERSON> an answer .</S>
<S>The office of Israeli president is largely ceremonial .</S>
<S>But <PERSON>Weizman</PERSON> , a former defence minister and an architect of <LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION>'s peace treaty with <LOCATION>Egypt</LOCATION> , has spoken out frequently on the peace process with the Palestinians -- at times urging the former <ORGANIZATION>Labour</ORGANIZATION> government to slow it down .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>Corporate <LOCATION>America</LOCATION> taking new view on compensation .</S>
<S><PERSON>Anne Murray</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>NEW YORK</LOCATION> 1996-08-23</S>
<S>Corporate <LOCATION>America</LOCATION> is planning major changes in employee compensation in the next few years , according to a recent study .</S>
<S>What it comes down to is this : If you're highly skilled , you'll benefit nicely .</S>
<S>But if you're not and cannot contribute to your employer's goals , you'll be paid less .</S>
<S>The survey , conducted in late 1995 and the early part of this year by management consulting firm <ORGANIZATION>Towers Perrin</ORGANIZATION> , showed that the focus will be on an employee's overall value to the company's bottom line -- rather than how well an employee performs a specific task .</S>
<S>Presently , for example , if an accountant's job involves doing five specific tasks , he or she can expect a certain salary , said <PERSON>Sandra O'Neal</PERSON> , a <ORGANIZATION>Towers Perrin</ORGANIZATION> principal .</S>
<S>In the future , the accountant will be evaluated solely on " knowledge , skill and abilities , " she said .</S>
<S>In addition to using accounting skills , the accountant will also have to be creative , work well in a team , be sensitive to customer needs and set productivity goals .</S>
<S>" The good news is , if you're highly skilled and have many abilities , you'll be paid more , " said <PERSON>O'Neal</PERSON> .</S>
<S>" The bad news is , if you're not skilled and can't contribute to a team , to customer service and the organisation's goals , you'll be paid less . "</S>
<S>Of the 750 mid-to-large size corporations surveyed , 81 percent had undergone a major restructuring in the last three years , and more than two-thirds reported that productivity and profits were up as result .</S>
<S>Next on the agenda for these firms is developing a new compensation structure , and 78 percent report that they are considering a new , skills-based plan for both management and non-management employees .</S>
<S>This coming shift , <PERSON>O'Neal</PERSON> said , " is not just isolated or a fad .</S>
<S>It's an inexorable change . "</S>
<S>After World War II , corporations adopted a " military model " creating hierarchical organisations where " the concept of defined tasks worked great , " she said .</S>
<S>But as the economy became global , customers were more demanding and problems became more complex .</S>
<S>" Multi-layers kept management at a distance from its customers , " <PERSON>O'Neal</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>Now organisations must change to stay competitive .</S>
<S><PERSON>O'Neal</PERSON> says firms will place a greater emphasis on teams and team performance in giving raises .</S>
<S>If your team does well , you'll do well .</S>
<S>If it doesn't do well , don't expect a raise .</S>
<S>Is this fair to an employee who can go the distance but is on a team that can't keep up ?</S>
<S>" That's an important question we used to ask a lot , " said <PERSON>O'Neal</PERSON> . "</S>
<S>It's not a question we ask any more .</S>
<S>The more important question is -- ' Do we have results ? '</S>
<S>To get those results , 27 percent of the companies surveyed plan to eliminate base pay increases in favour of cash bonuses and incentives , such as employee and team award programmes and education .</S>
<S>Companies that can change their culture and view employees as business partners will do well , <PERSON>O'Neal</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>For example , the survey rated some participants in the survey as " high-performing " companies , based on their return on equity above 16 percent .</S>
<S>Those companies also said they already offer employees variable pay and business education , give their managers more control over pay decisions and celebrate employee and team success .</S>
<S>" They respect employees more , they trust employees more and they value their employees more , " <PERSON>O'Neal</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>" The key to success at high-performance companies is engaging employees in a business partnership .</S>
<S>It will improve a company's bottom line . "</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>

<S>Belgian media reported that he had been questioned twice in the past two years about thefts but released both times .</S>

<S>One was <PERSON>Gerard Pignon</PERSON> , the owner of a warehouse where stolen vehicles were allegedly stored .</S>
<S>The other was insurer <PERSON>Thierry Dehaan</PERSON> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Bourlet</PERSON> said the investigation into the vehicle theft ring would be added to the inquiry into the paedophile sex scandal in which five other people have already been arrested .</S>
<S>He said the connection was through <PERSON>Bernard Weinstein</PERSON> , an accomplice of convicted child rapist <PERSON>Marc Dutroux</PERSON> -- the central figure in the paedophile scandal that has sent shockwaves across <LOCATION>Europe</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Weinstein</PERSON> was found dead last weekend alongside the bodies of eight-year-olds <PERSON>Julie Lejeune</PERSON> and <PERSON>Melissa Russo</PERSON> in a house belonging to <PERSON>Detroux</PERSON> , who said they starved to death earlier this year , nine months after being abducted in June 1995 .</S>
<S>Two other girls have been rescued and police are hunting for at least two more who <PERSON>Dutroux</PERSON> has admitted kidnapping a year ago .</S>
<S>" <PERSON>Dutroux</PERSON> has admitted killing <PERSON>Weinstein</PERSON> after a disagreement between the accomplices in an affair of truck theft , " <PERSON>Bourlet</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>Another four people were also questioned at the weekend but had not been detained , <PERSON>Bourlet</PERSON> added .</S>
<S><PERSON>Anne Thily</PERSON> , public prosecutor in the eastern city of <LOCATION>Liege</LOCATION> where <PERSON>Julie</PERSON> and <PERSON>Melissa</PERSON> lived , said this was a major case involving some 50 investigators -- including two from the <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> <ORGANIZATION>Federal Bureau of Investigation</ORGANIZATION> .</S>

<S><LOCATION>DHAKA</LOCATION> 1996-08-25</S>
<S>Students backed by opposition parties battled police and burned an effigy of Prime Minister Sheikh <PERSON>Hasina</PERSON> during a strike in the north Bangladeshi town of <LOCATION>Bogra</LOCATION> on Sunday .</S>
<S>The strikers barricaded streets , attacked the local office of the ruling <ORGANIZATION>Awami League</ORGANIZATION> , fought running battles with police and set alight hundreds of copies of the popular " <ORGANIZATION>Janakantha</ORGANIZATION> " newspaper , alleging it was pro-government .</S>
<S>Police used batons and teargas to try to disperse students who were throwing stones and home-made bombs , witnesses said .</S>
<S>The strike , called by the main opposition <ORGANIZATION>Bangladesh Nationalist Party</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>BNP</ORGANIZATION> ) , to denounce the deaths of four students killed by police over the last few days , coincided with a visit to the area by <PERSON>Hasina</PERSON> .</S>
<S>Local officials said one policeman was killed by gunshots during clashes with pro-opposition students on Thursday .</S>
<S><PERSON>Hasina</PERSON> told a cross section of people at the <LOCATION>Bogra</LOCATION> police headquarters on Sunday that the government had already suspended three police officers and ordered a judicial probe into the violent incidents .</S>
<S>The prime minister offered financial grants to the families of those killed , ordered the best possible medical care for the injured and urged <LOCATION>Bogra</LOCATION> residents to call off the strike .</S>
<S>Opposition legislators walked out of parliament in <LOCATION>Dhaka</LOCATION> on Sunday denouncing " unprecedented police barbarity " against opposition students and supporters .</S>
<S>They renewed their call for the resignation of Home ( Interior ) Minister <PERSON>Rafiqul Islam</PERSON> .</S>
<S>Hundreds of police raided the <LOCATION>Dhaka</LOCATION> university on Sunday , arresting nearly 30 outsiders who had been living in student dormitories and seizing weapons , university officials said .</S>
<S>Police stormed ten residence halls on the campus , flushed out people at gunpoint and searched their baggage .</S>
<S>They seized revolvers , sawn-off rifles , shotguns and knives .</S>
<S>The students were later allowed to return .</S>
<S>The swoop followed the resignation of the university's Vice-Chancellor Dr. <PERSON>Emajuddin Ahmed</PERSON> on Saturday over the deteriorating law and order situation on the campus .</S>
<S>Authorities closed down the 28,000-student university on Wednedsay following gunbattles between students and police .</S>
<S>Police said they fought armed activists from the <ORGANIZATION>BNP</ORGANIZATION> , headed by former prime minister <PERSON>Begum Khaleda Zia</PERSON> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Hasina</PERSON> told police the home ministry had already given a " blanket order " to arrest terrorists and possessors of illegal firearms irrespective of their political identities .</S>
<S>Nearly 100 students have been injured in the clashes in <LOCATION>Dhaka</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Bogra</LOCATION> , police told reporters .</S>

<S>16 die as bus crashes in <LOCATION>Pakistani Kashmir</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><LOCATION>MUZAFFARABAD</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Pakistan</LOCATION> 1996-08-25</S>
<S>At least 16 people were killed and several injured on Sunday when a bus fell from a mountain road into a ravine on a river bank in Pakistan-ruled <LOCATION>Azad ( free ) Kashmir</LOCATION> , police said .</S>
<S>They said 14 out of 45 passengers on the bus died instantly when the vehicle fell from the narrow road while on its way from the state capital <LOCATION>Muzaffarabad</LOCATION> to the nearby Pakistani town of <LOCATION>Garhi Habibullah</LOCATION> in the northwest .</S>
<S>Two died later in hospital .</S>

<DOCUMENT>
<S>FEATURE - Fertile <LOCATION>Ukraine</LOCATION> faces drought of cash and rain .</S>
<S><PERSON>Irene Marushko</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>BATKIVSHCHYNA COLLECTIVE FARM</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Ukraine</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S>Four shiny new green-and-yellow <PERSON>John Deere</PERSON> combines parked at this 1,750-hectare ( 4,325-acre ) farm in the grain-growing regions south of <LOCATION>Kiev</LOCATION> don't fill its chief agronomist with enthusiasm .</S>
<S>" They did a good job this year , but they need good diesel and good engine oil , " said <PERSON>Ivan Odnosum</PERSON> . "</S>
<S><PERSON>God</PERSON> help us if there is a breakdown , " he said of the machinery , loaned to the farm after the Ukrainian government bought it earlier this year .</S>
<S>The country's grain harvest this year is forecast to fall by more than 23 percent to only 28 million tonnes and two harsh factors are to blame .</S>
<S>A drought scoured the steppes in May and June , stunting the growing wheat .</S>
<S>And the farming sector , making the painful transition from Soviet central planning to a market economy simply has no money .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Ukraine</LOCATION>'s black soil is so fertile that a diplomat described it as " rich enough to grow rubber boots " .</S>
<S>But recently <LOCATION>Ukraine</LOCATION> has been losing its reputation as a breadbasket of <LOCATION>Europe</LOCATION> , earned in the years before brutal forced collectivisation under Soviet dictator <PERSON>Josef Stalin</PERSON> .</S>
<S>" The wheat will not be of a good quality this year , " said <PERSON>Hryhory Borsuk</PERSON> , a scientist at the <ORGANIZATION>Mironivka Wheat Institute</ORGANIZATION> , run by the <ORGANIZATION>Ukrainian Academy of Agrarian Sciences</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>" The temperature on the ground reached 62 decrees Celsius ( 143.60 Fahrenheit ) this summer .</S>
<S>We've never seen anything so bad , " he said in an interview in his office , unlit since the government cut off electricity because of unpaid power bills .</S>
<S>The harvest is gathered in the dry areas , but rainfall in <LOCATION>Western Ukraine</LOCATION> has delayed harvesting there .</S>
<S>While <ORGANIZATION>Mironivka</ORGANIZATION>'s scientists , some unpaid for months , carry on developing new strains of wheat resistant to <LOCATION>Ukraine</LOCATION>'s extreme continental climate , <PERSON>Borsuk</PERSON> said the lack of cash in <LOCATION>Ukraine</LOCATION>'s agricultural sector is as bad as the drought .</S>
<S>Collective farms and <LOCATION>Ukraine</LOCATION>'s nascent private farming sector have no money for fertiliser , no money for herbicides and pesticides , no money to repair old or buy new machinery , no money for fuel , and none to buy good seed .</S>
<S>This year's harvest is down from last year's 36.5 million tonne harvest , which in turn compares with 50 million tonnes in 1990 , the year before independence .</S>
<S>The decline is all the worse for people who recall wasteful Soviet times , when the <LOCATION>Kremlin</LOCATION> imported grain but priced bread so cheaply that people bought it to feed their pigs .</S>
<S>" Agriculture is very expensive , and there are no solutions to our problems on the horizon , " said <PERSON>Odnosum</PERSON> .</S>
<S>He said his farm , its 260 workers now readying the fields for winter wheat sowing , expected the land to yield 5.2 tonnes per hectare ( 2.5 acres ) but ended up with 3.9 tonnes -- still better than the national average of 2.11 tonnes per hectare this year .</S>
<S>" We did not have money for fertiliser , we're in debt for fuel , and we're borrowing diesel , " <PERSON>Odnosum</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>A few kilometres ( miles ) down the two-lane road which passes <PERSON>Odnosum</PERSON>'s farm , where the occasional horse-drawn buggy passes by , is the 1,700-hectare ( 4,200-acre ) <PERSON>Shevchenko</PERSON> collective farm , built next to a village still neat and tidy despite post-Soviet decay .</S>
<S>Chief Accountant <PERSON>Natalya Sypron</PERSON> said the collective is strapped for cash , earlier this year bartering 220 tonnes of grain for diesel to fuel six rickety grain combines and tractors badly in need of repairs and basic maintenance .</S>
<S>The average family earns 160-200 million karbovanets a year ( $ 800 - $ 1,000 ) -- but many have not been paid in months , <PERSON>Soprun</PERSON> said . "</S>
<S>People are working out of their own dedication . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Borsuk</PERSON> said the farm sector has two options : " We can sit down and cry , or we can do something . "</S>
<S>He said the government plans to increase the sowing of the winter wheat which will be harvested next year .</S>
<S>Planted in late summer and early autumn , the grain is <LOCATION>Ukraine</LOCATION>'s largest export item and traditionally grows better than summer wheat in <LOCATION>Ukraine</LOCATION>'s soil .</S>
<S>Further plans , he said , called for full provision of resources like fertiliser and herbicides for 25 percent of <LOCATION>Ukraine</LOCATION>'s arable land next year , for 50 percent in 1998 and 100 percent of the land in 1999 .</S>
<S>" If we follow this we'll be able to sell 10 million tonnes of grain by the year 2000 , " <PERSON>Borkus</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>The government has been trying to phase out huge subsidies to the farm sector , and in a move back to pre-Soviet days has given up to 50 hectares ( 124 acres ) of land to some 36,000 private farmers willing to go it alone .</S>
<S>Collective farms will last for the next few years , because most private farms now only produce enough to feed themselves with maybe a little extra to sell , said one private farmer : " In the future , maybe , but it's better not to hurry .</S>
<S>" Collectivisation brought us a lot of pain .</S>
<S>And it went too fast .</S>
<S>Privatising too quickly can also have a negative outcome . "</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Gencor</ORGANIZATION> swells profit despite setbacks .</S>
<S><PERSON>Melanie Cheary</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>JOHANNESBURG</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Gencor Ltd</ORGANIZATION> on Monday said it had swelled its year attributable profit and streamlined operations to strengthen it for the current financial year despite a variety of divisional setbacks .</S>
<S>Announcing the group's results for the year ended June 30 , chairman <PERSON>Brian Gilbertson</PERSON> said : " Happily the strong improvement in financial performance is not an illusion arising from the recent weakness of the rand relative to the dollar . "</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Gencor</ORGANIZATION> raised attributable earnings to 1,803 million rand from 1,003 million rand previously - in dollar terms an increase to $ 469 million from $ 279 million - and won despite the group's <ORGANIZATION>Impala Platinum Holdings Ltd</ORGANIZATION> posting dismal results .</S>
<S>" Not everything has gone well .</S>
<S>We've had substantial production difficulties at a number of our operations .</S>
<S>The most obvious one with the greatest effect on the corporation was at <ORGANIZATION>Impala</ORGANIZATION> where we had the furnace failure , " <PERSON>Gilbertson</PERSON> said .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Implats</ORGANIZATION> posted year attributable profit of 176 million rand from 281 million previously .</S>
<S>Not only did the company lock in 3.92 rand per dollar in February / March , but it suffered output losses due to a furnace shutdown last August .</S>
<S>The rand was last bid at 4.5350 against the dollar .</S>
<S>Nor was <ORGANIZATION>Implats</ORGANIZATION> the only operation to fail output targets .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Ingwe Coal Corporation Ltd</ORGANIZATION> was hit hard by heavy rains .</S>
<S>It forfeited nearly one million tonnes of production to flooding at its mines in <LOCATION>Mpumulanga</LOCATION> province .</S>
<S>But <PERSON>Gilbertson</PERSON> said the greatest gloom in the year came from the <ORGANIZATION>European Commission</ORGANIZATION>'s blocking of <ORGANIZATION>Implats</ORGANIZATION> ' proposed merger with <ORGANIZATION>Lonrho Plc</ORGANIZATION>'s platinum interests .</S>
<S>" The big disappointment for the year was the failure of the platinum merger .</S>
<S>From <ORGANIZATION>Gencor</ORGANIZATION>'s perspective we are taking the position that it is not on , " <PERSON>Gilbertson</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>Looking ahead to the current financial year , he said that <ORGANIZATION>Gencor</ORGANIZATION> would boost earnings further .</S>
<S>" <ORGANIZATION>Gencor</ORGANIZATION> is well placed to take up the challenges of the future .</S>
<S>The group is soundly structured and prudently financed and is blessed with an excellent portfolio of world-class businesses .</S>
<S>I think we can look forward to further growth " .</S>
<S>Citing the disposal of <ORGANIZATION>Gencor</ORGANIZATION>'s stake in industrial holdings group <ORGANIZATION>Malbak Ltd</ORGANIZATION> for one billion rand among other smaller disposals , <PERSON>Gilbertson</PERSON> said <ORGANIZATION>Gencor</ORGANIZATION> had pruned its portfolio to concentrate on core assets .</S>
<S>" We've tried to clean up our overall portfolio by disposing of non-core assets .</S>
<S>The biggest of those was <ORGANIZATION>Malbak</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>Overall a very substantial pruning ...</S>
<S>leaving <ORGANIZATION>Gencor</ORGANIZATION> clearly structured along commodity lines , " <PERSON>Gilbertson</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>He added that the group still had about 85 million rand after tax invested in various shares , which were market for disposal when required .</S>
<S>Referring to <ORGANIZATION>Gencor</ORGANIZATION>'s increased 41.5 percent stake in <ORGANIZATION>Ingwe</ORGANIZATION> , <PERSON>Gilbertson</PERSON> said the group would wait for coal shares to be cheaper before considering snapping up more .</S>
<S>" I think we would have liked to have more of <ORGANIZATION>Ingwe</ORGANIZATION> but it's the question of adding value .</S>
<S>When we bought the shares we bought ...</S>
<S>at quite a bit lower than the price is now ...</S>
<S>maybe if we just wait another few years for the next downturn in coal . "</S>
<S>Finally , <PERSON>Gilbertson</PERSON> said a growing proportion of <ORGANIZATION>Gencor</ORGANIZATION>'s income was coming from offshore and unlisted investments .</S>
<S>-- <LOCATION>Johannesburg</LOCATION> newsroom +27 11 482-1003</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Advanced Medical</ORGANIZATION> buying <ORGANIZATION>IVAC Medical</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><LOCATION>SAN DIEGO</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Advanced Medical Inc.</ORGANIZATION> said Monday it will buy <ORGANIZATION>IVAC Medical Systems Inc.</ORGANIZATION> , a former <ORGANIZATION>Eli Lilly & Co</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>unit , for about $ 400 million in cash , creating one of the world's largest makers of intravenous infusion therapy products .</S>
<S>Under the agreement , <ORGANIZATION>IVAC</ORGANIZATION> and <ORGANIZATION>Advanced Medical</ORGANIZATION>'s wholly owned subsidiary , <ORGANIZATION>IMED Corp.</ORGANIZATION> , will merge to form a new company that will develop and manufacture infusion pumps that regulate the amount of intravenous fluid being administered to a patient , as well as proprietary disposable products .</S>
<S>The combined company will have estimated revenues of $ 353 million .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Advanced Medical</ORGANIZATION> , through <ORGANIZATION>IMED</ORGANIZATION> , is already one of the nation's largest developers and manufacturers of intravenous infusion pumps and proprietary disposable products .</S>
<S>It has sales in 38 foreign countries .</S>
<S>San Diego-based <ORGANIZATION>IVAC</ORGANIZATION> is a major provider of infusion systems and related technologies to the health-care industry .</S>
<S>It has manufacturing plants in <LOCATION>San Diego</LOCATION> ; <LOCATION>Creedmoor</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>N.C.</LOCATION> ; <LOCATION>Hampshire</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>England</LOCATION> ; and <LOCATION>Tijuana</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Mexico</LOCATION> , and distributes its prodcuts in more than 120 countries .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Eli Lilly</ORGANIZATION> sold <ORGANIZATION>IVAC</ORGANIZATION> on Dec. 31 , 1994 to <ORGANIZATION>DLJ Merchant Banking Partners LP</ORGANIZATION> , <ORGANIZATION>River Medical Inc.</ORGANIZATION> and other investors .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Advanced Medical</ORGANIZATION> said it expects to take an unspecified one-time charge to pay for the merger .</S>
<S>It did not say when the charge would be taken .</S>
<S>" The addition of <ORGANIZATION>IVAC</ORGANIZATION> is expected to contribute to financial results in the full second quarter of 1997 , " the companies said .</S>
<S>The merger will add to both companies ' historical leadership in infusion therapy and technology-based drug delivery devices , they said .</S>
<S>In 1968 , <ORGANIZATION>IVAC</ORGANIZATION> introduced the world's first infusion therapy monitoring device .</S>
<S>A year later <ORGANIZATION>IVAC</ORGANIZATION> improved its system with the addition of an IV pump that regulated the flow of liquids through positive pressure .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>IMED</ORGANIZATION> introduced the world's first volumetric infusion pump in 1974 .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>IMED</ORGANIZATION> had profits of $ 1.7 million , or 6 cents per fully diluted common share , on $ 53.9 million in revenues in the first half of 1996 .</S>
<S>Excluding the effect of a one-time restructuring charge of $ 17.4 million , <ORGANIZATION>IVAC</ORGANIZATION> had net income of $ 4.2 million on net sales of $ 112.8 million for the 1996 first half .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Advanced Medical</ORGANIZATION> reported profits of $ 8.4 million on sales of $ 29.2 million in the quarter ended June 30 .</S>
<S><PERSON>William J. Mercer</PERSON> , <ORGANIZATION>IVAC</ORGANIZATION> president and chief executive officer , will become the president and CEO of <ORGANIZATION>Advanced Medical</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>He led the transition of <ORGANIZATION>IVAC</ORGANIZATION> to a privately held company and was previously senior vice president at <ORGANIZATION>Mallinckrodt Group Inc</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Joseph Kuhn</PERSON> , <ORGANIZATION>Advanced Medical</ORGANIZATION> and <ORGANIZATION>IMED</ORGANIZATION> president , will become the new company's executive vice president and chief financial officer .</S>
<S>The deal is expected to close by the first quarter of 1997 , subject to regulatory approval .</S>
<S>It has already been approved by both companies ' boards .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S><LOCATION>ST HELENS</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>England</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>St Helens</ORGANIZATION> completed their first league and Challenge Cup double in 30 years on Monday when they thrashed <ORGANIZATION>Warrington</ORGANIZATION> 66-14 to clinch the inaugural Super League title .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>St Helens</ORGANIZATION> secured the two points they needed in the last game of the season at <LOCATION>Knowsley Road</LOCATION> to win their first championship since 1975 and their first double since 1966 .</S>
<S>In rain-soaked conditions , centre <PERSON>Alan Hunte</PERSON> grabbed a hat-trick of tries , while <PERSON>Tommy Martyn</PERSON> , <PERSON>Anthony Sullivan</PERSON> and <PERSON>Paul Newlove</PERSON> each scored two .</S>
<S>Captain and goalkicker <PERSON>Bobbie Goulding</PERSON> scored 18 points .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>St Helens</ORGANIZATION>'s triumph marked the end of <ORGANIZATION>Wigan</ORGANIZATION>'s seven-year reign as British champions .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>St Helens</ORGANIZATION> needed to win on Monday to take the title -- a defeat or draw would have allowed <ORGANIZATION>Wigan</ORGANIZATION> their eighth consecutive championship .</S>
<S>They were also the toast of <ORGANIZATION>London Broncos</ORGANIZATION> , who managed to scrape into the top four ahead of <ORGANIZATION>Warrington</ORGANIZATION> and qualify for the end-of-season play-offs .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Bradford</ORGANIZATION> finished third .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>St Helens</ORGANIZATION> have now set their sights on taking the treble by winning the end-of-season premiership which begins with next Sunday's semifinal against <ORGANIZATION>London</ORGANIZATION> .</S>

<S>RALLYING - <PERSON>MAKINEN</PERSON> STEPS UP TITLE BID WITH LAKES WIN .</S>
<S><LOCATION>JYVASKYLA</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Finland</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S><PERSON>Tommi Makinen</PERSON> took a significant step towards becoming world rally champion with a brilliant victory in the 1000 Lakes Rally on Monday .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Mitsubishi</ORGANIZATION> driver <PERSON>Makinen</PERSON> stopped experienced fellow Finn <PERSON>Juha Kankkunen</PERSON> in his tracks on the final day of the 1,452-km rally , doubling his lead on the first two decisive stages .</S>
<S>" This was the most difficult win - three days at 125 percent effort , " said <PERSON>Makinen</PERSON> , whose success completed his 1,000 Lakes hat-trick .</S>
<S><PERSON>Kankkunen</PERSON> was runner-up in his <ORGANIZATION>Toyota</ORGANIZATION> as <LOCATION>Finland</LOCATION>'s <PERSON>Jarmo Kytolehto</PERSON> produced a remarkable drive to finish third in his <ORGANIZATION>Ford</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>Swede <PERSON>Kenneth Eriksson</PERSON> kept <ORGANIZATION>Subaru</ORGANIZATION> in the hunt for the manufacturers ' title with fifth place in spite of a gearbox problem that nearly forced him off the road close to the end of the event .</S>
<S><PERSON>Maakinen</PERSON>'s and <ORGANIZATION>Mitsubishi</ORGANIZATION>'s positions were strengthened by the late retirement of <LOCATION>Spain</LOCATION>'s <PERSON>Carlos Sainz</PERSON> when his <ORGANIZATION>Ford</ORGANIZATION> gearbox failed .</S>
<S><PERSON>Makinen</PERSON> , with 95 points , now leads his nearest championship rival , <PERSON>Sainz</PERSON> , by 32 points .</S>

<S>The only goal of the match also brought some relief for under-fire <ORGANIZATION>Leeds</ORGANIZATION> manager <PERSON>Howard Wilkinson</PERSON> following the team's poor start to the season .</S>

<S>CRICKET - <LOCATION>PAKISTAN</LOCATION>'s <PERSON>WASIM AKRAM</PERSON> JOINS 300 CLUB .</S>
<S><LOCATION>LONDON</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S><PERSON>Wasim Akram</PERSON>'s three-wicket haul</S>
<S>for <LOCATION>Pakistan</LOCATION> in <LOCATION>England</LOCATION>'s second innings at <LOCATION>The Oval</LOCATION> on Monday</S>
<S>gave him his 300th test match wicket .</S>
<S><PERSON>Wasim</PERSON> becomes the 11th player to join the 300-club of</S>
<S>bowlers and the second Pakistani , after <PERSON>Imran Khan</PERSON> , to achieve</S>
<S>the feat .</S>
<S>Other cricketers who have taken over 300 Test wickets :</S>
<S><PERSON>Kapil Dev</PERSON> ( <LOCATION>India</LOCATION> ) 434 wickets , 131 Tests</S>
<S><PERSON>Richard Hadlee</PERSON> ( <LOCATION>New Zealand</LOCATION> ) 431 , 86</S>
<S><PERSON>Ian Botham</PERSON> ( <LOCATION>England</LOCATION> ) 383 , 102</S>
<S><PERSON>Malcolm Marshall</PERSON> ( <LOCATION>West Indies</LOCATION> ) 376 , 81</S>
<S><PERSON>Imran Khan</PERSON> ( <LOCATION>Pakistan</LOCATION> ) 362 , 88</S>
<S><PERSON>Dennis Lillee</PERSON> ( <LOCATION>Australia</LOCATION> ) 355 , 70</S>
<S><PERSON>Bob Willis</PERSON> ( <LOCATION>England</LOCATION> ) 325 , 90</S>
<S><PERSON>Lance Gibbs</PERSON> ( <LOCATION>West Indies</LOCATION> ) 309 , 79</S>
<S><PERSON>Fred Trueman</PERSON> ( <LOCATION>England</LOCATION> ) 307 , 67</S>

<DOCUMENT>
<S>SOCCER - <LOCATION>SEYCHELLES</LOCATION> FAIL IN BID FOR HISTORIC VICTORY .</S>
<S><PERSON>Mark Gleeson</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>JOHANNESBURG</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S>The tiny islands of the <LOCATION>Seychelles</LOCATION> failed to make soccer history at the weekend when they bowed out of the preliminary rounds of the African Nations Cup .</S>
<S>Trailing fellow <LOCATION>Indian Ocean</LOCATION> islanders <LOCATION>Mauritius</LOCATION> 1-0 from the first leg , they were held to a 1-1 draw at home on Saturday despite playing against 10 men for most of the match .</S>
<S>The 2-1 aggregate took <LOCATION>Mauritius</LOCATION> into the group phase of the qualifiers for the 1998 finals , and kept up the <LOCATION>Seychelles</LOCATION> ' record of never having won an official match in their 10 years of <ORGANIZATION>FIFA</ORGANIZATION> membership .</S>
<S>The <LOCATION>Seychelles</LOCATION> must have thought they were on course for a historic breakthrough when Mauritian midfielder <PERSON>Andre Caboche</PERSON> was sent off for a crude tackle in the 19th minute .</S>
<S>But the visitors responded to the setback immediately -- veteran striker <PERSON>Ashley Mocude</PERSON> scoring a minute later to give them a two-goal aggregate lead .</S>
<S>Although <PERSON>Danny Rose</PERSON>'s 50th-minute equaliser gave the Seychellois renewed hope they could not find the net again and were eliminated .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Mauritius</LOCATION> now play in group seven of the qualifiers against <LOCATION>Malawi</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Mozambique</LOCATION> and favourites <LOCATION>Zambia</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Namibia</LOCATION> , who drew 0-0 with <LOCATION>Botswana</LOCATION> in their first leg , won the second leg in <LOCATION>Windhoek</LOCATION> 6-0 to stretch their unbeaten run to eight matches and continue their remarkable progress on the African soccer stage .</S>
<S>They now play in group five with <LOCATION>Cameroon</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Gabon</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Kenya</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>German-based striker <PERSON>Bachirou Salou</PERSON> returned home to <LOCATION>Togo</LOCATION> to score the decisive only goal of their tie against <LOCATION>Congo</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Salou</PERSON> , who plays for <ORGANIZATION>MSV Duisburg</ORGANIZATION> in the Bundesliga , scored in the 53rd minute of Sunday's match in <LOCATION>Lome</LOCATION> for a 1-0 aggregate win which takes his side into group six , where they will meet <LOCATION>Liberia</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Tanzania</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Zaire</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Ethiopia</LOCATION> needed a penalty shoot-out in <LOCATION>Addis Ababa</LOCATION> to overcome <LOCATION>Uganda</LOCATION> after a 2-2 aggregate scoreline .</S>
<S>Both legs ended 1-1 before <LOCATION>Ethiopia</LOCATION> won the spot kick decider 4-2 .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Uganda</LOCATION>'s elimination follows their humiliating 5-1 aggregate defeat by <LOCATION>Angola</LOCATION> in June's World Cup qualifying preliminaries .</S>
<S>The other preliminary round second leg match , between <LOCATION>Mauritania</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Benin</LOCATION> in <LOCATION>Nouakchott</LOCATION> , was postponed until Friday .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Benin</LOCATION> won the first leg 4-1 .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S>SWIMMING - <PERSON>POPOV</PERSON> IN `SERIOUS CONDITION ' AFTER STABBING .</S>
<S><LOCATION>MOSCOW</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S>Russian double Olympic swimming champion <PERSON>Alexander Popov</PERSON> was in a serious condition on Monday after being stabbed on a <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> street .</S>
<S>A doctor said it was too early to say whether <PERSON>Popov</PERSON> , the only man to retain the Olympic 50 and 100 metres freestyle titles , would return to top-level sport .</S>
<S>" His condition is serious , " said <PERSON>Rimma Maslova</PERSON> , deputy chief doctor of <LOCATION>Hospital No 31</LOCATION> in the Russian capital . "</S>
<S>But he is conscious and is talking and smiling . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Maslova</PERSON> told <ORGANIZATION>Reuters</ORGANIZATION> she was not an expert in sports medicine , but said it was too early to judge <PERSON>Popov</PERSON>'s chances of returning to competitive swimming .</S>
<S><PERSON>Popov</PERSON> , who won gold in the 50 and 100 metres freestyle at the recent Atlanta Olympics , was stabbed in the abdomen late on Saturday after an argument with a group of roadside watermelon sellers in south-west <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Maslova</PERSON> said the wound had affected a lung and a kidney .</S>
<S>Doctors operated on <PERSON>Popov</PERSON> , 24 , for three hours .</S>
<S><PERSON>Popov</PERSON> told <ORGANIZATION>NTV</ORGANIZATION> television on Sunday he was in no danger and promised he would be back in the pool shortly . "</S>
<S>There's no need to worry .</S>
<S>We're going to be walking soon -- and swimming , " he insisted cheerfully from his bed in the intensive care unit .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Interfax</ORGANIZATION> news agency said police had detained one of the attackers .</S>
<S>It said the row started when <PERSON>Popov</PERSON> and a group of his friends were returning from a party .</S>
<S><PERSON>Vitaly Smirnov</PERSON> , president of the Russian National Olympic Committee , said President <PERSON>Boris Yeltsin</PERSON> had given the swimmer <LOCATION>Russia</LOCATION>'s top award for his Olympic performance . "</S>
<S>I am not a doctor but I think he is doing all right , " said <PERSON>Smirnov</PERSON> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Smirnov</PERSON> said the Olympic Committee might ask the government to take measures to protect the country's best athletes , some of whom have already chosen to live abroad for fear of a surge in crime in post-Soviet <LOCATION>Russia</LOCATION> .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S>SOCCER - PLAYERS LEAVE MATCH EARLY TO CATCH PLANE .</S>
<S><PERSON>Brian Homewood</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>RIO DE JANEIRO</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S>Two key players left a Brazilian championship match early on Sunday because they had to catch a plane to <LOCATION>Russia</LOCATION> to play with the national team .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Sao Paulo</ORGANIZATION> midfielder <PERSON>Andre</PERSON> and <ORGANIZATION>Santos</ORGANIZATION> defender <PERSON>Narciso</PERSON> were both substituted during their teams ' game , taken to <LOCATION>Sao Paulo</LOCATION> airport and flown to <LOCATION>Rio de Janeiro</LOCATION> in a private jet chartered by the Brazilian Football Confederation ( CBF ) .</S>
<S>At <LOCATION>Rio</LOCATION> , they joined up with the national team squad for the journey to <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> , where <LOCATION>Brazil</LOCATION> will face <LOCATION>Russia</LOCATION> in a friendly international on Wednesday .</S>
<S>The problem arose because the <ORGANIZATION>Sao Paulo-Santos</ORGANIZATION> clash was selected as the day's televised live match , forcing it to be put back three hours from the usual kickoff time .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Santos</ORGANIZATION> suffered more from their loss as <PERSON>Narciso</PERSON>'s replacement <PERSON>Jean</PERSON> gave away a penalty from which <ORGANIZATION>Sao Paulo</ORGANIZATION> scored the decisive goal in a 2-1 win .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Sao Paulo</ORGANIZATION> lead the first stage of the championship on goal difference from surprise package <ORGANIZATION>Juventude</ORGANIZATION> , who beat <ORGANIZATION>Internacional</ORGANIZATION> 2-1 .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Corinthians</ORGANIZATION> , who played in a tournament in <LOCATION>Spain</LOCATION> last week , also faced a plane marathon as they attempted to keep up with a hectic fixture list .</S>
<S>They were due to leave <LOCATION>Spain</LOCATION> Monday night , arrive in <LOCATION>Sao Paulo</LOCATION> on Tuesday morning , catch another plane to the southern city of <LOCATION>Curitiba</LOCATION> one hour later and then play away to <ORGANIZATION>Atletico Paranaense</ORGANIZATION> in the Brazilian championship the same evening .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Botafogo</ORGANIZATION> striker <PERSON>Tulio</PERSON> , who was overlooked by <PERSON>Zagalo</PERSON> for the tour which also features a game away to the <LOCATION>Netherlands</LOCATION> on Sunday , scored his third goal in three games as the defending champions beat <ORGANIZATION>Bahia</ORGANIZATION> 2-1 away .</S>
<S><PERSON>Tulio</PERSON> , who has been top-scorer in the competition for the last two seasons , has been struggling against injury for most of this year .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>SOCCER - ARGENTINE CHAMPIONSHIP RESULTS .</S>
<S><LOCATION>BUENOS AIRES</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S>Results of matches on the</S>

<DOCUMENT>
<S>TENNIS - QUENCH YOUR THIRST - IF YOU CAN AFFORD IT AT U.S. OPEN .</S>
<S><PERSON>Bill Berkrot</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>NEW YORK</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S>A message on television monitors all around the <LOCATION>National Tennis Centre</LOCATION> reads : " Due to hot weather please seek shade and drink plenty of fluids " -- sound advice until you check out the price of fluids .</S>
<S>Perhaps the advisory was cut off before concluding : " ...and bring plenty of money . "</S>
<S>A small bottle of a garishly-coloured sports drink at the sun-drenched U.S. Open is going for $ 3.75 , while a litre of basic , life-sustaining water will set you back $ 4.00 -- for water ?</S>
<S>" At the Olympics water was only a dollar , and that was the Olympics , " said one incredulous fan , noting that the Atlanta Games had been notorious for price gouging .</S>
<S>U.S. Open officials managed to insult most of the male tennis players last week with their controversial handling of the seeding and draw .</S>
<S>When the tournament began on Monday it was the fans ' turn to be offended .</S>
<S>" That baked lasagna better be good for $ 8.50 , " said New Yorker <PERSON>Rebecca Weinstein</PERSON> , a U.S. Open regular who was eating a sandwich she had brought from home .</S>
<S>A trio of hungry fans at the food court who had already forked over the lasagna money pronounced it good , but <PERSON>Carol Perry</PERSON> chimed in , " The water is ridiculous , they want four dollars for the water , you might as well get a glass of wine . "</S>
<S>Indeed , a nice glass of chardonnay or white zinfandel was going for $ 4.75 , while an imported beer was just a bit more than the water at $ 4.50 .</S>
<S>What's the message here ? "</S>
<S>Maybe they want us to be alcoholics , " <PERSON>Perry</PERSON> joked before lifting her glass of wine .</S>
<S>Fans will be shelling out $ 12.50 for a hamburger and a large french fries .</S>
<S>And that little snack is guaranteed to make you thirsty .</S>
<S>Make that $ 16.50 .</S>
<S>Even a sandwich as pedestrian as a ham and swiss cheese is going for a whopping $ 8.00 .</S>
<S>Of course , it is served on a tuscan roll .</S>
<S>It must be the cost of flying those rolls over from <LOCATION>Tuscany</LOCATION> every day that drives up the price of the sandwich .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>TENNIS - <PERSON>HUBER</PERSON> AND <PERSON>MALEEVA</PERSON> FALL , UP-AND-COMERS ADVANCE AT OPEN .</S>
<S><PERSON>Larry Fine</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>NEW YORK</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S><PERSON>Martina Hingis</PERSON> led a youthful charge and Australian Open finalist <PERSON>Anke Huber</PERSON> and <PERSON>Magdalena Maleeva</PERSON> were fallen seeds on Monday in a hot , sunny opening to the U.S. Open tennis championships .</S>
<S>The 15-year-old <PERSON>Hingis</PERSON> , seeded 16th , was honoured to play the first match of the season's last Grand Slam on <LOCATION>Stadium Court</LOCATION> but happy to hurry off with a straight-sets victory over the 112th-ranked <PERSON>Angeles Montolio</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Spain</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" It was very hot and I didn't want to stay long on the court , " said a cheery <PERSON>Hingis</PERSON> , who had no worries in racing to a 6-1 6-0 victory against the overmatched Spaniard .</S>
<S>Hoping for a longer engagement on the cement at <LOCATION>Flushing Meadows</LOCATION> were the sixth-seeded <PERSON>Huber</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Germany</LOCATION> and 12th seed <PERSON>Maleeva</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Bulgaria</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Huber</PERSON> , who lost to <PERSON>Monica Seles</PERSON> in the Australian Open final , fell victim to an unfortunate draw in bowing to dangerous floater <PERSON>Amanda Coetzer</PERSON> of <LOCATION>South Africa</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Coetzer</PERSON> , ranked 17th , avenged her defeat to <PERSON>Huber</PERSON> in the Australian Open semifinals by winning 6-1 2-6 6-2 .</S>
<S>" I looked at it as not a first round match , just a great challenge for me , " said <PERSON>Coetzer</PERSON> , 24 . "</S>
<S>I was really concentrating on keeping my own momentum and my own rhythm .</S>
<S>" She is tough to play in that way because she plays very up and down .</S>
<S>She played one great game and than a few errors .</S>
<S>The challenge was just for me to keep playing my own game . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Huber</PERSON> , who reached the final a week ago at <LOCATION>Manhattan Beach</LOCATION> , could only mourn her luck of the draw .</S>
<S>" I wasn't happy when I saw the draw .</S>
<S>She was the first non- seeded player , " said the 21-year-old German . "</S>
<S>It's always tough to play somebody like that in the first round in a Grand Slam .</S>
<S>" I think I didn't play that bad today .</S>
<S>It was maybe my best first round match in a Grand Slam I ever played . "</S>
<S>Monday brought the best out in U.S. Open rookie <PERSON>Aleksandra Olsza</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Poland</LOCATION> , ranked 110th .</S>
<S>The 18-year-old <PERSON>Olsza</PERSON> , last year's Wimbledon junior champion , celebrated her debut in the main draw of the Open by removing <PERSON>Maleeva</PERSON> 6-4 6-2 .</S>
<S>The curtain-raising victories by <PERSON>Hingis</PERSON> and <PERSON>Olsza</PERSON> provided a ringing endorsement for the newest wave of women's players coming up from the junior ranks .</S>
<S>The Swiss teenager , a twice French Open junior champion and a Wimbledon juniors winner , had already proven her main stage mettle by reaching the quarters at this year's Australian Open .</S>
<S>" I hope I can get into the last 16 , " said <PERSON>Hingis</PERSON> , seeded to face third seed <PERSON>Arantxa Sanchez Vicario</PERSON> in the fourth round .</S>
<S><PERSON>Hingis</PERSON> has been working hard on conditioning and has lost eight pounds ( 3.5 kilos ) in advance of the championships .</S>
<S>" There will be tough matches but I hope I can get there , " she said . "</S>
<S>Then we'll see if <PERSON>Arantxa</PERSON> will be there , too . "</S>
<S>The fast-moving <PERSON>Olsza</PERSON> , 18 , was cool in her opening match .</S>
<S>" I wasn't scared when I heard that I was playing <PERSON>Maleeva</PERSON> , " said <PERSON>Olsza</PERSON> . "</S>
<S>I know that if I want to play professional tennis I have to do my best to try to beat her and I can't be scared . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Olsza</PERSON> is undaunted by the level of competition in the pros .</S>
<S>" In terms of tennis , I think the junior players are really good now .</S>
<S>In a few years , it could change a lot among the top players . "</S>
<S>Two big-serving women's players made quick work of Japanese opponents .</S>
<S><PERSON>Brenda Schultz-McCarthy</PERSON> of the <LOCATION>Netherlands</LOCATION> , the 13th seed , was a 6-1 6-4 winner over <LOCATION>Japan</LOCATION>'s <PERSON>Nana Miyaga</PERSON> , while Czech veteran <PERSON>Helena Sukova</PERSON> prevailed over <PERSON>Yone Kamio</PERSON> 6-2 6-3 .</S>
<S>Austrian <PERSON>Barbara Paulus</PERSON> , seeded 14th , also reached the second round with a 6-2 6-1 victory over <PERSON>Yi Jing-Qian</PERSON> of <LOCATION>China</LOCATION> .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>TENNIS - <PERSON>STICH</PERSON> GLAD HE STAYED AFTER OPEN VICTORY .</S>
<S><PERSON>Richard Finn</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>NEW YORK</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S><PERSON>Michael Stich</PERSON> nearly pulled out of the U.S. Open in protest over the men's seeding fiasco but the former Wimbledon champion was glad he stayed after sweating out a four-set win on Monday over qualifier <PERSON>Tommy Haas</PERSON> .</S>
<S>" I still feel it's embarrassing what happened and I was about to pull out yesterday and say , ' That's it , ' " said <PERSON>Stich</PERSON> , one of a host of men who cried foul over seeding procedures that forced an unprecedented remaking of the men's draw last week .</S>
<S>" But there are so many reasons to play , especially spectators and the kids who come out here and want to enjoy watching tennis , that I decided to stay . "</S>
<S>In a break from tradition , the Open did not seed in strict accordance with <ORGANIZATION>ATP</ORGANIZATION> rankings , instead taking into account other factors that raised objections of favourtism toward <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> players .</S>
<S>One prominent player that did not stay for the Open was French Open champion <PERSON>Yvegeny Kafelnikov</PERSON> , who after being dropped three spots from his <ORGANIZATION>ATP</ORGANIZATION> ranking to a seventh seeding , withdrew and returned home to <LOCATION>Russia</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Kafelnikov</PERSON> had pulled out of last week's tournament with a rib injury .</S>
<S>At a news conference attended by approximately 50 players on Sunday , <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> Davis Cup player <PERSON>Todd Martin</PERSON> expressed the players ' outrage at the seedings .</S>
<S>" The way the U.S. Open has seeded here , tampering with the ranking system , has tarnished the image and reputation of this U.S. Open in the players ' mind , and we think that is damaging to our sport , " <PERSON>Martin</PERSON> said .</S>
<S><PERSON>Stich</PERSON> said he felt the players ought to have organised an active protest .</S>
<S>" I feel that we made it a little easy for the <ORGANIZATION>USTA</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>They didn't really get hurt as much as I think they should have , " said <PERSON>Stich</PERSON> . "</S>
<S>I feel that we should have maybe just cancelled out the Monday , not show up today and start the tournament tomorrow . "</S>
<S>But once the 27-year-old <PERSON>Stich</PERSON> got on the court , he focused his energies on trying to win the year's last Grand Slam .</S>
<S>He took a positive first step with his 6-3 1-6 6-1 7-5 win over compatriot <PERSON>Haas</PERSON> on a sun-baked Grandstand court .</S>
<S>Others advancing early on Monday included 11th-seeded American <PERSON>Malivai Washington</PERSON> , the Wimbledon runner-up , <LOCATION>Sweden</LOCATION>'s <PERSON>Magnus Gustafsson</PERSON> , and two-time former French Open champion <PERSON>Sergi Bruguera</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Spain</LOCATION> , who will be <PERSON>Stich</PERSON>'s next opponent .</S>
<S>The suspicion , however , lingers in <PERSON>Stich</PERSON>'s mind that U.S. Open officials did tamper with the seeding process in order to benefit homegrown players .</S>
<S>" I get the feeling that everything is done here for the American players and they forget about all the other players , " said <PERSON>Stich</PERSON> , who lost the 1994 Open final to <PERSON>Andre Agassi</PERSON> .</S>
<S>It was <PERSON>Agassi</PERSON> who was at the centre of the controversy that engulfed the tournament since the original draw was completed on Wednesday .</S>
<S>The flamboyant American star was bumped up two spots from his <ORGANIZATION>ATP</ORGANIZATION> ranking of eight to a seeding of six .</S>
<S>" He ( <PERSON>Agassi</PERSON> ) should be seeded the way he is playing tennis right now , " said <PERSON>Stich</PERSON> about the unfairness of moving up <PERSON>Agassi</PERSON> , who made early exits from the French Open and Wimbledon .</S>
<S><PERSON>Stich</PERSON> , not seeded here for the first time since 1990 , might have benefitted from some fiddling with the seedings himself after <PERSON>Kafelnikov</PERSON> withdrew .</S>
<S>Ranked 18th in the world , <PERSON>Stich</PERSON> might have been slipped into that spot ahead of <LOCATION>Spain</LOCATION>'s <PERSON>Felix Mantilla</PERSON> , who is 16th but had never been played in the Open and had been left out of the seedings originally .</S>
<S>But <PERSON>Stich</PERSON> didn't want to play that game .</S>
<S>" I think he deserves to be seeded as everybody else who is in the top 16 deserves to be seeded , " <PERSON>Stich</PERSON> said .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>

<S><PERSON>Frederic Vitoux</PERSON> ( <LOCATION>France</LOCATION> ) beat <PERSON>Ramon Delgado</PERSON> ( <LOCATION>Paraguay</LOCATION> ) 6-4 6-4 7-6 ( 7-3 )</S>

<S>BASEBALL - <ORGANIZATION>CUBS</ORGANIZATION> EDGE <ORGANIZATION>BRAVES</ORGANIZATION> WITH RUN IN TOP OF NINTH .</S>
<S><LOCATION>ATLANTA</LOCATION> 1996-08-25</S>
<S><PERSON>Brian McRae</PERSON> singled in <PERSON>Tyler Houston</PERSON> in the top of the ninth inning to snap a tie as the <ORGANIZATION>Chicago Cubs</ORGANIZATION> avoided a three-game sweep with 3-2 victory over the <ORGANIZATION>Atlanta Braves</ORGANIZATION> on Sunday .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Braves</ORGANIZATION> scored four runs in the ninth for a 6-5 victory on Saturday .</S>
<S><PERSON>Kevin Foster</PERSON> ( 5-2 ) won his second straight start , allowing two runs and six hits with two walks and three strikeouts over eight innings .</S>
<S>" The biggest thing was my fastball , I was able to rotate it pretty good , " <PERSON>Foster</PERSON> said . "</S>
<S>Also , I was able to keep my changeup down . "</S>
<S>At <LOCATION>Colorado</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Vinny Castilla</PERSON> homered twice and drove in four runs and <PERSON>Larry Walker</PERSON> went 3-for-4 with a homer and three RBI as the <ORGANIZATION>Colorado Rockies</ORGANIZATION> outslugged the <ORGANIZATION>Pittsburgh Pirates</ORGANIZATION> 13-9 in the rubber game of a three-game series .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Castilla</ORGANIZATION>'s first homer of the game , a solo shot in the seventh off reliever <PERSON>Marc Wilkins</PERSON> ( 3-1 ) extended <ORGANIZATION>Colorado</ORGANIZATION>'s lead to 9-7 .</S>
<S>He added a three-run homer in the eighth off <PERSON>John Ericks</PERSON> to make it 13-8 .</S>
<S>At <LOCATION>Florida</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Edgar Renteria</PERSON>'s two-out single in the bottom of the ninth inning scored <PERSON>Jesus Tavarez</PERSON> with the winning run as the <ORGANIZATION>Florida Marlins</ORGANIZATION> edged the <ORGANIZATION>Cincinnati Reds</ORGANIZATION> 6-5 .</S>
<S>" Right after <PERSON>Edgar</PERSON> made contact , I knew I had to score , " said <PERSON>Tavarez</PERSON> . "</S>
<S>I knew I would score even if he fielded it cleanly , he couldn't throw me out . "</S>
<S>" <PERSON>Edgar</PERSON> is a tremendous player right now , " said <ORGANIZATION>Florida</ORGANIZATION> manager <PERSON>John Boles</PERSON> . "</S>
<S>But I can't wait to see how good he'll be when he grows up . "</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>San Francisco</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Osvaldo Fenandez</PERSON> fired a seven-hitter and <PERSON>Trenidad Hubbard</PERSON> belted a two-run homer as the <ORGANIZATION>San Francisco Giants</ORGANIZATION> ended a three-game losing streak by defeating the <ORGANIZATION>Montreal Expos</ORGANIZATION> , 7-2 .</S>
<S><PERSON>Fernandez</PERSON> ( 6-13 ) allowed two runs , walked one and struck out eight for his second career complete game , both against <ORGANIZATION>Montreal</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Los Angeles</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Greg Gagne</PERSON> had a run-scoring single and <PERSON>Chad Curtis</PERSON> drew a bases-loaded walk in the bottom of the eighth inning as the <ORGANIZATION>Los Angeles Dodgers</ORGANIZATION> rallied for a 6-5 victory and a three-game sweep of the <ORGANIZATION>New York Mets</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>" It was one of these games where you get three straight pinch-hits and a walk of a pinch-hitter , that's how you win pennants , " <ORGANIZATION>Dodgers</ORGANIZATION> manager <PERSON>Bill Russell</PERSON> said . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Mike Piazza</PERSON></S>
<S>In <LOCATION>San Diego</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Steve Finley</PERSON> and <PERSON>Jody Reed</PERSON> drove in three runs apiece as the <ORGANIZATION>San Diego Padres</ORGANIZATION> built a six-run lead after three innings and cruised to an 11-2 victory over the <ORGANIZATION>Philadelphia Phillies</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Ken Caminiti</PERSON> added two RBI for the <ORGANIZATION>Padres</ORGANIZATION> , who have won six of their last seven games and remained one game ahead of the <ORGANIZATION>Los Angeles Dodgers</ORGANIZATION> in the National League West .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Houston</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Jeff Bagwell</PERSON> homered and <PERSON>Donne Wall</PERSON> allowed one run over seven innings as the <ORGANIZATION>Houston Astros</ORGANIZATION> defeated the <ORGANIZATION>St. Louis Cardinals</ORGANIZATION> 4-1 .</S>

<S>BASEBALL - <PERSON>BONDS</PERSON> ' CONSECUTIVE GAME STREAK ENDS .</S>
<S><LOCATION>SAN FRANCISCO</LOCATION> 1996-08-25</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>San Francisco Giants</ORGANIZATION> All-Star left fielder <PERSON>Barry Bonds</PERSON> did not appear in Sunday's 7-2 victory over the <ORGANIZATION>Montreal Expos</ORGANIZATION> , ending his consecutive games streak .</S>
<S>After appearing as a pinch-hitter in the previous two games , <PERSON>Bonds</PERSON> , who has been battling a hamstring injury , did not see any action today , ending his streak at 357 consecutive games .</S>
<S>It was the second-longest streak by an active player in the the majors behind <ORGANIZATION>Baltimore</ORGANIZATION>'s <PERSON>Cal Ripken</PERSON> , who appeared in his major-league record 2,282nd straight game today , a 13-0 loss to the <ORGANIZATION>California Angels</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Bonds</PERSON> has been limited to a pinch-hitting role since an MRI Friday showed a mild strain of his left hamstring .</S>
<S><PERSON>Bonds</PERSON> came out of Wednesday's game against <ORGANIZATION>New York</ORGANIZATION> in the ninth inning after suffering a mild hamstring strain .</S>
<S>He was back in the starting lineup Thursday night and went 1-for-2 before exiting in the third inning .</S>
<S>The 32-year-old <PERSON>Bonds</PERSON> is hitting .307 with 35 homers and 107 RBI and has been one of the few bright spots for the last-place <ORGANIZATION>Giants</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Chicago Cubs</ORGANIZATION> outfielder <PERSON>Sammy Sosa</PERSON> had the third-longest streak at 304 games , but that ended earlier this week when he suffered a broken bone in his right hand .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Atlanta Braves</ORGANIZATION> first baseman <PERSON>Fred McGriff</PERSON> owns the second-longest streak at 295 games .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S><LOCATION>ROTTERDAM</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S>Dutch coach <PERSON>Guus Hiddink</PERSON> on Monday recalled midfielder <PERSON>Wim Jonk</PERSON> after a 14-month absence for a friendly against World Cup holders <LOCATION>Brazil</LOCATION> in <LOCATION>Amsterdam</LOCATION> on Sunday .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Feyenoord</ORGANIZATION> midfielder <PERSON>Jean-Paul van Gastel</PERSON> was also named to make his debut in the 18-man squad .</S>
<S><PERSON>Hiddink</PERSON> did not name a replacement captain for <PERSON>Danny Blind</PERSON> , who announced his retirement from international soccer on Sunday .</S>
<S><PERSON>Ronald de Boer</PERSON> and <PERSON>Dennis Bergkamp</PERSON> are the likely contenders to lead the team .</S>
<S>The 35-year-old <PERSON>Blind</PERSON> , who won 42 caps for the <LOCATION>Netherlands</LOCATION> , said he wanted to concentrate on playing for his Dutch club <ORGANIZATION>Ajax Amsterdam</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>AC Milan</ORGANIZATION> midfielder <PERSON>Edgar Davids</PERSON> , who was sent home early from the European championship in <LOCATION>England</LOCATION> after a clash with the coach , was left out of the squad .</S>

<DOCUMENT>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Lamonts Apparel</ORGANIZATION> files reorganization plan .</S>
<S>[ CORRECTED 18:00 GMT ]</S>
<S><LOCATION>KIRKLAND</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Wash</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Lamonts Apparel Inc</ORGANIZATION> , an operator of 42 family apparel stores in six northwestern states , said it has filed a reorganization plan in bankruptcy court in <LOCATION>Seattle</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>( Corrects to make clear a reorganization plan has been filed ) .</S>
<S>The reorganization plan calls for all secured claims to be paid in full .</S>
<S>Unsecured claims , including those of company bondholders , will be satisfied by issuing new common stock and warrants .</S>
<S>Unsecured claims are estimated at about $ 90 million .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Lamonts</ORGANIZATION> said it plans to issue 9 million shares of new common stock .</S>
<S>Of that amount , 4.05 million and 5.67 million shares will be allocated to the company's trade creditors .</S>
<S>Between 4.75 and 3.13 million shares will be allocated to bondholders and other unsecured non-trade creditors and 200,000 will be allocated to existing shareholders in exchange for all existing stock of the company .</S>
<S>Bondholders and other unsecured non-trade creditors will receive warrants four about 2.2 million shares when the company's market capitalization reaches $ 20 million .</S>
<S>Bondholders , other unsecured non-trade creditors , and existing shareholders also will receive warrants entitling them to roughly 800,000 shares when the company's market capitalization reaches $ 25 million .</S>
<S>Management will receive options to purchase 10 percent of the company's outstanding common stock with protection against dilution at an option exercise price of $ 1 million .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S><LOCATION>LONDON</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S>More than 100 people were safely evacuated on Monday from a ferry that caught fire soon after leaving <LOCATION>Guernsey</LOCATION> in <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION>'s <LOCATION>Channel Islands</LOCATION> , police said .</S>
<S>Police said the 111 passengers and six crew on board the ferry Trident Seven , owned by <LOCATION>France</LOCATION>'s <ORGANIZATION>Emeraud</ORGANIZATION> line , were rescued by a variety of private and commercial boats after fire broke out in the engine room soon after it left port .</S>
<S>An 88-year-old woman was taken to hospital with leg injuries , according to a spokesman for <LOCATION>Guernsey</LOCATION> police .</S>
<S>The ferry , which was towed into port , had been bound for <LOCATION>Jersey</LOCATION> , another in a cluster of small British-ruled islands off north-west <LOCATION>France</LOCATION> .</S>
