<DOCUMENT>
<S><ORGANIZATION>OSCE</ORGANIZATION> delays decision on refugee voting .</S>
<S><PERSON>Kurt Schork</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>SARAJEVO</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S><LOCATION>Bosnia</LOCATION>'s election organisers will decide on Tuesday whether or not to postpone municipal elections scheduled as part of nationwide balloting , an <ORGANIZATION>OSCE</ORGANIZATION> spokeswoman said on Monday .</S>
<S>Officials from the <ORGANIZATION>Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>OSCE</ORGANIZATION> ) are considering the postponement following allegations of serious irregularities in the registration of Serb refugees .</S>
<S>International observers say the alleged irregularities could affect the outcome of voting for municipal assemblies .</S>
<S>" Tomorrow ...</S>
<S>the <ORGANIZATION>Provisional Election Commission</ORGANIZATION> will consider the possible postponement of municipal elections only ...</S>
<S>the other elections will be held on September 14 , " <ORGANIZATION>OSCE</ORGANIZATION> spokeswoman <PERSON>Agota Kuperman</PERSON> told reporters in <LOCATION>Sarajevo</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" I think that it would be very difficult to select which municipal elections would have to be cancelled .</S>
<S>I think probably if the decision ( to cancell ) were to be taken it would probably be all municipal elections ..</S>
<S><PERSON>Kuperman</PERSON> added that options other than postponement were also on the table , but she refused to specify what they were .</S>
<S>The <LOCATION>Dayton</LOCATION> peace agreement gave the <ORGANIZATION>OSCE</ORGANIZATION> a mandate to organise Bosnian elections .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Provisional Election Commission</ORGANIZATION> is <ORGANIZATION>OSCE</ORGANIZATION>'s top rule-making body for the poll .</S>
<S>More than 600,000 refugees have registered to vote in 55 countries around the world , representing about 20 per cent of <LOCATION>Bosnia</LOCATION>'s total electorate .</S>
<S>They are due to begin voting on Wednesday , August 28 , just one day after the <ORGANIZATION>PEC</ORGANIZATION> is supposed to make its decision .</S>
<S>Balloting inside <LOCATION>Bosnia</LOCATION> is scheduled for September 14 , when citizens are slated to elect municipal and cantonal assemblies , separate Moslem-Croat and Serb parliaments , a national <ORGANIZATION>House of Representatives</ORGANIZATION> and a three-man Presidency .</S>
<S>A <LOCATION>Sarajevo</LOCATION> daily newspaper , <ORGANIZATION>Dnevi Avaz</ORGANIZATION> , which is close to <LOCATION>Bosnia</LOCATION>'s Moslem nationalist <ORGANIZATION>SDA</ORGANIZATION> party , on Monday said the <ORGANIZATION>OSCE</ORGANIZATION> would postpone the municipal-level elections until the Spring of 1997 because of the refugee registration problems .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>SDA</ORGANIZATION> has a representative on the <ORGANIZATION>Provisional Election Commission</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>" I don't know what the source of the <ORGANIZATION>Dnevi Avaz</ORGANIZATION> report is , but it is consistent with what I have heard from western diplomats and from inside the <ORGANIZATION>OSCE</ORGANIZATION> , " said an <ORGANIZATION>OSCE</ORGANIZATION> staff member in <LOCATION>Sarajevo</LOCATION> who asked not to be named .</S>
<S>" The word is that <PERSON>Frowick</PERSON> has decided to postpone municipal elections but that he will wait for one more session of the <ORGANIZATION>PEC</ORGANIZATION> on Tuesday to take everyone's temperature on the issue . "</S>
<S>Ambassador <PERSON>Robert Frowick</PERSON> , an American , heads the <ORGANIZATION>OSCE</ORGANIZATION> mission in <LOCATION>Bosnia</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>OSCE</ORGANIZATION> and independent monitors allege that Serb authorities have systematically discouraged refugees from registering to cast a ballot in the places they lived before the war .</S>
<S>Instead , the refugees were said to have been directed by their authorities to vote from strategic towns which had Moslem majorities before the 43-month Bosnian war , but which are now underpopulated as a result of " ethnic cleansing " .</S>
<S>Diplomats explain the purpose of this electoral engineering is to secure Serb control over pivotal towns inside the 49 per cent of <LOCATION>Bosnia</LOCATION> known as the Serb republic , consolidating through the ballot box what was initially taken in war .</S>
<S>The top <ORGANIZATION>U.N.</ORGANIZATION> refugee official in the <LOCATION>Balkans</LOCATION> highlighted the voter registration problem on Monday .</S>
<S>" Results of the registration for September elections herald a dismal future for multi-ethnicity in <LOCATION>Bosia-Hercegovina</LOCATION> , " warned <PERSON>Soren Jessen-Petersen</PERSON> , Special Envoy for the <ORGANIZATION>U.N.</ORGANIZATION> High Commissioner for Refugees in <LOCATION>Former Yugoslavia</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" In the run-up to elections , nationalistic political leaders are playing the ethnic / sectarian card , drumming up support within their constituencies by playing on bitter memories or fear . "</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>After truce , <PERSON>Lebed</PERSON> faces tougher Chechen problem .</S>
<S><PERSON>Alastair Macdonald</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>MOSCOW</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S><PERSON>Alexander Lebed</PERSON> may finally get to discuss his Chechen peace proposals with <PERSON>Boris Yeltsin</PERSON> on Tuesday after a lost weekend in the region when he was forced to abandon plans to sign a new political treaty with the separatist rebels .</S>
<S>It could be a sobering experience for the <LOCATION>Kremlin</LOCATION> security chief who , just two months after being appointed by the president and two heady weeks after taking charge of the Chechen crisis , had promised to wrap up the 20-month war by the weekend .</S>
<S>Despite a mood of compromise in the region after some of the worst fighting of the war , <PERSON>Lebed</PERSON> may be just finding out that concluding a long-term settlement , somewhere between rebel demands for independence and <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION>'s insistence that <LOCATION>Chechnya</LOCATION> remain part of <LOCATION>Russia</LOCATION> , will be no easy matter .</S>
<S>A chain-smoking former paratroop general with a sharp line in deadpan putdowns and a soldier's knack for making life sound simple , <PERSON>Lebed</PERSON> managed to arrange an ambitious ceasefire in the region last week , days after the Russian army threatened to bomb its way back into the rebel-held Chechen capital <LOCATION>Grozny</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>He returned at the weekend , pledging to conclude a political settlement that would make this truce work where all others have failed .</S>
<S>But then he apparently thought better of it .</S>
<S>Saying he needed to tidy up legal loose ends on the deal -- and also cover his back against unnamed pro-war schemers in <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> -- he flew back to the capital empty-handed on Sunday .</S>
<S>He met Russian Prime Minister <PERSON>Viktor Chernomyrdin</PERSON> on Monday and , according to the press service of <PERSON>Lebed</PERSON>'s <ORGANIZATION>Security Council</ORGANIZATION> , could meet <PERSON>Yeltsin</PERSON> on Tuesday .</S>
<S>It was not clear if the start of <PERSON>Yeltsin</PERSON>'s holiday , announced later , would affect plans to talk .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION>'s as yet undisclosed proposals on <LOCATION>Chechnya</LOCATION>'s political future have , meanwhile , been sent back to do the rounds of various government departments .</S>
<S>It is not known what caused the delay in the peace plan .</S>
<S>Speculation mounted last week that <PERSON>Lebed</PERSON> was operating out on a limb in <LOCATION>Chechnya</LOCATION> as <PERSON>Yeltsin</PERSON> , hardly seen since his reelection last month , kept out of sight and then gave an interview criticising his envoy just as he clinched a truce .</S>
<S>But <PERSON>Chernomyrdin</PERSON> took pains at the weekend to insist <PERSON>Lebed</PERSON> was playing for a united team and that the proposals he took to rebel chief-of-staff <PERSON>Aslan Maskhadov</PERSON> had been agreed by <PERSON>Yeltsin</PERSON> .</S>
<S>If that were the case , it was unclear why <PERSON>Lebed</PERSON> suddenly found it necessary to have the deal verified in <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Lebed</PERSON> himself said he was concerned that powerful interests in <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> , who have profited from the war and want it to go on , would seize on any inadequacy in the deal to remove him .</S>
<S><PERSON>Maskhadov</PERSON> warned that <PERSON>Lebed</PERSON> risked the same fate as a former Russian army commander in the region who sought a compromise and was blown up last year by -- so the Chechens say -- Russian forces .</S>
<S><PERSON>Maskhadov</PERSON> may also have made new demands on <PERSON>Lebed</PERSON> , forcing him to check back with the <LOCATION>Kremlin</LOCATION> on what he could offer .</S>
<S>A rebel spokesman said the two military men had come close to agreement on a face-saving formula acceptable to both sides and involving a referendum on independence at some future date .</S>
<S><PERSON>Chernomyrdin</PERSON> said voters should decide <LOCATION>Chechnya</LOCATION>'s future but stressed there was no question of the government letting the region quit the <LOCATION>Russian Federation</LOCATION> -- something <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> fears could encourage separatist tendencies in other ethnic regions , particularly in the strategic <LOCATION>North Caucasus</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Lebed</PERSON> may be be finding that closing that political gap between the two sides is more difficult than just ending a war .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S>" The head of state's holiday has only just begun , " the agency quoted <PERSON>Sergei Yastrzhembsky</PERSON> as saying , adding that the president was currently in a <LOCATION>Kremlin</LOCATION> residence near <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Interfax</ORGANIZATION> said <PERSON>Yastrezhembsky</PERSON> did not exclude that <PERSON>Yeltsin</PERSON> could spend some time in other places .</S>
<S>He would continue working on various documents and might meet " one state offical or another " .</S>
<S>" One must give <PERSON>B. Yeltsin</PERSON> a chance to rest and recover his health after the elections , " <ORGANIZATION>Interfax</ORGANIZATION> quoted <PERSON>Yastrezhembsky</PERSON> as saying .</S>
<S>" ( <PERSON>Yeltsin</PERSON> ) controls internal and international policies , daily receives a big packet of documents from <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> , which demand his intervention ...</S>
<S>Many of those documents return to the president's administration the same day , " he said .</S>

<S><ORGANIZATION>Yugo Zastava</ORGANIZATION> workers ' protest enters 2nd week .</S>
<S><LOCATION>BELGRADE</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S>Thousands of workers of <LOCATION>Serbia</LOCATION>'s <ORGANIZATION>Zastava</ORGANIZATION> arms factory entered the second week of protests on Monday over unpaid wages and the lack of a programme to revive the plant's production .</S>
<S>" We are stubborn , have strength and time to persist until our demands are met , " said the factory's trade union secretary <PERSON>Dragutin Stanojlovic</PERSON> .</S>
<S>" We are united and we are waiting for the government to decide what to do with us . "</S>
<S>Trade unions demanded payment of June and July wages and last year's holiday pay , and called on government to develop a revival programme for the plant .</S>
<S>The former Yugoslav national army consumed 90 percent of <ORGANIZATION>Zastava</ORGANIZATION>'s pre-war output , but like the rest of <LOCATION>Yugoslavia</LOCATION>'s economy , the new army of <LOCATION>Serbia</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Montenegro</LOCATION> is crippled by lack of funds .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Kragujevac</LOCATION> where the plant is based , 9,000 to 10,000 people gathered in the central square to express their bitterness at what <PERSON>Stanojlovic</PERSON> called government indifference .</S>
<S>The ruling <ORGANIZATION>Socialist Party</ORGANIZATION> last week accused <LOCATION>Serbia</LOCATION>'s opposition of stirring up social unrest and using workers ' already difficult social position for their own interests .</S>
<S>" Late wages , no work and ( the lack of a ) production programme are the main reasons for their protests , " a senior member of the local <ORGANIZATION>Socialist Party</ORGANIZATION> branch told <ORGANIZATION>Reuters</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>" But there is a significant influence of opposition parties that are collecting points ahead of coming elections . "</S>
<S>Federal Yugoslav elections are due on November 3 .</S>
<S>The party official said the union's figure on the number of protesters was exaggerated . "</S>
<S>There were about 1,400 to 1,600 people at the protest today -- much less then last week .</S>
<S>" But there were more observers and passers by , " he said .</S>
<S>-- <PERSON>Gordana Kukic</PERSON> , <ORGANIZATION>Belgrade Newsroom</ORGANIZATION> +381 11 222 4254</S>

<S>Croatian lending rate falls to 8.0 vs 9.1 pct .</S>
<S><LOCATION>ZAGREB</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S>The Croatian lending rate fell to 8.0 percent on Monday from last Friday's 9.1 percent after thin demand for kuna forced bank lenders to trim their rates further .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Interbank</ORGANIZATION> call money was down to 8.0 from 10.0 percent .</S>
<S>Insurers ' five-10 and 10-15 day loans were made at a steady 8.0 percent after last week's drop from an earlier 15 percent .</S>
<S>Total <ORGANIZATION>Zagreb Money Market</ORGANIZATION> settlements shrank to 17.4 million kuna , of which dealers put new borrowing at a meagre 5.5 million .</S>
<S>Supply stood at a high 180 million kuna .</S>
<S>Overnight trade at the weekend left a surplus of 1.2 billion kuna on the supply side after 40 million were settled .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Croatia</LOCATION>'s central bank again stayed out of the foreign exchange market .</S>
<S>It calculated the kuna midrates for Tuesday's trade stronger at 5.2420 against the dollar and slightly weaker at 3.5486 against the German mark .</S>
<S>-- <PERSON>Kolumbina Bencevic</PERSON> , <ORGANIZATION>Zagreb Newsroom</ORGANIZATION> , 385-1-4557075</S>

<S><ORGANIZATION>SVCD Bulgaria</ORGANIZATION> air traffic controllers to strike September 3 .</S>
<S><LOCATION>SOFIA</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S>Bulgarian air traffic controllers will go on strike on September 3 demanding higher pay , the chief of the Bulgarian association of air traffic controllers ( <ORGANIZATION>Bulatka</ORGANIZATION> ) said on Monday .</S>
<S><PERSON>Stefan Raichev</PERSON> told a news conference the strike by more than half of the 1,380 traffic controllers and technicians would paralyse traffic which has increased by 10 percent since last year .</S>
<S>More than 1,500 planes per day fly over <LOCATION>Bulgaria</LOCATION> , in a strategic location between <LOCATION>Europe</LOCATION> and the <LOCATION>Middle</LOCATION> and the <LOCATION>Far East</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Raichev</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>The director general of the air traffic service <PERSON>Valentin Valkov</PERSON> said last Friday that a controllers ' strike would be illegal .</S>
<S><PERSON>Valkov</PERSON> said he could not curb the summer charter flights of national carrier <ORGANIZATION>Balkan Airlines</ORGANIZATION> , which carries thousands of foreign tourists to the Bulgarian <LOCATION>Black Sea</LOCATION> resorts .</S>
<S>But <PERSON>Raichev</PERSON> said it would be " discrimination " against the other airlines if only <LOCATION>Balkan</LOCATION> planes were guided in .</S>
<S>" Under the law before launching the strike we have to sign an agreement with our employer for a minimal transport servicing of emergency flights , " <PERSON>Raichev</PERSON> said .</S>
<S><PERSON>Raichev</PERSON> said a lock-out with military air controllers was impossible as they did not speak English .</S>
<S>The controllers are demanding the monthly wage be increased to $ 1,000 per month from the current $ 230 , as well as the resignation of the air traffic service's management .</S>
<S>They also demand the financial separation of the 350 air controllers from the technical staff .</S>
<S>-- <PERSON>Liliana Semerdjieva</PERSON> , <ORGANIZATION>Sofia Newsroom</ORGANIZATION> , 359-2-84561</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S>Shareholders of the Polish construction firm <ORGANIZATION>Mostostal Zabrze Holding SA</ORGANIZATION> approved a 25- million-zloty , five-year convertible issue with a par value of 100 zlotys each , the company's spokesman said on Monday .</S>
<S><PERSON>Piotr Grabowski</PERSON> told <ORGANIZATION>Reuters</ORGANIZATION> that a <ORGANIZATION>Mostostal</ORGANIZATION> extraordinary shareholders meeting on Saturday had decided that the price of the 250,000 bonds would be set as a 10-session average price of <ORGANIZATION>Mostostal</ORGANIZATION> shares plus a premium .</S>
<S>" The premium will be no lower than 15 percent and will be set by management before the issue ...</S>
<S>which we expect at the beginning of next year , " <PERSON>Grabowksi</PERSON> said .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Mostostal</ORGANIZATION> , based in southern <LOCATION>Poland</LOCATION> , wants to offer the bonds to large investors in a public offering , paying an annual coupon of no more than 80 percent of the yield of the benchmark 52-week T-bill .</S>
<S>The firm has signed an agreement with the <ORGANIZATION>Polish Development Bank</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>PBR</ORGANIZATION> ) to manage the issue and plans them to be listed on the <LOCATION>Warsaw</LOCATION> bourse's bond market .</S>
<S><PERSON>Grabowski</PERSON> also said shareholders approved the issue of 1.6 million shares for which the bonds could be exchanged , a ratio of 6.4 shares per bond .</S>
<S>He also said shareholders approved the issue of 2.6 million new shares , two million of which are earmarked for large investors and 600,000 for retail domestic investors .</S>
<S>The price will be determined through book-building .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Mostostal</ORGANIZATION> plans to use the proceeds from the issues to add companies to its holding and modernise its plant .</S>

<S><ORGANIZATION>Interacciones</ORGANIZATION> ups <LOCATION>Mexico</LOCATION> GDP forecast , lowers peso .</S>
<S><LOCATION>MEXICO CITY</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Interacciones</ORGANIZATION> brokerage on Monday raised its forecasts for 1996 gross domestic product growth to 4.3 percent from 3.8 percent , but it kept its 1997 projection unchanged at 4.5 percent , a statement said .</S>
<S>Economist <PERSON>Alonso Cervera</PERSON> said the revisions were chiefly fueled by stronger than expected growth of 7.2 percent in the second quarter and he forecast an annual GDP rise of 6.1 percent in the third quarter and 4.9 percent in Q4 .</S>
<S>The firm also revised down its year-end peso forecast to 7.85-8.15 per dollar from 8.20-8.50 .</S>
<S>It forecast an end 1997 peso in the range of 9.20-9.40 .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Interacciones</ORGANIZATION> kept its 1996 and 1997 inflation forecast unchanged at 26 percent and 20 percent , expecting the government's 1997 inflation target to be around 15 percent .</S>
<S>It bumped up its average interest rate projection in 1997 to 25.8 percent from 23 percent .</S>
<S>Fiscal policy was expected to be loosened a bit in the second half of this year , boosting growth without running into a deficit .</S>
<S>" Next year , the fiscal policy will have less margin of freedom because the government will have to face commitments that it has taken on under different support schemes for the banks , debtors and firms , " the brokerage said .</S>

<S>Colombian peso closes lower , importers buy dlrs .</S>
<S><LOCATION>BOGOTA</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S><LOCATION>Colombia</LOCATION>'s peso closed lower at 1,044 after coming under pressure from dollar-buying by importers seeking to meet their commitments abroad , interbank dealers said .</S>
<S>It was the second consecutive session that saw the peso , which ended at 1,041 Friday , close lower .</S>
<S>" The ( dollar's ) rise was due to demand from importers who have a lot of wire transfers accumulated , " one dealer said .</S>
<S>Contributing to the peso's weakness , another dealer said banks who might have sold greenbacks in Monday's trading appeared to shy away from the market .</S>
<S>This , according to the trader , was typical of month-end position-squaring -- and the fact that a stronger <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> currency helps limit some foreign exchange losses .</S>
<S>Dealers reported 355 trades for a total of $ 142 million and said the peso hit an intra-day high of 1,037 before heading lower into the close .</S>

<S><LOCATION>JAKARTA</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S>The Indonesian rupiah was stable against the dollar in quiet trading on Monday , dealers said .</S>
<S>They said volume was thin following a public holiday in <LOCATION>Hong Kong</LOCATION> and the <LOCATION>United Kingdom</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" We didn't see anything from <LOCATION>Singapore</LOCATION> operators either .</S>
<S>It's a pretty quiet day , " one foreign bank dealer said .</S>
<S>Spot rupiah was quoted at 2,342.0 / 42.5 at 0915 GMT , unchanged from the opening level .</S>
<S>It was softer in the morning due to relatively ample rupiah liquidity but recovered later .</S>
<S>Tomorrow and today rupiah closed at 2,342.00 / 42.45 and 2,341.5 / 42.0 , respectively .</S>
<S>Another dealer said operators were reluctant to unload rupiah despite ample conditions due to the month-end factor .</S>
<S>" There are two factors which determine the market at present .</S>
<S>The liquidity at month-end and the next court hearing scheduled for Thursday , " the dealer said .</S>
<S><PERSON>Megawati Sukarnoputri</PERSON> , deposed leader of the <ORGANIZATION>Indonesian Democratic Party</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>PDI</ORGANIZATION> ) has sued the government for ousting her as <ORGANIZATION>PDI</ORGANIZATION> leader .</S>
<S>The central <LOCATION>Jakarta</LOCATION> court adjourned the case last Thursday for possible out-of-court settlement .</S>
<S>The hearing is due to resume on Thursday .</S>
<S><PERSON>Megawati</PERSON>'s lawyers said they were still discussing a possible out of court settlement but they was not optimistic an agreement could be reached .</S>
<S>The dealer said this issue remained a factor but its importance to the market seemed to diminish .</S>
<S>He said liquidity would be the main concern for the next few days .</S>
<S>Overnight swap was at 0.45 / 0.48 and tom / next at 0.50 / 0.55 .</S>
<S>One-month swap was at 18.0 / 18.5 , two at 34.0 / 35.0 , three at 52.75 / 53.50 and six at 106.5 / 107.0 points .</S>
<S>The central bank kept its intervention rate at 2,337 / 2,455 and the conversion rate at 2,337 / 2,383 on Monday .</S>

<S>Producers were expected to ship as many hogs as they can ahead of the Labor Day holiday weekend , they said .</S>

<S><PERSON>Michael Posner</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>CHICAGO</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S>No more mild-mannered and meek <PERSON>Al Gore</PERSON> , the vice president and likely heir apparent to President <PERSON>Bill Clinton</PERSON> , emerged on Monday as the new Democratic attack dog leading a front-line assault on <PERSON>Bob Dole</PERSON> and <ORGANIZATION>House</ORGANIZATION> Speaker <PERSON>Newt Gingrich</PERSON> .</S>
<S>While <PERSON>Clinton</PERSON> takes a train trip to the Democratic Convention that will renominate him on Wednesday for a second term , <PERSON>Gore</PERSON> is the bright star in the convention city now .</S>
<S>Crowds anxiously wait for his appearances , thrusting out hands for him to grip as they scream " 12 more years " -- a wishful hope to eight years of <PERSON>Gore</PERSON> after a <PERSON>Clinton</PERSON> re-election .</S>
<S>Over a 15-hour span from Sunday evening to Monday morning , so many people jammed <PERSON>Gore</PERSON> events that the fire marshal stopped members of <ORGANIZATION>Congress</ORGANIZATION> , reporters and others from entering a pro-Israel rally and a meeting of the <LOCATION>New York</LOCATION> delegation .</S>
<S>In his appearances , the often stiff and wooden <PERSON>Gore</PERSON> seemed transformed into a new energetic , gesturing " pol " as he ripped into Republican presidential nominee <PERSON>Dole</PERSON> and <PERSON>Gingrich</PERSON> , who has emerged as the favorite right-wing foil of Democrats .</S>
<S><PERSON>Gore</PERSON> told a roaring labor rally of about 1,000 union workers that <PERSON>Dole</PERSON> and <PERSON>Gingrich</PERSON> were the virtual personifaction of evil , without even mentioning that former Housing Secretary <PERSON>Jack Kemp</PERSON> is <PERSON>Dole</PERSON>'s running mate .</S>
<S>" With equal measures of ignorance and audacity this two-headed monster of <PERSON>Dole</PERSON> and <PERSON>Gingrich</PERSON> has been launching an all out assault on decades of progress of behalf of working men and women , " <PERSON>Gore</PERSON> said to whoops of " 12 more years . "</S>
<S>" They want to drive you out of politics and they can't , " he added . "</S>
<S>They want to silence your voices in elections . "</S>
<S>At a downtown hotel Monday , the 48-year-old <PERSON>Gore</PERSON> gave <LOCATION>Wisconsin</LOCATION> delegates a taste again of the new <PERSON>Gore</PERSON> .</S>
<S>" I want you to ask this question .</S>
<S>What would <LOCATION>Wisconsin</LOCATION> face if the same extremist coalition , the <ORGANIZATION>Gingrich / Dole Congress</ORGANIZATION> , also controlled the executive branch ? "</S>
<S><PERSON>Gore</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>Noting the next presidential term will probably see two or three <ORGANIZATION>Supreme Court</ORGANIZATION> justice nominations , he warned , " Their extremist agenda would come out of the <ORGANIZATION>Gingrich Congress</ORGANIZATION> , into and through the <ORGANIZATION>Dole White House</ORGANIZATION> , down through the <ORGANIZATION>Supreme Court</ORGANIZATION> . "</S>
<S>He painted a scene of horrors he saw if Republicans controlled the <LOCATION>White House</LOCATION> and the <ORGANIZATION>Congress</ORGANIZATION> they hold now . "</S>
<S>Our personal and religious liberties would be at risk .</S>
<S>Medicare would be at risk of withering on the vine .</S>
<S>Medicaid would be at risk of being taken away from poor children .</S>
<S>Education would be at risk .</S>
<S>The environment would be at risk from the polluters that control that coalition , " he said .</S>

<S>With your help we can re-elect <PERSON>Bill Clinton</PERSON> . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Dole</PERSON>'s tax cut plans were called " deja-voodoo economics .... It's a warmed-over plan that failed and drove our economy into a ditch .</S>
<S>We got burned once and we won't let that happen to our nation again . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Gore</PERSON> ridiculed <PERSON>Dole</PERSON>'s defense of the tobacco industry , praised <PERSON>Clinton</PERSON> for " courage " in advancing regulations of it .</S>
<S>To the delegates of <LOCATION>Wisconsin</LOCATION> , a leading dairy state , <PERSON>Gore</PERSON> had the right audience in poking fun at <PERSON>Dole</PERSON>'s comparison to addiction to tobacco to those who can't tolerate milk .</S>
<S>" Some people say milk is bad for you , " <PERSON>Gore</PERSON> said as <LOCATION>Wisconsin</LOCATION> delegates held aloft a plastic inflated cow .</S>

<S>" The choice has never been starker , the stakes today have never been higher , " <PERSON>Gore</PERSON> said . "</S>
<S>We're not going to let them get away with that . "</S>

<DOCUMENT>
<S>Actor <PERSON>Reeve</PERSON> highlights Democrats ' first night .</S>
<S><LOCATION>CHICAGO</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S>The highlights of the first day of the Democratic convention on Monday were expected to feature a mix of party leaders and people who have overcome adversity .</S>
<S>Among the latter were gun control advocate <PERSON>Sarah Brady</PERSON> and actor <PERSON>Christopher Reeve</PERSON> and the politicians included Rep .</S>
<S><PERSON>Richard Gephardt</PERSON> and Sen .</S>
<S><PERSON>Thomas Daschle</PERSON> .</S>
<S>Here are thumbnail profiles of the convention's key Monday speakers .</S>
<S><PERSON>Sarah Brady</PERSON> -- The nation's toughest gun control law is named after <PERSON>Ronald Reagan</PERSON>'s press secretary <PERSON>James Brady</PERSON> but it was his wife who was the major force behind its passage .</S>
<S>As head of <ORGANIZATION>Handgun Control Inc.</ORGANIZATION> , <PERSON>Sarah Brady</PERSON> , 54 , campaigned nonstop for tough gun control in the years following the shooting of her husband and then President <PERSON>Reagan</PERSON> in 1981 .</S>
<S>Her reward was the passage in 1993 of the " Brady Bill " which requires a mandatory five-day waiting period for purchase of handguns and also mandates background checks for would-be gun purchasers .</S>
<S><PERSON>Reagan</PERSON> recovered fully from his wounds but <PERSON>Brady</PERSON> , who was close to death after being shot by <PERSON>John Hinckley Jr</PERSON> .</S>
<S>, suffered serious brain damage .</S>
<S><PERSON>Sarah</PERSON> was <PERSON>Brady</PERSON>'s second wife and they have a son , <PERSON>James Scott Brady Jr</PERSON> .</S>
<S>Before the assassination attempt , she had worked for Republican congressmen and for the <ORGANIZATION>Republican Party</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Christopher Reeve</PERSON> -- <PERSON>Reeve</PERSON> was best known for playing the comic book hero <PERSON>Superman</PERSON> in four movies but his greatest heroics came in real life .</S>
<S><PERSON>Reeve</PERSON> , an accomplished rider who owned several horses , suffered multiple injuries including two shattered neck vertebrae when he was thrown from his horse at an equestrian event in <LOCATION>Culpepper</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Virginia</LOCATION> , on May 27 , 1995 .</S>
<S>Almost entirely paralyzed , <PERSON>Reeve</PERSON> underwent extensive surgery to fuse the vertebrae to the base of the skull and prevent any further damage to his spine .</S>
<S>That allowed him to be moved to a semi-upright position .</S>
<S>Over time he regained the power of speech , so much so that he was asked to address the opening night of the Democratic National Convention .</S>
<S><PERSON>Reeve</PERSON> , 43 , was classically trained as an actor but became the prototypical handsome leading man .</S>
<S>He performed in summer stock and soap operas before being plucked as an almost unknown to play the lead in " <PERSON>Superman</PERSON> " and three sequels .</S>
<S><PERSON>Richard Gephardt</PERSON> -- <PERSON>Gephardt</PERSON> , <ORGANIZATION>House</ORGANIZATION> Democratic leader , is a politician with a " <PERSON>Mr Clean</PERSON> " reputation who sought the presidency eight years ago and is widely believed to still have ambitions for the job .</S>
<S><PERSON>Gephardt</PERSON> , 55 , the son of a milkman from a working class district of <LOCATION>St. Louis</LOCATION> , is a consummate congressional insider , sufficiently skilled in compromise and the ways of the legislature to manage the often-unruly <ORGANIZATION>House</ORGANIZATION> Democrats .</S>
<S>A former lawyer , he was in the front line of President <PERSON>Bill Clinton</PERSON>'s battle with the Republican-led <ORGANIZATION>Congress</ORGANIZATION> over the budget but has opposed the president's decision to sign the Republican-written welfare reform bill .</S>
<S>He advocated tough action against foreign countries to cut <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> trade deficits but sometimes been out of step with the party's liberal wing .</S>
<S>He was an opponent of abortion until 1986 and voted for President <PERSON>Ronald Reagan</PERSON>'s big tax cut bill .</S>
<S><PERSON>Gephardt</PERSON> , a red-haired square-jawed man , is a less than fiery orator .</S>
<S>His 1988 bid for the Democratic nomination only took off after he recreated himself as a firebreathing reformer of the establishment , standing up for blue collar workers and farmers .</S>
<S><PERSON>Tom Daschle</PERSON> -- <PERSON>Daschle</PERSON> , 48 , was largely unknown outside <LOCATION>Washington</LOCATION> and his state of <LOCATION>South Dakota</LOCATION> when he surprisingly beat more prominent rivals to become <ORGANIZATION>Senate</ORGANIZATION> Democratic leader after the party lost its majority to the Republicans in 1994 .</S>
<S>A mild-mannered and youthful man who rose rapidly after entering the <ORGANIZATION>Senate</ORGANIZATION> in 1987 , he presented himself as a <LOCATION>Midwest</LOCATION> moderate , as a Democratic winner in a Republican state able to unite <ORGANIZATION>Senate</ORGANIZATION> factions .</S>
<S>Concern that he might be steamrollered by the vastly more experienced Republican leader <PERSON>Bob Dole</PERSON> was dispelled when he showed a tough edge , outmaneuvering <PERSON>Dole</PERSON> in a wrangle over scrapping a gas tax and raising the federal minimum wage .</S>
<S>In his early <ORGANIZATION>Senate</ORGANIZATION> years he was seen as a " prairie populist " , working on legislation protecting farmers ' prices and also on compensating veterans sickened by Agent Orange defoliant spraying in the Vietnam War .</S>
<S><PERSON>Daschle</PERSON> was a key player in President <PERSON>Bill Clinton</PERSON>'s failed attempt at sweeping healthcare changes but when he became minority leader he declared he would be no water-carrier for the <LOCATION>White House</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>He has made clear he opposed <PERSON>Clinton</PERSON>'s signing of the Republican-initiated welfare reform bill .</S>
<S>He has spent his adult life in politics , coming to <ORGANIZATION>Congress</ORGANIZATION> as an aide in 1972 after three years in the <ORGANIZATION>Air Force</ORGANIZATION> and then being elected to the <ORGANIZATION>House of Representatives</ORGANIZATION> himself in 1978 .</S>

<S>An explosion at <ORGANIZATION>Repsol</ORGANIZATION>'s <LOCATION>Puertollano</LOCATION> refinery , which killed four workers , had not affected output of oil products , an official said .</S>
<S>" The plant is functioning as usual , " <PERSON>Jose Manuel Prieto</PERSON> , director of personnel , told Spanish state television .</S>
<S>Gasoline prices were notionally unchanged from Friday despite sagging NYMEX numbers , with the arbitrage window to the <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> considered closed for the moment .</S>
<S>Eurograde barges were offered at $ 207 fob ARA for <LOCATION>Amsterdam-Rotterdam</LOCATION> barrels , and at $ 206 for full ARA material .</S>
<S>" There is no market at the moment , " one <LOCATION>Rotterdam</LOCATION> trader said . "</S>
<S>Maybe sentiment is a little bit weaker but prices have not changed . "</S>
<S>Outright gas oil prices were notionally softer as the NYMEX heating oil contract headed lower , and following news that the <ORGANIZATION>Indian Oil Corp</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>IOC</ORGANIZATION> ) had issued a tender to buy only 120,000 tonnes of high speed diesel for October .</S>
<S>Asian traders had earlier expected an <ORGANIZATION>IOC</ORGANIZATION> tender for around 400,000 tonnes .</S>
<S>ARA gas oil barges were quiet although one trader said he had seen offers at $ 1 a tonne over September IPE for prompt barrels , while <LOCATION>Antwerp</LOCATION> material was available for 0-50 cents over September .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>IOC</ORGANIZATION> tender had " a bearish impact , but not a great impact , " one German player said .</S>
<S>Fuel oil markets were also listless .</S>
<S>Offers were around a dollar a tonne higher at $ 102 fob ARA but bids were scarce .</S>
<S>-- <PERSON>Nicholas Shaxson</PERSON> , <LOCATION>London</LOCATION> newsroom +44 171 542 8167</S>

<S><LOCATION>Prairies</LOCATION> saw no frost Monday , none rest of week .</S>
<S><LOCATION>WINNIPEG</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S><LOCATION>Canada</LOCATION>'s <LOCATION>Prairies</LOCATION> saw no frost on Monday morning and none was expected anywhere on the grainbelt until late in the Labour Day long weekend , <ORGANIZATION>Environment Canada</ORGANIZATION> said .</S>
<S>" Apparently , we're home free for the rest of the week .</S>
<S>We're not calling for any frost until after the weekend when it starts to cool off in northwestern <LOCATION>Alberta</LOCATION> after the weekend probably Monday or Tuesday , " meteorologist <PERSON>Gerald Machnee</PERSON> told <ORGANIZATION>Reuters</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Sprague</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Manitoba</LOCATION> , on the <LOCATION>Minnesota</LOCATION> border was the cold spot of the <LOCATION>Prairies</LOCATION> Monday morning at 4.0 Celsius ( 39.2 F ) .</S>
<S>Temperatures at ground level can be 2.0 to 5.0 Celsius lower than at chest level depending on windspeed , sky conditions and ground surface moisture .</S>
<S>Freezing occurs at 0 Celsius ( 32.0 F ) .</S>
<S><LOCATION>North Battleford</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Sask</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>, reported a low of 5.0 Celsius ( 41.0 F ) and <LOCATION>Grande Prairie</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Alta</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>, in the <LOCATION>Peace River Valley</LOCATION> reported 7.0 Celsius ( 44.6 F ) .</S>
<S><PERSON>Machnee</PERSON> dismissed talk of frost Wednesday by proponents of the " full moon , frost soon " school of thought .</S>
<S>Lows on August 28 across the <LOCATION>Prairies</LOCATION> should range from 8.0 to 12.0 Celsius with highs around 30.0 Celsius .</S>

<S><LOCATION>CLEVELAND</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Brush Wellman Inc</ORGANIZATION> said Monday that 10 of 24 lawsuits involving chronic beryllium disease have been dismissed since July 1 .</S>
<S>The leading <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> beryllium producer said in a conference call it has traditionally been pro-active regarding the workplace disease , a lung ailment which can affects a small percent of people whose immune systems are susceptible .</S>
<S>Of the 14 remaining suits , 10 were filed by employees of industrial <ORGANIZATION>Brush Wellman</ORGANIZATION> customers and <ORGANIZATION>Brush Wellman</ORGANIZATION> liability in such suits is typically covered by insurance , <PERSON>Timothy Reid</PERSON> , vice president of corporate communications , said on the call .</S>
<S>The company was responding to an article in Sunday's <ORGANIZATION>New York Times</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>He said the article largely reiterated information about the suits and the disease which had previously been made public via <ORGANIZATION>Securities and Exchange Commission</ORGANIZATION> filings and annual reports .</S>
<S>" <ORGANIZATION>Brush Wellman</ORGANIZATION> has been a leader in dealing with health and safety issues ( related to chronic Beryllium disease ) for nearly 50 years , " he said . "</S>
<S>We have a record of going beyond regulatory requirements ... and we consistently share the most current information available ... with customers and employees . "</S>
<S>The customer employee suits were filed in 1990-95 , he said .</S>
<S>A class action filed by a former <ORGANIZATION>Brush Wellman</ORGANIZATION> employee in April 1996 was dismissed in July , he said .</S>
<S>The company is " vigorously defending " the remaining four suits filed by former and current <ORGANIZATION>Brush Wellman</ORGANIZATION> employees , he said .</S>
<S>After a delayed opening , the stock was off 1-1/2 to 18-7/8 .</S>

<S>- <PERSON>Chelsea Clinton</PERSON> , until now carefully shielded from the exposure of public life , made her political debut on Sunday on her father's whistlestop train trip .</S>
<S><PERSON>Chelsea</PERSON> , 16 , was at President <PERSON>Bill Clinton</PERSON>'s side as he rode the rails through parts of <LOCATION>West Virginia</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Kentucky</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Ohio</LOCATION> , and was introduced at every stop .</S>
<S>She even worked ropelines , shaking hands with excited fans .</S>
<S><PERSON>Hillary Rodham Clinton</PERSON> saw her husband and daughter off on the trip in <LOCATION>Huntington</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>West Virginia</LOCATION> and then went on to <LOCATION>Chicago</LOCATION> to begin a rigorous Democratic Convention schedule .</S>
<S>Asked if <PERSON>Chelsea</PERSON> would have a prominent role in the campaign , <LOCATION>White House</LOCATION> spokesman <PERSON>Mike McCurry</PERSON> said : " She'll do what she did today when she can .</S>
<S>She has to go back to school . "</S>
<S>The president's daughter is going into her senior year of high school at <ORGANIZATION>Sidwell Friends School</ORGANIZATION> , a private school in <LOCATION>Washington</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>McCurry</PERSON> said <PERSON>Chelsea</PERSON> has asked to go on the train trip and attend the convention where her father will be renominated , but said her exposure did not signal the start of a new political career .</S>
<S><PERSON>Chelsea</PERSON> " is a very poised young lady , but she's not that much interested in politics , " the spokesman said .</S>

<S>Dutch closing share market report .</S>
<S><LOCATION>AMSTERDAM</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S>Dutch shares drifted to a lower close on Monday , dragged down by weakness in the domestic bond market and turnover depressed by the <LOCATION>UK</LOCATION> bank holiday and lack of any significant <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> economic data .</S>
<S>The AEX index of leading shares closed 4.54 points easier at 556.19 , the day's low .</S>
<S>The Dutch market had been on the defensive all day but a softer start to <LOCATION>Wall Street</LOCATION> did little to boost sentiment in late trade , dealers said .</S>
<S>" It was always going to be a tough day with participation so low .</S>
<S>But the only thing really worrying the market was the bonds , and that dragged us lower , " one dealer said .</S>
<S>Stocks were down across the board , with <ORGANIZATION>Dutch PTT</ORGANIZATION> topping the volume list and closing down 1.90 guilders at 58.70 .</S>
<S>The post and telecoms firm posted an 8.5 percent rise in first half earnings on Friday , just below analysts ' expectations .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>IHC Caland</ORGANIZATION> reported first half results well under forecasts on Monday and the shares suffered as a result .</S>
<S>They were trading unchanged just before the release of figures but closed 2.40 guilders down at 80.70 after it reported net profits of 34.9 million guilders against 36.6 million last year and estimates ranging from 37.5 to 47.2 million .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>IHC</ORGANIZATION> also forecast post tax earnings rising 21 percent for the full year .</S>
<S>Banking group <ORGANIZATION>ING</ORGANIZATION> traded ex-dividend today and finished 0.60 guilders weaker at 52.90 as a result .</S>
<S>But <ORGANIZATION>Nutricia</ORGANIZATION> shrugged off its ex-div tag to soar a further 4.10 guilders to 214.40 continuing its explosive rally sparked by the 51 percent jump in first half net profits last week , which set the market alight on Friday , sending the shares up 18.40 at 210.00 by the close .</S>
<S>Engineering concern <ORGANIZATION>Stork</ORGANIZATION> started the day well as the shares attracted some follow-through interest to the announcement late on Friday that its <ORGANIZATION>Fokker Aviation</ORGANIZATION> unit had won a major order .</S>
<S>But the rally was short-lived and <ORGANIZATION>Stork</ORGANIZATION> ended just 0.20 up at 51.00 guilders .</S>

<S><PERSON>Tapie</PERSON> to quit French assembly seat as film opens .</S>
<S><LOCATION>PARIS</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S>Former businessman and soccer boss <PERSON>Bernard Tapie</PERSON> said that he would give up his seat in the <ORGANIZATION>National Assembly</ORGANIZATION> by Wednesday , the day a film by <PERSON>Claude Lelouche</PERSON> in which he stars opens in <LOCATION>France</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" I will no longer be deputy by the time the film opens , " he said in a broadcast interview .</S>
<S>" Just about , " he told <ORGANIZATION>Europe 1</ORGANIZATION> radio when asked whether he had sent his letter of resignation to <ORGANIZATION>Assembly</ORGANIZATION> speaker <PERSON>Philippe Seguin</PERSON> .</S>
<S>A <PERSON>Seguin</PERSON> spokeswoman confirmed that no letter or call had yet been received .</S>
<S><PERSON>Tapie</PERSON> , 53 , was resigning just ahead of expected government action to eject him from the <ORGANIZATION>Assembly</ORGANIZATION> following a finding by the <ORGANIZATION>Supreme Court</ORGANIZATION> that he was bankrupt and thus ineligible for public office for a five-year period .</S>
<S><PERSON>Tapie</PERSON> , the target of a blizzard of legal actions over his now-destroyed business empire and the <ORGANIZATION>Marseille</ORGANIZATION> soccer team he once ran , has a starring role in <PERSON>Lelouche</PERSON>'s " Homme , femmes : mode d'emploi " ( Men , women : instructions for use ) .</S>
<S>He plays a power-hungry lawyer in the movie described as " a tender and cruel comedy " by <PERSON>Lelouche</PERSON> , who is making his 35th film .</S>
<S>" I have paid too dearly for mixing two careers , " <PERSON>Tapie</PERSON> said . "</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>France</LOCATION> , you cannot be a film artist and a national politician at the same time .</S>
<S>That is why I will no longer be deputy by the time the film opens . "</S>
<S>Justice Minister <PERSON>Jacques Toubon</PERSON> began last month the formal process of ejecting <PERSON>Tapie</PERSON> from the French parliament as well as stripping him of his seat in the European parliament .</S>
<S>The French procedure was expected to be completed before October 2 , when the <ORGANIZATION>National Assembly</ORGANIZATION> is to reconvene after a summer break , but the European procedure was expected to take longer .</S>
<S><PERSON>Tapie</PERSON>'s lawyer has said he intends to appeal to the <ORGANIZATION>European Court of Human Rights</ORGANIZATION> in an effort to prevent or delay the loss of his European seat .</S>
<S>But such an appeal , even if the court were to accept the case , which it is not obliged to do , would not suspend enforcement of the French judgement against him .</S>
<S><PERSON>Tapie</PERSON> faces a probable spell in prison after he loses his parliamentary immunity , since two appeal courts have confirmed jail sentences of eight and six months against him for tax fraud and rigging a soccer match .</S>
<S>He is appealing in both cases to the <ORGANIZATION>Supreme Court</ORGANIZATION> .</S>

<S>Dutch co-operative bank <ORGANIZATION>Rabobank Nederland BA</ORGANIZATION>'s net profit growth might slow to less than than 10 year percent in the second half of 1996 , executive board chairman <PERSON>Herman Wijffels</PERSON> said on Monday .</S>
<S>The unlisted bank earlier announced a 1996 interim net profit of 853 million guilders , up 21.5 percent on the 702 million guilders reported in the first half of 1995 .</S>
<S>He said second-half profit growth would depend on customer demand for loans , which was already easing , and the performance of financial markets , which were strong in the first half and boosted securities , trading and underwriting income .</S>
<S>" We expect reasonable growth in the second half .</S>
<S>Maybe it will be in single-digits , " <PERSON>Wijffels</PERSON> told <ORGANIZATION>Reuters</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>He said growth in customer demand in the first half was 50 percent above normal but it was hard to maintain this pace .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Rabobank</ORGANIZATION>'s net profit was 1.43 billion guilders in 1995 .</S>
<S>The bank earlier warned that profit growth would slow in the second half , citing the increasing momentum in profit growth in the comparative period of 1995 and increased investment .</S>
<S>But <PERSON>Wijffels</PERSON> was unable to quantify second half investment to improve and extend domestic and offshore services .</S>

<S>Thai Prime Minister <PERSON>Banharn Silpa-archa</PERSON> on Monday proposed September 18 as the date for parliamentary debate on an opposition no-confidence motion accusing him of incompetence .</S>
<S>The president of parliament had earlier said September 11 could be set for the debate .</S>
<S>The opposition motion against <PERSON>Banharn</PERSON> accuses him of being incompetent , lacking ethical leadership and alleges his administration is corrupt .</S>
<S>His critics allege he may be attempting to delay the debate .</S>
<S><PERSON>Banharn</PERSON> has denied the accusations and said he is ready to clear himself in parliament .</S>
<S>" In my opinion September 18 would be a convenient date for the government to answer questions .</S>
<S>This has nothing to do with the accusation that I am trying to escape the debate , " <PERSON>Banharn</PERSON> told reporters after meeting coalition partners .</S>
<S><PERSON>Banharn</PERSON>'s 13-month-old , six-party coalition government controls 209 seats in the 391-seat lower house of parliament .</S>
<S>Political infighting within <PERSON>Banharn</PERSON>'s <ORGANIZATION>Chart Thai</ORGANIZATION> party has raised doubts whether he can hold his supporters together and defeat the opposition motion , political analysts said .</S>
<S>" We are still waiting to fix a date .</S>
<S>September 18 is regarded as tentative because we still have not received the order to fix it on the agenda , " said an official at parliament's agenda section .</S>
<S>The last no-confidence debate against <PERSON>Banharn</PERSON>'s coalition in May was won by the government .</S>

<S><ORGANIZATION>Nomura Research Institute Ltd</ORGANIZATION> downgraded <ORGANIZATION>Aronkasei Co Ltd</ORGANIZATION> to a " 2 " rating from its previous " 1 " , market sources said on Monday .</S>
<S>In its three-grade rating system , the research institute assigns a " 2 " rating to issues whose values it sees moving within 10 percentage points in either direction of the key 225-share Nikkei average over the next six months .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Nomura</ORGANIZATION> officials were not immediately available for comment .</S>

<S>FOCUS - <ORGANIZATION>Eurobourses</ORGANIZATION> end mixed but <LOCATION>London</LOCATION> recovers .</S>
<S><PERSON>Leonard Santorelli</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>LONDON</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>European bourses closed mixed on Tuesday with <LOCATION>London</LOCATION> clawing back most of the day's losses despite an unsteady start on <ORGANIZATION>wall Street</ORGANIZATION> , hit by inflation worries .</S>
<S>The dollar weakened during the day with many dealers sidelined because of uncertainty over <LOCATION>Tokyo</LOCATION>'s monetary direction ahead of the important Japanese <ORGANIZATION>Tankan</ORGANIZATION> economic survey out on Wednesday .</S>
<S>But it recovered at the close of trade .</S>
<S>Stocks in <LOCATION>London</LOCATION> started the week badly after a three-day weekend , slipping 0.3 percent , but bargain-hunters later moved in and the FTSE index recovered most of the lost ground to end only just in negative ground .</S>
<S>Tuesday's patchy showing in <LOCATION>London</LOCATION> followed a string of records last week , culminating in Friday's trading high of 3,911 , fuelled by a wave of European interest rate cuts .</S>
<S>The <LOCATION>London</LOCATION> bourse drew little help from the unsettled morning on <LOCATION>Wall Street</LOCATION> , which slipped in and out of positive ground after a stronger-than-expected August consumer confidence report refuelled inflation fears , pulling <ORGANIZATION>U.S. Treasuries</ORGANIZATION> back from their early peaks .</S>
<S>Shortly after the report appeared showing the confidence index rising to 109.4 in August from a revised 107.0 in July , <LOCATION>Wall Street</LOCATION> relinquished virtually all its morning gains .</S>
<S>" <ORGANIZATION>Treasuries</ORGANIZATION> remain very sensitive to any indication of a strong economy and we're still in that summer doldrum period of light trading , " said <PERSON>Alan Ackerman</PERSON> , market strategist at <ORGANIZATION>Fahnestock & Co</ORGANIZATION> . "</S>
<S>Consequently , stocks and bonds are both subject to rapid swings . "</S>
<S><LOCATION>Frankfurt</LOCATION> was the one bright spot in <LOCATION>Europe</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>Floor trading ended up 0.25 percent and the computerised IBIS index climbed nearly 0.4 percent , given a push by the performance of chemical shares . "</S>
<S>The market is trading 100 percent on fundamentals at the moment as interest rate fantasy disappears -- it's all company news , " said one trader .</S>
<S>French shares ended slightly down amid growing unease about a difficult autumn for the government which also weighed on the franc , dealers said .</S>
<S>Bond prices were weaker and the franc was quoted at 3.4210 per mark for the first time since August 13 as worries about the government's autumn budget and a weak <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> currency lifted the mark and squeezed French investments .</S>
<S>The dollar , which dropped sharply on Monday because of jitters over the Japanese <ORGANIZATION>Tankan</ORGANIZATION> survey , weakened further in quiet trading but regained losses to end the day close to Monday's levels .</S>
<S>" Besides the <ORGANIZATION>Tankan</ORGANIZATION> , there's nothing really until the <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> jobs numbers next week , " said a <LOCATION>UK</LOCATION> bank corporate dealer . "</S>
<S>There is still the summer malaise hanging over the market . "</S>
<S>Foreign exchange markets regard the <ORGANIZATION>Tankan</ORGANIZATION> report as an important indication of the country's future monetary policy direction .</S>
<S>If it points to weakness in the economy , the report will help the dollar regain some lost ground as speculation of a near-term rise in Japanese interest rates will evaporate .</S>
<S>The Japanese discount rate is currently at a record low of 0.5 percent .</S>
<S>The dollar was also pressured by the mark's strength against European currencies amid renewed concerns over <LOCATION>Europe</LOCATION>'s economic and monetary union ( EMU ) timetable .</S>
<S>CURRENCIES</S>
<S>The dollar was at 1.4788 marks and 107.74 yen at the close of European trading compared with 1.4789 marks and 107.55 yen on Monday .</S>
<S>STOCK MARKETS</S>
<S>The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading British shares ended 1.8 points lower at 3,905.7 .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Paris</LOCATION> , the CAC-40 share index finished down 2.43 at 2,017.99 .</S>
<S>The 30-share DAX index in <LOCATION>Frankfurt</LOCATION> closed up 6.48 at 2,558.84 .</S>
<S>PRECIOUS METALS</S>
<S>Gold closed at $ 388.55 an ounce , compared with Monday's close of $ 388.75 on international markets .</S>
<S>Silver ended up one cent $ 5.24 .</S>

<S><LOCATION>STANSTED</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>England</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>

<S>A spokesman for <LOCATION>Stansted</LOCATION> airport said that the unidentified hijackers were demanding to see a British-based member of the <ORGANIZATION>Iraqi Community Association</ORGANIZATION> , called Mr <PERSON>Sadiki</PERSON> , and that police were trying to trace him .</S>
<S>Police spokeswoman <PERSON>Kim White</PERSON> said police had already contacted <PERSON>Sadiki</PERSON> and were trying to arrange to bring him to <LOCATION>Stansted</LOCATION> , 30 miles ( 48 km ) north-east of <LOCATION>London</LOCATION> , to talk to the hijackers .</S>
<S>The airport spokesman said the six hijackers , who police said were armed with grenades and possibly other explosives , were believed to be Iraqi nationals .</S>
<S>The hijackers started to release people for the Airbus plane in batches of 10 , starting with women and children , in what police described as a " controlled release " .</S>

<DOCUMENT>
<S>FEATURE - " Eco terrorists " target <LOCATION>UK</LOCATION> builders .</S>
<S><PERSON>Edna Fernandes</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>LONDON</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>Ecological warfare has broken out across the British construction industry , striking some of the biggest corporates as activists give up peaceful protests and seek to hit builders where it hurts -- their profit margins .</S>
<S>Described by one British company as " eco-terrorism " , it is seen as the new business risk of the 1990s .</S>
<S>Famous names like <ORGANIZATION>Tarmac Plc</ORGANIZATION> , <ORGANIZATION>Costain Group Plc</ORGANIZATION> and <ORGANIZATION>ARC</ORGANIZATION> , a unit of conglomerate <ORGANIZATION>Hanson Plc</ORGANIZATION> , have all been targeted .</S>
<S>Activist groups are no longer seen by British firms as a harmless , badly organised ragbag of students and hippies .</S>
<S>" You only have to see them in action at protests , " said <PERSON>David Harding</PERSON> , spokesman at <ORGANIZATION>ARC</ORGANIZATION> , <ORGANIZATION>Hanson</ORGANIZATION>'s aggregates company . "</S>
<S>They walk around with mobile phones and camera equipment , they communicate and gather support for demos via the Internet -- we're talking about a highly sophisticated organisation . "</S>
<S>One road protestor under the codename <PERSON>Steady Eddie</PERSON> told construction journal " <ORGANIZATION>Building</ORGANIZATION> " earlier this year , " If it comes down to full-scale economic warfare , we will aim to drive them out of business . "</S>
<S>As well as financial threats , companies also emphasise the " terror " tactics used .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Costain</ORGANIZATION>'s contract to build the controversial <LOCATION>Newbury</LOCATION> bypass , which runs through a conservation area , has led to violent protests delaying building , bomb threats , staff intimidation and picketing of chief executive <PERSON>Alan Lovell</PERSON>'s home .</S>
<S>A <ORGANIZATION>Costain</ORGANIZATION> spokesman told <ORGANIZATION>Reuters</ORGANIZATION> : " We've had all sorts of protests at the head office and the chief executive's house .</S>
<S>But it's when it gets to the ( employee ) families -- that it goes across the line . "</S>
<S>Tactics used by some underground groups including the cryptic <ORGANIZATION>Berkshire Wood Elves</ORGANIZATION> , which distribute leaflets with instructions on home-made explosives , are now the subject of a police investigation .</S>
<S>Other larger activist groups include <ORGANIZATION>Earth First</ORGANIZATION> , <ORGANIZATION>The Land is Ours</ORGANIZATION> , <ORGANIZATION>Alarm UK</ORGANIZATION> and <ORGANIZATION>Road Alert</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>The groups have targeted specific projects like the <LOCATION>Newbury</LOCATION> bypass and the <LOCATION>M3</LOCATION> motorway through <LOCATION>Twyford Down</LOCATION> in the southern county of <LOCATION>Hampshire</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>But they are also campaigning on broader issue such as stopping the government road building programme and out-of-town superstores which they say create more traffic , pollution and damage local communities .</S>
<S>The government has slashed its road-building spending .</S>
<S>Although protests may have contributed to the decision it has been seen primarily as economic rather than ecological .</S>
<S><PERSON>Graham Watts</PERSON> , chief executive of the <ORGANIZATION>Construction Industry Council</ORGANIZATION> , said : " I don't think many firms involved in tendering for sensitive projects realise the impact environmental activity has on the cost of running a project .</S>
<S>" But they are more alert than they were 3-4 years ago .</S>
<S>There's no doubt it's a big issue now . "</S>
<S>He says the damage comes in two forms : " Tangible -- in the form of extra costs , additional security , threats to staff and the more intangible damage caused by negative publicity . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Watts</PERSON> said the cost of protesting can be heavy once the company is locked into a contract .</S>
<S>" I do often hear on the industry circuit of tales where the company tenders at low margins and the demonstrations which follow means they are running the project at a loss . "</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>ARC</ORGANIZATION> says it's not just contractors in the front line but also suppliers like itself .</S>
<S>Its own quarries came under attack after it emerged that it may be a supplier for the <LOCATION>Newbury</LOCATION> bypass .</S>
<S>" It was called the " First Battle of the Newbury bypass ' , " said <ORGANIZATION>ARC</ORGANIZATION>'s <PERSON>Harding</PERSON> .</S>
<S>" We had 300 <ORGANIZATION>Earth First</ORGANIZATION> protestors invade and occupy our site .</S>
<S>Hundreds of thousands of pounds ( dollars ) of damage was done in one day .</S>
<S>Plus there was the knock-on cost of lost production and extra security in future . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Simon Brown</PERSON> , analyst at investement bank <ORGANIZATION>UBS</ORGANIZATION> , said this new phenomenon has led to a change in the way the industry evaluates project risk .</S>
<S>" When talking to <ORGANIZATION>Tarmac</ORGANIZATION> about the <LOCATION>M3</LOCATION> link ( through <LOCATION>Twyford Down</LOCATION> ) they made it fairly clear that their risk assessment methods have been changed and now involve a very clear environmental risk analysis . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Harding</PERSON> says others have done the same . "</S>
<S>As a result of eco-terrorism we are looking at controversial jobs more closely to see if the profit margins are wide enough to cover things like extra security . "</S>
<S>For an industry already suffering from razor-thin margins , overcapacity and stagnant demand , eco-terrorism is the latest bizarre twist in the construction sector's tale of woe .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S>London Carnival ends in high spirits .</S>
<S><LOCATION>LONDON</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S><LOCATION>London</LOCATION>'s annual Notting Hill Carnival , the largest in <LOCATION>Europe</LOCATION> and second in the world only to <LOCATION>Rio</LOCATION> , ended peacefully on Monday with an estimated 800,000 revellers singing and dancing the day away in high spirits .</S>
<S>Police said they made 30 arrests and there were two stabbings .</S>
<S>But there was no repeat of the ugly scenes that used to scar the street festival , and police praised the crowds over the two days of festivities as good-natured .</S>
<S>Around 400 police were wounded in riots in 1976 when the carnival , now in its 31st year , acquired its darker reputation from which it is now only slowly recovering .</S>
<S>Shopkeepers still board up their windows and many residents leave town for the weekend , but for four or five years there has been no disorder and relatively little crime .</S>

<S>The Spaniard has not played for nearly a year because of rheumatoid arthritis in both his feet , and organisers of a pairs event to be staged in <LOCATION>Bordeaux</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>France</LOCATION> from October 17 to 20 have been asked to provide him with a buggy .</S>

<S>But commitee member <PERSON>Montgomerie</PERSON> said it could set an unhelpful precedent . "</S>
<S>I know <PERSON>Olly</PERSON>'s situation is very unfortunate , but I don't think we can start giving dispensations , " he said . "</S>
<S>You've got to have a rule for everybody and I don't think it's feasible . "</S>
<S>The use of carts is generally prohibited in the professional game , and if <PERSON>Olazabal</PERSON> is allowed to use one in <LOCATION>Bordeaux</LOCATION> , he might then request one for the qualifying tournaments for next year's Ryder Cup .</S>

<S>SOCCER - <PERSON>BALL</PERSON> RESIGNS AS <ORGANIZATION>MANCHESTER CITY</ORGANIZATION> MANAGER .</S>
<S><LOCATION>MANCHESTER</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>England</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>Former <LOCATION>England</LOCATION> midfielder <PERSON>Alan Ball</PERSON> resigned as manager of first division side <ORGANIZATION>Manchester City</ORGANIZATION> on Monday night , the club said .</S>
<S><PERSON>Ball</PERSON> , appointed in July 1995 , was unable to prevent <ORGANIZATION>City</ORGANIZATION> being relegated from the premier league last season and his record read 13 wins , 14 draws and 22 losses in 49 games .</S>
<S>They have lost two of their three matches so far this season .</S>
<S>Club secretary <PERSON>Bernard Halford</PERSON> said in a statement : " The chairman and <ORGANIZATION>Board</ORGANIZATION> would like to place on record their appreciation of his endeavours and efforts whilst in his period of office and wish him well in the future . "</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S>CRICKET - <PERSON>GOOCH</PERSON> TO PLAY ANOTHER SEASON FOR <LOCATION>ESSEX</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><LOCATION>LONDON</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S><PERSON>Graham Gooch</PERSON> , the 43-year-old former <LOCATION>England</LOCATION> captain , is to continue playing county cricket for at least another season , his club <ORGANIZATION>Essex</ORGANIZATION> announced on Tuesday .</S>
<S>Opener <PERSON>Gooch</PERSON>'s decision comes towards the end of a season in which he has underlined his consistency by becoming the leading scorer in <ORGANIZATION>Essex</ORGANIZATION>'s history , beating <PERSON>Keith Fletcher</PERSON>'s aggregate of 29,434 .</S>
<S><PERSON>Gooch</PERSON> , who retired from test cricket after the 1994-95 tour of <LOCATION>Australia</LOCATION> but is now an <LOCATION>England</LOCATION> selector , is seventh in this season's first-class averages with 1,429 runs at 64.95 , having hit five centuries and one double century .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Essex</ORGANIZATION> secretary-general manager <PERSON>Peter Edwards</PERSON> said : " He is a remarkable batsman and still the best in this country .</S>
<S>No-one will argue with that .</S>
<S>You just have to look at his record to appreciate that fact . "</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>SOCCER - <LOCATION>ROMANIA</LOCATION> CLUB BOSS BANNED FOR HEADBUTT .</S>
<S><LOCATION>BUCHAREST</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Romanian Soccer Federation</ORGANIZATION> has banned first division club <ORGANIZATION>Jiul Petrosani</ORGANIZATION>'s president <PERSON>Miron Cozma</PERSON> for two years for headbutting a visiting team player , a federation statement said .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Romania</LOCATION>'s soccer bosses also fined <PERSON>Cozma</PERSON> , a well-known miners ' union leader , 10 million lei ( $ 3000 ) for the half-time attack on <ORGANIZATION>Dinamo Bucharest</ORGANIZATION>'s <PERSON>Danut Lupu</PERSON> last Sunday .</S>
<S>Miners led by <PERSON>Cozma</PERSON> rioted in <LOCATION>Bucharest</LOCATION> in 1990 and 1991 , bringing down the reformist government of premier <PERSON>Petre Roman</PERSON> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Cozma</PERSON> is awaiting trial for assault and criminal damage in a bar in his home town of <LOCATION>Petrosan</LOCATION> , 300 kms west of <LOCATION>Bucharest</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>The attack on <PERSON>Lupu</PERSON> came during a tunnel skirmish between opposing players as they left the field .</S>
<S>" <PERSON>Cozma</PERSON>'s blow was not too painful because I'm a tall man , " <PERSON>Lupu</PERSON> told <ORGANIZATION>Reuters</ORGANIZATION> on Tuesday .</S>
<S><PERSON>Lupu</PERSON> is one of the tallest players in <LOCATION>Romania</LOCATION>'s first division , towering over <PERSON>Cozma</PERSON> by some 17 cms ,</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Jiul Petrosani</ORGANIZATION> , promoted to the first division this year , won the league game 1-0 .</S>
<S><PERSON>Cozma</PERSON> is barred from taking part in any official soccer activity during the ban .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<DOCUMENT>
<S>TENNIS - <PERSON>EDBERG</PERSON> EXTENDS GRAND SLAM RUN , TOPPLES <LOCATION>WIMBLEDON</LOCATION> CHAMP .</S>
<S><PERSON>Larry Fine</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>NEW YORK</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S><PERSON>Stefan Edberg</PERSON> produced some of his vintage best on Tuesday to extend his grand run at the Grand Slams by toppling Wimbledon champion <PERSON>Richard Krajicek</PERSON> in straight sets at the U.S. Open .</S>
<S><PERSON>Edberg</PERSON> , competing in the 54th consecutive and final Grand Slam event of his illustrious career , turned back the clock at <LOCATION>Stadium Court</LOCATION> with a flowing 6-3 6-3 6-3 serve-and-volley victory over the fifth-seeded Dutchman .</S>
<S>" It's a win that I can be proud of , " said the 30-year-old Swede , winner of two <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> Opens and six Grand Slam titles in all . "</S>
<S>It's never easy to beat the Wimbledon champion . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Edberg</PERSON> , who has said he will retire at season's end , made it look easy under gray skies at the <LOCATION>National Tennis Centre</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>The unseeded Swede struck quickly , breaking <PERSON>Krajicek</PERSON> in the first game and never let loose his grip on the one hour 44 minute match as he served and volleyed with the grace that made him one of the dominant players of his time .</S>
<S>" There's not doubt about it , <PERSON>Richard</PERSON> was definitely off his game and I took advantage , " said <PERSON>Edberg</PERSON> .</S>
<S>" I still have my days where I feel great out there . "</S>
<S>Also reaching the second round were top-seeded defending champion <PERSON>Pete Sampras</PERSON> , a 6-2 6-2 6-1 winner over last minute replacement <PERSON>Jimy Szymanski</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Venezuela</LOCATION> , called on after <PERSON>Adrian Voinea</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Romania</LOCATION> withdrew because of a sprained ankle .</S>
<S>Third seed <PERSON>Thomas Muster</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Austria</LOCATION> also charged into the second round with a 6-1 7-6 ( 7-2 ) 6-2 romp over <PERSON>Javier Frana</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Argentina</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Marcelo Rios</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Chile</LOCATION> , the 10th seed , also advanced .</S>
<S><PERSON>Rios</PERSON> claimed a 4-6 6-1 6-4 6-2 victory over <LOCATION>Romania</LOCATION>'s <PERSON>Andrei Pavel</PERSON> .</S>
<S>On the women's side , second seed <PERSON>Monica Seles</PERSON> got off to a strong start by beating fellow-American <PERSON>Anne Miller</PERSON> 6-0 6-1 and was joined in the second round by <LOCATION>Spain</LOCATION>'s <PERSON>Arantxa Sanchez Vicario</PERSON> ( seeded third ) , Olympic champion <PERSON>Lindsay Davenport</PERSON> ( 8 ) and <PERSON>Karina Habsudova</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Slovakia</LOCATION> ( 17 ) .</S>
<S>The women's draw lost another seed when Austrian <PERSON>Judith Wiesner</PERSON> overcame <PERSON>Iva Majoli</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Croatia</LOCATION> 2-6 6-3 6-1 .</S>
<S>The fifth- seeded <PERSON>Majoli</PERSON> joined <PERSON>Anke Huber</PERSON> ( 5 ) and <PERSON>Magdalena Maleeva</PERSON> ( 12 ) on the sidelines .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>TENNIS - TUESDAY's RESULTS FROM U.S. OPEN .</S>
<S><LOCATION>NEW YORK</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>

<S>BASEBALL - <ORGANIZATION>GIANTS</ORGANIZATION> EDGE <ORGANIZATION>PHILLIES</ORGANIZATION> 1-0 .</S>
<S><LOCATION>SAN FRANCISCO</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S><PERSON>William VanLandingham</PERSON> pitched eight scoreless innings and <PERSON>Glenallen Hill</PERSON> drove in the game's only run with a first-inning single as the <ORGANIZATION>San Francisco Giants</ORGANIZATION> claimed a 1-0 victory over the <ORGANIZATION>Philadelphia Phillies</ORGANIZATION> on Monday .</S>
<S><PERSON>VanLandingham</PERSON> ( 8-13 ) , who entered the game with one complete game in the first 56 starts of his career , limited the <ORGANIZATION>Phillies</ORGANIZATION> to two hits and two walks with four strikeouts .</S>
<S>" We've been working all year on my follow-through , and I really concentrated on that , " <PERSON>VanLandingham</PERSON> said . "</S>
<S>It gave me more life in all of my pitches , so the ball moved more . "</S>
<S>At <LOCATION>Colorado</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Andres Galarraga</PERSON> homered and drove in three runs as the <ORGANIZATION>Colorado Rockies</ORGANIZATION> had 10 extra-base hits and <PERSON>Billy Swift</PERSON> won his first game in almost a year in a 9-5 rain-shortened seven-inning victory over the <ORGANIZATION>Cincinnati Reds</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Swift</PERSON> ( 1-0 ) , who made his first start since June 3rd and underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right shoulder earlier in the season , allowed five runs and six hits in five innings .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Houston</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Andy Benes</PERSON> allowed two runs over seven innings and <PERSON>Royce Clayton</PERSON> had a run-scoring single in the seventh to lift the <ORGANIZATION>St. Louis Cardinals</ORGANIZATION> to a 3-2 victory over the <ORGANIZATION>Houston Astros</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Benes</PERSON> ( 14-9 ) allowed five hits , walked five and struck out 10 for his 11th win in 12 decisions .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Cardinals</ORGANIZATION> moved within one-half game of first-place <ORGANIZATION>Houston</ORGANIZATION> in the National League Central Division .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>BASEBALL - <ORGANIZATION>ORIOLES</ORGANIZATION> WIN , <ORGANIZATION>YANKEES</ORGANIZATION> LOSE .</S>
<S><LOCATION>BALTIMORE</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S><PERSON>Cal Ripken</PERSON>'s bases-loaded walk scored <PERSON>Brady Anderson</PERSON> with the winning run in the bottom of the 10th as the <ORGANIZATION>Baltimore Orioles</ORGANIZATION> regained control of the top spot in the wild-card race with a wild 12-11 victory over the <ORGANIZATION>Oakland Athletics</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>Trailing by a run entering the 11th , the <ORGANIZATION>Orioles</ORGANIZATION> rallied against <ORGANIZATION>Oakland</ORGANIZATION> reliever <PERSON>Mark Acre</PERSON> ( 0-2 ) with a walk and a triple by <PERSON>Brady Anderson</PERSON> to tie the game .</S>
<S>Then <ORGANIZATION>Oakland</ORGANIZATION> manager <PERSON>Art Howe</PERSON> decided to intentionally walk <PERSON>Rafael Palmeiro</PERSON> and <PERSON>Bobby Bonilla</PERSON> to load the bases but <PERSON>Acre</PERSON> was nowhere near the plate to <PERSON>Ripken</PERSON> .</S>
<S>The decisive pitch nearly hit <PERSON>Ripken</PERSON> and gave the <ORGANIZATION>Orioles</ORGANIZATION> a one-half game lead over the <ORGANIZATION>Chicago White Sox</ORGANIZATION> in the wild-card race .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Seattle</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Jay Buhner</PERSON>'s eighth-inning single snapped a tie as the <ORGANIZATION>Seattle Mariners</ORGANIZATION> edged the <ORGANIZATION>New York Yankees</ORGANIZATION> 2-1 in the opener of a three-game series .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>New York</ORGANIZATION> starter <PERSON>Jimmy Key</PERSON> left the game in the first inning after <ORGANIZATION>Seattle</ORGANIZATION> shortstop <PERSON>Alex Rodriguez</PERSON> lined a shot off his left elbow .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Yankees</ORGANIZATION> have lost 12 of their last 19 games and their lead in the AL East over <ORGANIZATION>Baltimore</ORGANIZATION> fell to five games .</S>
<S>At <LOCATION>California</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Tim Wakefield</PERSON> pitched a six-hitter for his third complete game of the season and <PERSON>Mo Vaughn</PERSON> and <PERSON>Troy O'Leary</PERSON> hit solo home runs in the second inning as the surging <ORGANIZATION>Boston Red Sox</ORGANIZATION> won their third straight 4-1 over the <ORGANIZATION>California Angels</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Boston</ORGANIZATION> has won seven of eight and is 20-6 since August 2nd .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Red Sox</ORGANIZATION> are two games over .500 for the first time this season .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Chicago</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Cal Eldred</PERSON> pitched 5-1/3 scoreless innings and <PERSON>John Jaha</PERSON> scored one run and doubled in another as the <ORGANIZATION>Milwaukee Brewers</ORGANIZATION> held off the slumping <ORGANIZATION>Chicago White Sox</ORGANIZATION> , 3-2 .</S>
<S>Eldred ( 6-5 ) walked one and struck out three .</S>
<S><PERSON>Angel Miranda</PERSON> retired one batter and <PERSON>Bob Wickman</PERSON> retired the next four but loaded the bases in the eighth .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Detroit</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Jim Thome</PERSON>'s solo homer in the ninth inning snapped a tie and <PERSON>Charles Nagy</PERSON> pitched a three-hitter for his first win in over a month , leading the <ORGANIZATION>Cleveland Indians</ORGANIZATION> to their 11th straight victory over the <ORGANIZATION>Detroit Tigers</ORGANIZATION> , 2-1 .</S>
<S>With the score tied 1-1 in the ninth , Thome hit a 2-2 pitch from starter <PERSON>Felipe Lira</PERSON> ( 6-11 ) over the left-field fence for his 29th homer .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Toronto</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Juan Guzman</PERSON> allowed three runs over seven innings to make homers by <PERSON>Joe Carter</PERSON> and <PERSON>Carlos Delgado</PERSON> stand up as the surging <ORGANIZATION>Toronto Blue Jays</ORGANIZATION> held off the <ORGANIZATION>Minnesota Twins</ORGANIZATION> , 5-3 .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Toronto</LOCATION> returned home from a 10-game road trip and won for the eighth time in nine games as <PERSON>Guzman</PERSON> ( 11-8 ) allowed nine hits and struck out eight without a walk .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
