<S>TENNIS - <PERSON>CHANG</PERSON> , <LOCATION>WASHINGTON</LOCATION> ADVANCE , TWO WOMEN's SEEDS FALL .</S>
<S><PERSON>Larry Fine</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>NEW YORK</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S><PERSON>Michael Chang</PERSON> is playing in his 10th U.S. Open and enjoying his highest seeding ever , but the 24-year-old American had to overcome a case of the jitters Monday before winning his first-round match on opening day .</S>
<S><PERSON>Chang</PERSON> , seeded second behind defending champion <PERSON>Pete Sampras</PERSON> , took two hours 40 minutes to defeat 186th-ranked <PERSON>Jaime Oncins</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Brazil</LOCATION> 3-6 6-1 6-0 7-6 , 8-6 in the tiebreaker .</S>
<S>" I was pretty tight the whole match , " conceded <PERSON>Chang</PERSON> , one of the hottest players on tour this summer with a 16-2 record on hardcourts that included two titles and a runner-up finish .</S>
<S>" Everyone has moments when they get tight .</S>
<S>Hopefully , this will have been my nerves for the whole tournament . "</S>
<S>Joining <PERSON>Chang</PERSON> into the second round was Wimbledon runner-up <PERSON>MaliVai Washington</PERSON> , the 11th seed , who also needed four sets to get past talented Moroccan <PERSON>Karim Alami</PERSON> 6-4 2-6 7-6 ( 7-5 ) 6-1 .</S>
<S><PERSON>Washington</PERSON>'s win was not comfortable , either .</S>
<S>The 27-year-old American hurried off the <LOCATION>Stadium Court</LOCATION> for treatment of an upset stomach after his two and a half hour struggle against <PERSON>Alami</PERSON> .</S>
<S>" Towards the end of my match my stomach felt like week-old sushi , " said <LOCATION>Washington</LOCATION> . "</S>
<S>Maybe it was a combination of the heat and something I ate . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Chang</PERSON> and <PERSON>Washington</PERSON> were the only men's seeds in action on a day that saw two seeded women's players fall .</S>
<S>Australian Open runner-up <PERSON>Anke Huber</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Germany</LOCATION> , the sixth seed , was undone by an unlucky draw that put her against 17th ranked South African <PERSON>Amanda Coetzer</PERSON> in her opening match .</S>
<S><PERSON>Coetzer</PERSON> claimed revenge for the semifinal defeat she suffered to <PERSON>Huber</PERSON> in <LOCATION>Melbourne</LOCATION> by taking a 6-1 2-6 6-2 victory .</S>
<S>Last year's Wimbledon junior champion , <PERSON>Aleksandra Olsza</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Poland</LOCATION> , removed another seed from the draw by eliminating number 12 <PERSON>Magdalena Maleeva</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Bulgaria</LOCATION> 6-4 6-2 .</S>
<S>Other men's winners included a pair of former Grand Slam tournament champions whose victories set up a showdown in the second round .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Germany</LOCATION>'s <PERSON>Michael Stich</PERSON> , the 1991 Wimbledon champion , and two-time French Open winner <PERSON>Sergi Bruguera</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Spain</LOCATION> will face each other next after beating German <PERSON>Tommy Haas</PERSON> 6-3 1-6 6-1 7-5 , and Belgian <PERSON>Kris Goossens</PERSON> 6-2 6-0 7-6 ( 7-1 ) , respectively .</S>
<S><PERSON>Alex O'Brien</PERSON> , who scored his first professional title eight days ago in <LOCATION>New Haven</LOCATION> , advanced to the second round with a 6-4 1-6 6-4 6-3 win over <LOCATION>Ecuador</LOCATION>'s <PERSON>Nicolas Lapentti</PERSON> .</S>
<S>Wimbledon bad boy <PERSON>Jeff Tarango</PERSON> caught a break Monday when he advanced after the retirement of German <PERSON>Alex Radulescu</PERSON> due to heat exhaustion .</S>
<S><PERSON>Tarango</PERSON> was leading 6-7 ( 5-7 ) 6-4 6-1 3-1 .</S>
<S><PERSON>Chang</PERSON> blamed breezy conditions for some of the erratic play in his match with <PERSON>Oncins</PERSON> , who had beaten him in the round of 32 at the 1992 <LOCATION>Barcelona</LOCATION> Olympics .</S>
<S><PERSON>Chang</PERSON> committed an untidy 53 unforced errors , though he made seven fewer than the Brazilian , who also walloped a woeful 24 double faults .</S>
<S>The most deflating double fault came when <PERSON>Oncins</PERSON> was serving to force a fifth set , leading 6-4 in the tiebreaker .</S>
<S>The set point came after confusion at the net on the point previous , which was awarded to <PERSON>Oncins</PERSON> after the two exchanged shots at close quarters at the net .</S>
<S>First <PERSON>Chang</PERSON> approached the umpire , then <PERSON>Oncins</PERSON> , then <PERSON>Chang</PERSON> again before play finally resumed .</S>
<S>" Those little seconds were like an hour to me , " said <PERSON>Oncins</PERSON> , who promptly fired two serves barely contained by the baseline as he frittered away his best chance .</S>
<S><PERSON>Chang</PERSON> ran off the next three points to close out the match but for <PERSON>Oncins</PERSON> , the contest was a personal victory .</S>
<S>The 26-year-old Brazilian had risen into the top 30 in 1992 .</S>
<S>The next year a close friend was struck by a stray bullet while riding home in a car from a soccer game in <LOCATION>Sao Paulo</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>He died slumped against <PERSON>Oncins</PERSON> , who subsequently lost interest in tennis .</S>
<S>" Two months ago I started talking about quitting , " said <PERSON>Oncins</PERSON> , who decided to give it one last try and made it through the Open qualifying tournament last weekend .</S>
<S>" I believe in my game again , " he said .</S>
<S>At the end of the day , a spate of withdrawals from the tournament were announced .</S>
<S>Eighth seed <PERSON>Jim Courier</PERSON> withdrew because of a bruised right knee , and 1988 Open champion <PERSON>Mats Wilander</PERSON> bowed out due to a groin pull , organisers said .</S>
<S>Women's ninth seed <PERSON>Mary Joe Fernandez</PERSON> pulled out because of tendinitis in her right wrist .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S>SOCCER - <ORGANIZATION>MARSEILLE</ORGANIZATION> HOLD <ORGANIZATION>AUXERRE</ORGANIZATION> TO GOALLESS DRAW .</S>
<S><LOCATION>PARIS</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>Former European champions <ORGANIZATION>Marseille</ORGANIZATION> held French champions <ORGANIZATION>Auxerre</ORGANIZATION> to a goalless draw in a lacklustre league match on Tuesday .</S>
<S>The bill looked promising but both sides , struggling to find their form early in the season , were disappointing .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Auxerre</ORGANIZATION> , who start their European Cup campaign next week against <ORGANIZATION>Ajax Amsterdam</ORGANIZATION> , dominated the match but were unable to score .</S>
<S>Unbeaten in four matches , they still trail leaders <ORGANIZATION>Lens</ORGANIZATION> by one point .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Lens</ORGANIZATION> , who have won all their three league matches so far , host <ORGANIZATION>Montpellier</ORGANIZATION> on Wednesday night .</S>
<S>Despite another dismal performance , especially in defence , <ORGANIZATION>Marseille</ORGANIZATION> restored some pride by keeping the reigning champions at bay after losing 2-1 at home to <ORGANIZATION>Metz</ORGANIZATION> last Saturday .</S>
<S>After two seasons in the second division and after taking on half a dozen new recruits this season , some of whom do not speak a word of French , <ORGANIZATION>Marseille</ORGANIZATION> are not playing with any fluidity .</S>
<S>But German international goalkeeper <PERSON>Andreas Koepke</PERSON> again proved a sound investment when under pressure from the <ORGANIZATION>Auxerre</ORGANIZATION> strikers , saving his team with a number of fine parries .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Marseille</ORGANIZATION> now lie seventh in the league on five points .</S>

<S>SOCCER - <ORGANIZATION>NEUCHATEL</ORGANIZATION> TO APPEAL AGAINST <PERSON>CYPRIEN</PERSON>'s NINE-MONTH BAN .</S>
<S><LOCATION>GENEVA</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>Swiss league leaders <ORGANIZATION>Neuchatel Xamax</ORGANIZATION> said on Tuesday they would appeal against a nine-month ban imposed on French international defender <PERSON>Jean-Pierre Cyprien</PERSON> for his part in a post-match brawl .</S>
<S><PERSON>Cyprien</PERSON> , also fined 10,000 Swiss francs ( $ 8,400 ) , traded punches with <ORGANIZATION>St Gallen</ORGANIZATION>'s Brazilian player <PERSON>Claudio Moura</PERSON> after a match on Saturday .</S>
<S>When officials and coaching staff tried to intervene , <PERSON>Cyprien</PERSON> launched a flying kick at <PERSON>Moura</PERSON> , but only succeeded in kneeing <ORGANIZATION>St Gallen</ORGANIZATION> coach <PERSON>Roger Hegi</PERSON> in the stomach .</S>
<S><PERSON>Moura</PERSON> , who appeared to have elbowed <PERSON>Cyprien</PERSON> in the final minutes of the 3-0 win by <ORGANIZATION>Neuchatel</ORGANIZATION> , was suspended for seven matches and fined 1,000 francs ( $ 840 ) by the Swiss league disciplinary committee .</S>
<S>Club president <PERSON>Gilbert Facchinetti</PERSON> said he was astonished the committee had arrived at its decision so quickly and vowed the club would appeal .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Neuchatel</ORGANIZATION> coach <PERSON>Gilbert Gress</PERSON> described the incident as " shocking " , but said <PERSON>Moura</PERSON> was also to blame .</S>
<S>" <PERSON>Moura</PERSON> physically and verbally provoked <PERSON>Cyprien</PERSON> during the match .</S>
<S>The referee could not have seen it or he would have punished him , " <PERSON>Gress</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>" During the scuffle , <PERSON>Moura</PERSON> threw the first punch .</S>
<S>Tomorrow , if someone punches me , I would not know how to react . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Cyprien</PERSON> , who won his one French cap against <LOCATION>Italy</LOCATION> in February 1994 , cannot play in <LOCATION>Switzerland</LOCATION> or elsewhere until May next year .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>CYCLING - <PERSON>BUGNO</PERSON> CLEARED OF DOPING .</S>
<S><LOCATION>MILAN</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>Veteran Italian <PERSON>Gianni Bugno</PERSON> has been cleared of doping after testing positive for high levels of testosterone during the Tour of Switzerland in June , the Italian cycling federation said on Tuesday .</S>
<S>" He has been cleared .</S>
<S>The case is closed , " a spokesman said .</S>
<S><PERSON>Bugno</PERSON> tested positive for the banned hormone after the fifth stage of the Tour , in which he finished third overall .</S>
<S>But the spokesman said subsequent tests in <LOCATION>Cologne</LOCATION> proved his body produced higher-than-average testosterone levels naturally .</S>
<S><PERSON>Bugno</PERSON> , who won the Giro d'Italia in 1990 and two successive world titles , was banned for three months in 1994 after testing positive for the stimulant caffeine .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<DOCUMENT>
<S><ORGANIZATION>COFINEC</ORGANIZATION> SLIPS ON <LOCATION>BUDAPEST</LOCATION> BOURSE BUT FUTURE STRONG .</S>
<S><PERSON>Emese Bartha</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>BUDAPEST</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>Expectations that <ORGANIZATION>Cofinec S.A.</ORGANIZATION> , the Hungarian bourse's first foreign listing , will report a disappointing first half have depressed the stock below its issue price , but analysts expect a rebound in the long term .</S>
<S>" The first half of the year is unlikely to be as strong as expected so the company will probably be unable to reach its annual plan in 1996 , " said <PERSON>Gabor Sitanyi</PERSON> , a London-based analyst for <ORGANIZATION>ING Barings</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>The French-registered packaging materials company , which floated its shares in <LOCATION>Hungary</LOCATION> in July , for most of the past two weeks hovered below the 6,425 forints / Global Depositary Receipts price of its initial offering , which was oversubscribed .</S>
<S>The company , which asked for a two-week delay from the usual August 15 deadline for reporting first-half results , closed on Tuesday at 5,800 forints , down 300 .</S>
<S>" <ORGANIZATION>Cofinec</ORGANIZATION>'s first-half figures will be ...</S>
<S>between one-third of two-fifths of its annual plan , " said <PERSON>Tamas Erdei</PERSON> , a Budapest-based analyst for <ORGANIZATION>ABN-AMRO Hoare Govett</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>Analysts blame , at least partly , <LOCATION>Hungary</LOCATION>'s macroeconomic environment for the weaker figures for <ORGANIZATION>Cofinec</ORGANIZATION> which , operating in <LOCATION>Hungary</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Poland</LOCATION> and the <LOCATION>Czech Republic</LOCATION> , now generates about 55 to 60 percent of its annual sales from <LOCATION>Hungary</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Hungary</LOCATION>'s Gross Domestic Product fell one percentage point in the first quarter while real wages plunged 7.2 percentage points in the first half of 1996 .</S>
<S>Both will have their impact on <ORGANIZATION>Cofinec</ORGANIZATION>'s figures , the analysts said .</S>
<S>Despite the current difficulties , however , analysts were convinced that <ORGANIZATION>Cofinec</ORGANIZATION>'s outlook was strong .</S>
<S>" The eastern European market offers good chances , " said <PERSON>Erdei</PERSON> . "</S>
<S>Just like many other companies on the bourse , <ORGANIZATION>Cofinec</ORGANIZATION> has big growth opportunities . "</S>
<S>" At the same time , it's an advantage for <ORGANIZATION>Cofinec</ORGANIZATION> that it has a foreign management which perhaps understands the market better , " <PERSON>Erdei</PERSON> added .</S>
<S>" <ORGANIZATION>Cofinec</ORGANIZATION> is a very good story in the long-term as the per capita packaging consumption is still so low in east <LOCATION>Europe</LOCATION> that a very strong increase can be expected ( long-term ) , " <PERSON>Sitanyi</PERSON> said , saying that several recent moves by <ORGANIZATION>Cofinec</ORGANIZATION> boosted its position .</S>
<S>Among them , he noted that <ORGANIZATION>Cofinec</ORGANIZATION> had acquired the outstanding stake in its Czech folding company <ORGANIZATION>Krpaco a.s.</ORGANIZATION> , increasing its ownership to 100 percent , so in the second half the whole of <ORGANIZATION>Krpaco</ORGANIZATION>'s figures will be consolidated .</S>
<S>The company also repaid some $ 21 million of debt , well above the originally planned $ 8 million to $ 9 million .</S>
<S>In addition , its Polish operation began with some six weeks of delay due to cold winter weather and the test run was also longer than planned .</S>
<S>-- <LOCATION>Budapest</LOCATION> newsroom ( 36 1 ) 266 2410</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S>DIRECT EQUITY TRADES ON THE CZECH <ORGANIZATION>PSE</ORGANIZATION> - AUG 27 .</S>
<S><LOCATION>PRAGUE</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>The following is a list of</S>
<S>direct equity trades made on the <ORGANIZATION>Prague Stock Exchange</ORGANIZATION> :</S>
<S>ISSUE Min .</S>
<S>Price Max .</S>

<S>AFTER THE BELL - After hours slows in light volume .</S>
<S><LOCATION>NEW YORK</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>Traders said on Tuesday after-hours activity was light .</S>
<S>Both <ORGANIZATION>WorldCom Inc</ORGANIZATION> and <ORGANIZATION>MFS Communications Co Inc</ORGANIZATION> were trading but they moved in line with their close .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>WorldCom</ORGANIZATION> , which said it will buy <ORGANIZATION>MFS</ORGANIZATION> , shed 1-3/4 to close at 21 while <ORGANIZATION>MFS</ORGANIZATION> lost 3-8/16 to close at 41-5/16 .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>New York Stock Exchange</ORGANIZATION> said its session one volume was 5,700 shares compared to 53,400 shares Monday .</S>
<S>Session two volume was 4,153,800 shares compared to no volume Monday .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>American Stock Exchange</ORGANIZATION> said there was no after-hours activity .</S>

<S><ORGANIZATION>CBOE</ORGANIZATION> in routine review of <ORGANIZATION>MFS</ORGANIZATION> options .</S>
<S><LOCATION>CHICAGO</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Chicago Board Options Exchange</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>CBOE</ORGANIZATION> ) said on Tuesday it was doing a routine investigation into trading in options on <ORGANIZATION>MFS Communications Co Inc</ORGANIZATION> shares .</S>
<S>On Monday , the company said it had agreed to be acquired by <ORGANIZATION>WorldCom Inc</ORGANIZATION> in a deal valued at $ 14 billion .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>MFS</ORGANIZATION> shares surged on the news while <ORGANIZATION>WorldCom</ORGANIZATION> fell on fears of dilution .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>The New York Times</ORGANIZATION> said on Tuesday some of the options trading in <ORGANIZATION>MFS</ORGANIZATION> last Friday may suggest insider trading .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>MFS</ORGANIZATION> options also trade on the <ORGANIZATION>American Stock Exchange</ORGANIZATION> and the <ORGANIZATION>Pacific Stock Exchange</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>A spokesman for the <ORGANIZATION>American Stock Exchange</ORGANIZATION> would neither confirm or deny whether the exchange was looking into trading .</S>
<S>" If there is unusual activity , certainly we look at it , but that's not to say we're doing anything official , " he said .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Pacific Stock Exchange</ORGANIZATION> officials were not available .</S>
<S>One trader said trading in <ORGANIZATION>MFS</ORGANIZATION> options had increased steadily from about mid-August , and doubted whether any of last Friday's activity was insider trading .</S>
<S>- Derivatives desk , 312 408-8750 / E-mail : derivatives@reuters.com</S>

<S>The 36-year-old <ORGANIZATION>Aston Villa</ORGANIZATION> player won the last of his Irish record of 82 international caps against the <LOCATION>Czech Republic</LOCATION> in <LOCATION>Prague</LOCATION> in April .</S>
<S>" <PERSON>Paul</PERSON> accepted the situation .</S>

<S>He's certainly is still very much part of my plans for the future .</S>

<S>Sudanese rebels say missionaries should be freed .</S>
<S><PERSON>Peter Smerdon</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>NAIROBI</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>The main rebel group in south <LOCATION>Sudan</LOCATION> said on Tuesday it was trying to arrange the release of six Roman Catholic missionaries , including three Australian nuns , held for nearly two weeks .</S>
<S><PERSON>George Garang</PERSON> , <LOCATION>Nairobi</LOCATION> spokesman for the <ORGANIZATION>Sudan People's Liberation Army</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>SPLA</ORGANIZATION> ) , said it was urgently trying to contact <ORGANIZATION>SPLA</ORGANIZATION> commander <PERSON>Nuour Marial</PERSON> at <LOCATION>Mapourdit</LOCATION> in the south to free the six .</S>
<S>" The movement is making arrangements for them to be set free .</S>
<S>This is a decision of the leadership , " <PERSON>Garang</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>" Commander <PERSON>Nuour Marial</PERSON> is a soldier so he must accept the leadership's decision .</S>
<S>But communications at this time of year are very difficult because of rains and a lack of power , " he added .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Catholic Information Office</ORGANIZATION> in <LOCATION>Nairobi</LOCATION> said on Monday that four of the six had been charged by the <ORGANIZATION>SPLA</ORGANIZATION> with spying , spreading Islam and hindering recruitment into the rebel group .</S>
<S>" These charges are the interpretation of the church , " <PERSON>Garang</PERSON> said on Tuesday . "</S>
<S>We have no idea why they are being held .</S>
<S>We are still trying to establish contact with the local commander . "</S>
<S>Asked whether this meant the commander was out of control , <PERSON>Garang</PERSON> said the rebel movement was working on the problem .</S>
<S>He said he believed all six were being held in the mission compound at <LOCATION>Mapourdit</LOCATION> and were reported to be in good health .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Catholic Information office</ORGANIZATION> in <LOCATION>Nairobi</LOCATION> said on Monday that Australian Sisters <PERSON>Moira Lynch</PERSON> , 73 , and <PERSON>Mary Batchelor</PERSON> , 68 , American Father <PERSON>Michael Barton</PERSON> , 48 , and Sudanese Father <PERSON>Raphael Riel</PERSON> , 48 , were held in a prison in south <LOCATION>Sudan</LOCATION> by the <ORGANIZATION>SPLA</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>It said Australian Sister <PERSON>Maureen Carey</PERSON> , 52 , and Italian Brother <PERSON>Raniero Iacomella</PERSON> , 28 , were held inside the compound .</S>
<S>The church in <LOCATION>Australia</LOCATION> said on Monday <PERSON>Lynch</PERSON> , <PERSON>Batchelor</PERSON> , <PERSON>Barton</PERSON> and <LOCATION>Riel</LOCATION> were held in a prison until the weekend , when they were moved to join the other captives at the compound .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Catholic Information Office</ORGANIZATION> said the <ORGANIZATION>SPLA</ORGANIZATION> in the Kenyan capital had attributed the detentions of the six to a local commander and had promised they would be freed by August 23 .</S>
<S>But the church learned in a recent meeting with the local commander that no instructions to release the prisoners were received and they would be held until investigations were completed .</S>
<S>It said last Friday they were visited by Monsignor <PERSON>Caesar Mazzolari</PERSON> , apostolic administrator of the diocese of <LOCATION>Rumbek</LOCATION> in southern <LOCATION>Sudan</LOCATION> , and an <ORGANIZATION>SPLA</ORGANIZATION> administrator and appeared in good condition .</S>
<S>" On August 17 the mission was surrounded ( by the <ORGANIZATION>SPLA</ORGANIZATION> ) and sealed off .</S>
<S>The evening of the same day the missionaries were put in prison or isolation .</S>
<S>Later the mission was looted , " it added .</S>
<S>An Australian foreign ministry official said the charges against them were " fairly bizarre " and a matter for concern .</S>
<S>He said Australian diplomats in <LOCATION>Nairobi</LOCATION> were working with the Roman Catholic church in southern <LOCATION>Sudan</LOCATION> and with <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> and Italian diplomats in the region to help free the missionaries .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>SPLA</ORGANIZATION> has fought <LOCATION>Khartoum</LOCATION>'s government forces in the south since 1983 for greater autonomy or independence of the mainly Christian and animist region from the Moslem , <LOCATION>Arabised north</LOCATION> .</S>

<S><ORGANIZATION>OSCE</ORGANIZATION> postpones Bosnian municipal elections .</S>
<S><LOCATION>SARAJEVO</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>The <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> diplomat in charge of elections in <LOCATION>Bosnia</LOCATION> announced on Tuesday that voting for municipal assemblies would be postponed because of irregularities by the Serbs in registering voters .</S>
<S>Ambassador <PERSON>Robert Frowick</PERSON> , representing the <ORGANIZATION>Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>OSCE</ORGANIZATION> ) , told reporters that municipal polls due on September 14 with other Bosnian elections would be put off .</S>
<S>" I have made a chairman's decision that it is not feasible to hold municipal elections on September 14 , " said <PERSON>Frowick</PERSON> .</S>
<S>He said no exact date had been set but it was possible the local elections would take place in the spring of 1997 .</S>
<S>According to <ORGANIZATION>OSCE</ORGANIZATION> officials , Serb authorities have pressed their refugees to register to vote in towns now under Serb control , but which used to have Moslem majorities .</S>
<S>Human rights workers say authorities in <LOCATION>Serbia</LOCATION> and Bosnian Serb territory have conducted a well-organised campaign to coerce refugees into registering only on Serb territory and failed to inform them of their rights under the <LOCATION>Dayton</LOCATION> peace agreement .</S>
<S>Diplomats say the effect of the electoral engineering would be to establish political control over districts they conquered and ethnically cleansed in war .</S>
<S>The response of the Bosnian Serbs to the <ORGANIZATION>OSCE</ORGANIZATION>'s announcement was not immediately clear .</S>
<S>But Bosnian Serb leaders have hinted they would boycott the poll if the municipal elections were postponed , or go ahead with their own .</S>
<S>The Bosnian Serb cabinet , in a letter to the <ORGANIZATION>OSCE</ORGANIZATION> , said on Monday that any delay of local elections would be " a direct and flagrant violation fo the <LOCATION>Dayton</LOCATION> agreement " .</S>
<S>The Serbs , who administer half of <LOCATION>Bosnia</LOCATION> in a Serb republic , said they had met all conditions for holding the September elections .</S>
<S>Diplomats fear that the crisis could cast doubt over the entire election process , which already appears set to confirm <LOCATION>Bosnia</LOCATION>'s ethnic partition rather than its reintegration as the <LOCATION>Dayton</LOCATION> peace agreement had planned .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>New talks in <LOCATION>Chechnya</LOCATION> as <PERSON>Lebed</PERSON> waits for <PERSON>Yeltsin</PERSON> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Dmitry Kuznets</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>NOVYE ATAGI</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Russia</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>Russian and rebel military commanders finally met in <LOCATION>Chechnya</LOCATION> on Tuesday for delayed talks aimed at finalising a ceasefire arranged last week by President <PERSON>Boris Yeltsin</PERSON>'s envoy <PERSON>Alexander Lebed</PERSON> .</S>
<S>The Russian army commander in the region , General <PERSON>Vyacheslav Tikhomirov</PERSON> , arrived at the rebel-held village of <LOCATION>Novye Atagi</LOCATION> , some 20 km ( 12 miles ) south of the Chechen capital <LOCATION>Grozny</LOCATION> for discussions with rebel chief-of-staff <PERSON>Aslan Maskhadov</PERSON> .</S>
<S>But <PERSON>Lebed</PERSON> himself , the <LOCATION>Kremlin</LOCATION> security chief , is still waiting back in <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> to meet <PERSON>Yeltsin</PERSON> over his plans for a lasting political settlement in <LOCATION>Chechnya</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Itar-Tass</ORGANIZATION> news agency quoted the <LOCATION>Kremlin</LOCATION> press service as saying <PERSON>Yeltsin</PERSON> , who left for a state holiday home near <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> on Monday , would hold no working meetings on Tuesday .</S>
<S><PERSON>Lebed</PERSON> interrupted talks with <LOCATION>Chechnya</LOCATION>'s separatists on a political deal on Sunday , saying he had to consult with <PERSON>Yeltsin</PERSON> .</S>
<S>After a meeting failed to materialise on Monday , <PERSON>Lebed</PERSON>'s spokesman said he might meet the president on Tuesday .</S>
<S>But <PERSON>Yeltsin</PERSON>'s spokesman rebuffed the suggestion , saying the president had left <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> for a holiday near the capital .</S>
<S>The Russians postponed the talks after a Chechen band disarmed a column of <ORGANIZATION>interior ministry</ORGANIZATION> troops on Sunday .</S>
<S>The Chechens said a renegade group seized the weapons and said on Monday they had all been returned .</S>
<S>The Russian command insisted that not all the weapons were the same as those taken .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Tass</ORGANIZATION> said the weapons and the practical implementation of the ceasefire signed by <PERSON>Lebed</PERSON> and <PERSON>Maskhadov</PERSON> last Thursday would be on the agenda of today's talks .</S>
<S>Neither spoke to reporters before the meeting , which started around 10.45 a.m. ( 0645 GMT ) .</S>
<S>Also in <LOCATION>Novye Atagi</LOCATION> on Tuesday morning , was <PERSON>Tim Guldimann</PERSON> , the Swiss diplomat who heads the <LOCATION>Chechnya</LOCATION> mission of the <ORGANIZATION>Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>OSCE</ORGANIZATION> ) .</S>
<S><PERSON>Guldimann</PERSON> , who helped broker an earlier truce in May , was not taking part in the Tikhomirov-Maskhadov talks .</S>
<S><PERSON>Lebed</PERSON>'s peace mission this month has stopped some of the worst fighting of the 20-month-old conflict .</S>
<S>However , tension on the ground indicates that it could falter if the momentum for a settlement is not maintained .</S>
<S>Three Russian servicemen were wounded in a total of six shooting incidents overnight , <ORGANIZATION>Itar-Tass</ORGANIZATION> news agency quoted the Russian military as saying on Tuesday morning .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>RIA</ORGANIZATION> news agency quoted an army source accusing rebel fighters of failing to turn up for joint Russian-Chechen police patrols in some districts of the capital <LOCATION>Grozny</LOCATION> on Tuesday .</S>
<S>But the separatist command told <ORGANIZATION>Interfax</ORGANIZATION> news agency the patrols , part of the truce brokered by <PERSON>Lebed</PERSON> last week , would begin on Tuesday after delays for " technical reasons " .</S>
<S><PERSON>Yeltsin</PERSON>'s spokesman said he might meet officials during his break , but indicated <PERSON>Lebed</PERSON> was low on the list by saying <PERSON>Yeltsin</PERSON> would need time to study the proposals before talking to him .</S>
<S>Russian news agencies also quoted the <LOCATION>Kremlin</LOCATION> spokesman as saying that <PERSON>Lebed</PERSON>'s representatives had not sought a meeting , hinting at an attempt by the president to put his popular and outspoken protege in his place with a lesson on protocol .</S>
<S><PERSON>Yeltsin</PERSON> , 65 , has kept a low profile since he was reelected in July , prompting new speculation that the two heart attacks he suffered last year and a rumoured drinking problem could be taking their toll , weakening his grip on affairs of state .</S>
<S>Aides have dismissed such speculation , insisting that he simply needs a rest after his energetic election campaign .</S>
<S>Some analysts say the <LOCATION>Kremlin</LOCATION> leader , whose order sending troops and tanks into <LOCATION>Chechnya</LOCATION> in 1994 started <LOCATION>Russia</LOCATION>'s ill-fated military campaign , could merely be reluctant to put his name to a peace process which might fall apart .</S>
<S>But <PERSON>Lebed</PERSON> , who has no real power without his boss and has hinted at dark forces in <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> working against him , appears to think a deal will not stick without strong backing from <PERSON>Yeltsin</PERSON> .</S>
<S>His proposals have not been spelled out but are expected to involve a compromise between the separatists ' demand for independence and <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION>'s insistence that <LOCATION>Chechnya</LOCATION> remain part of the <LOCATION>Russian Federation</LOCATION> .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S><LOCATION>Slovenia</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Poland</LOCATION> target <ORGANIZATION>EU</ORGANIZATION> , <ORGANIZATION>NATO</ORGANIZATION> membership .</S>
<S><LOCATION>LJUBLJANA</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S><LOCATION>Slovenia</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Poland</LOCATION> pledged to intensify cooperation on Tuesday and reinforced their determination to join the <ORGANIZATION>European Union</ORGANIZATION> and <ORGANIZATION>NATO</ORGANIZATION> at the earliest possible date .</S>
<S>Polish President <PERSON>Aleksander Kwasniewski</PERSON> and his Slovenian counterpart , <PERSON>Milan Kucan</PERSON> , met for talks at the start of a two-day visit to <LOCATION>Slovenia</LOCATION> by <PERSON>Kwasniewski</PERSON> .</S>
<S>It was their fourth meeting this year .</S>
<S>They said in a statement they agreed to have regular telephone contact to discuss progress in strengthening ties with the <LOCATION>West</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" We expect our cooperation will help both countries towards entering the <ORGANIZATION>European Union</ORGANIZATION> and <ORGANIZATION>NATO</ORGANIZATION> , " <PERSON>Kwasniewski</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>" We have similar ambitions as far as our internal development and international life is concerned , " <PERSON>Kucan</PERSON> said .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Poland</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Slovenia</LOCATION> are hoping to be among the first group of former eastern bloc countries to join the <ORGANIZATION>European Union</ORGANIZATION> and <ORGANIZATION>NATO</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>They have already signed an association agreement with the <ORGANIZATION>European Union</ORGANIZATION> and are both part of the <ORGANIZATION>Central European Free Trade Area</ORGANIZATION> , which also comprises <LOCATION>Hungary</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Slovakia</LOCATION> and the <LOCATION>Czech Republic</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Slovenia</LOCATION>'s trade with <LOCATION>Poland</LOCATION> rose to $ 142.3 million in 1995 from $ 118.8 million in 1994 .</S>
<S>During his visit to <LOCATION>Slovenia</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Kwasniewski</PERSON> is also scheduled to meet Prime Minister <PERSON>Janez Drnovsek</PERSON> , representatives of Slovenian political parties and representatives of the <ORGANIZATION>Chamber of Economy</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>Nationalists want <PERSON>Iliescu</PERSON> ousted for <LOCATION>Hungary</LOCATION> pact .</S>
<S><LOCATION>BUCHAREST</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>Junior Nationalist members of <LOCATION>Romania</LOCATION>'s ruling coalition called on Tuesday for the impeachment of President <PERSON>Ion Iliescu</PERSON> for backing a friendship treaty with neighbouring <LOCATION>Hungary</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Iliescu</PERSON>'s <ORGANIZATION>Party of Social Democracy</ORGANIZATION> , the senior coalition partner , immediately dismissed the <ORGANIZATION>National Unity Party</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>PUNR</ORGANIZATION> ) demand as crude electioneering .</S>
<S>" It is a desperate move by the <ORGANIZATION>PUNR</ORGANIZATION> , which is losing its only reason for existing ahead of the electoral campaign , " said <ORGANIZATION>PDSR</ORGANIZATION> executive president <PERSON>Adrian Nastase</PERSON> .</S>
<S>" This treaty is both necessary and good , " <PERSON>Nastase</PERSON> said , adding that the <ORGANIZATION>PUNR</ORGANIZATION>'s stance was threatening its position in the government .</S>
<S>The treaty agreed unexpectedly two weeks ago will end years of disputes over the status of <LOCATION>Romania</LOCATION>'s large ethnic Hungarian minority .</S>
<S>It will also boost both countries ' chances of admission to <ORGANIZATION>NATO</ORGANIZATION> and the <ORGANIZATION>European Union</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>" If they ( the <ORGANIZATION>PUNR</ORGANIZATION> ) are so vexed , they could leave the government ...</S>
<S>We might also help them to do it , if they go on like this , " he said .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>PUNR</ORGANIZATION> holds four key ministries -- justice , transport , agriculture and communications .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>PUNR</ORGANIZATION> leader <PERSON>Gheorghe Funar</PERSON> said in a statement <PERSON>Iliescu</PERSON> , in power since the fall of communism in 1989 , should be impeached for treason for compromising on the issue of ethnic Hungarian minority rights in the treaty due to be signed next month .</S>
<S><PERSON>Funar</PERSON>'s call came on the eve of the official launch of <PERSON>Iliescu</PERSON>'s campaign for a new term at November 3 polls .</S>
<S>His appeal to the opposition to back his attempt to oust <PERSON>Iliescu</PERSON> was unlikely to succeed , analysts said .</S>
<S><PERSON>Iliescu</PERSON> has invited political leaders to a meeting on Thursday to discuss the final form of the pact which both Romanian and Hungarian nationalists oppose for different reasons .</S>
<S>Presidential officials were not available to comment on the call for <PERSON>Iliescu</PERSON>'s impeachment .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>Estonian MPS see little hope of electing president .</S>
<S><PERSON>Belinda Goldsmith</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>TALLINN</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S><LOCATION>Estonia</LOCATION>'s parliament failed for a second time to elect a president on Tuesday , dealing a blow to incumbent <PERSON>Lennart Meri</PERSON> and pushing the country towards stalemate in its choice of a new head of state .</S>
<S>Neither <PERSON>Meri</PERSON> , who oversaw <LOCATION>Estonia</LOCATION>'s first steps into statehood after the collapse of the <LOCATION>Soviet Union</LOCATION> , nor his arch-rival , former communist <PERSON>Arnold Ruutel</PERSON> , have secured the 68 votes necessary from the 101-member parliament .</S>
<S><PERSON>Meri</PERSON> garnered 49 votes and <PERSON>Meri</PERSON> 34 in Tuesday's ballot for the five-year presidency of <LOCATION>Estonia</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>A third and final vote was due to be held when parliament reconvened on Tuesday but legislators were not expecting a clear result .</S>
<S>If there is no result the decision will be ceded to an electoral college .</S>
<S>" The votes are a strong message to <PERSON>Meri</PERSON> that he is not favoured by some politicians any more , " <ORGANIZATION>Reform Party</ORGANIZATION> head <PERSON>Heiki Kranich</PERSON> told <ORGANIZATION>Reuters</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>Under a constitution agreed in 1992 , a year after independence , the president has no executive powers .</S>
<S>His only political role is to smoothe the functioning of government in periods of crisis .</S>
<S>But <PERSON>Meri</PERSON> , 67 , has been accused in parliament of taking too much power and not always consulting parliamentarians before making decisions .</S>
<S>His relations with a leftist-led government have sometimes been tense .</S>
<S>His support in the first round of voting on Monday was much lower than expected , scoring only 45 votes , which political analysts put down as a vote of no confidence in his performance .</S>
<S>This support only inched up to 49 in the second vote .</S>
<S>Support for <PERSON>Ruutel</PERSON> , 68 , remained constant at 34 votes .</S>
<S>If the third vote fails to give either <PERSON>Meri</PERSON> or <PERSON>Ruutel</PERSON> 68 votes , the parliamentary speaker will convene an electoral college of 101 MPs and 273 local goverment representatives to hold a new poll that could include new nominations .</S>
<S>This would be the first time that the former Soviet republic has had to call together an electoral college .</S>
<S>In its first presidential election in 1992 <PERSON>Meri</PERSON> won the necessary votes in in a parliamentary election against <PERSON>Ruutel</PERSON> .</S>
<S>Parliamentary organisers said the exact timetable remained unclear but it would probably take about a month to organise an electoral college which could also hold several rounds of voting before a clear winner emerges .</S>

<S><PERSON>Ruutel</PERSON> won 34 votes in the first two secret ballots .</S>

<S>The election will now go before an electoral college involving MPs and local government representatives that will be convened by the parliamentary Speaker in the next day or so .</S>
<S>It could take up to a month before a new vote but the timetable is not yet clear .</S>
<S>This is the first time the former Soviet republic has had to convene such a group .</S>

<S>A <ORGANIZATION>Central Bank</ORGANIZATION> spokesman said he could not confirm or deny the report .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Banespa</ORGANIZATION> has been under central bank special temporary administration since December 1994 .</S>
<S>The central bank management could be lifted if <LOCATION>Sao Paulo</LOCATION> state decided to take part in the recent federal government's plan to restructure state banks .</S>
<S>Under the plan , the federal government would provide 100 percent of the financing needed to restructure debt of state banks being privatized , liquidated or turned into development banks .</S>
<S>It also offers to refinance up to 50 percent of the debt held by state banks whose governments decide to keep control of their banks .</S>
<S>Although the plan was designed under terms proposed by <LOCATION>Sao Paulo</LOCATION> state governor <PERSON>Mario Covas</PERSON> , he has showed no interest in taking part in the plan because <LOCATION>Sao Paulo</LOCATION>'s debt with <ORGANIZATION>Banespa</ORGANIZATION> has increased sharply , <ORGANIZATION>O Globo</ORGANIZATION> said .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Sao Paulo</LOCATION> state's debt is now estimated at 19 billion reais .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>O Globo</ORGANIZATION> also said another delicate case to be solved involves private bank <ORGANIZATION>Bamerindus</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>The newspaper said <ORGANIZATION>Bamerindus</ORGANIZATION> has sent to the <ORGANIZATION>Central Bank</ORGANIZATION> a proposal for restructuring combined with a request for a 90-day credit line , paying four percent a year plus the Basic Interest Rate of the <ORGANIZATION>Central Bank</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>TBC</ORGANIZATION> ) .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>O Globo</ORGANIZATION> also said the loan would give <ORGANIZATION>Bamerindus</ORGANIZATION> time to sell assets .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Bamerindus</ORGANIZATION> , <LOCATION>Brazil</LOCATION>'s fourth-largest private bank , has been facing liquidity troubles .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Bamerindus</ORGANIZATION> declined to comment on negotiations being held with the <ORGANIZATION>Central Bank</ORGANIZATION> .</S>

<S>Former Argentine benevolent dictator <PERSON>Alejandro Lanusse</PERSON> dies .</S>
<S><LOCATION>BUENOS AIRES</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S><PERSON>Alejandro Lanusse</PERSON> , the former dictator who ruled <LOCATION>Argentina</LOCATION> for two years , died at age 78 on Monday .</S>
<S><PERSON>Lanusse</PERSON> died after being brought to a hospital a week ago following a fall at home that resulted in a blood clot in the brain .</S>
<S>He was operated on earlier in the week but failed to recover from surgery .</S>
<S>The former dictator , who ruled from 1971 to 1973 , was best known for allowing <PERSON>Juan Domingo Peron</PERSON> , <LOCATION>Argentina</LOCATION>'s famed populist leader , to return to <LOCATION>Argentina</LOCATION> after 17 years of forced exile .</S>
<S><PERSON>Lanusse</PERSON> took over the leadership of the country after five years of dictatorship .</S>
<S>But unlike his two predecessors , <PERSON>Juan Carlos</PERSON> Ongania and <PERSON>Marcelo Levingston</PERSON> , who ruled <LOCATION>Argentina</LOCATION> with an iron hand , <PERSON>Lanusse</PERSON> steered the country toward democracy .</S>
<S>That resulted in general elections in March 1973 when the <ORGANIZATION>Peronists</ORGANIZATION> led by <PERSON>Hector Campora</PERSON> and <PERSON>Vicente Solano Lima</PERSON> returned to power .</S>
<S><PERSON>Lanusse</PERSON> was a candidate in the election but failed to defeat his old adversories and never returned to public office .</S>
<S>He was imprisoned for four years in 1951 for taking part in a coup attempt to overthrow <PERSON>Peron</PERSON> led by General <PERSON>Benjamin Menendez</PERSON> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Lanusse</PERSON>'s rule saw the gradual rise of left-wing activism which culminated in another period of brutal Argentine dictatorship from 1976 to 1983 , during which the military launched its " dirty war " that resulted in 10,000 missing people .</S>
<S>In his autobiography published in 1990 , <PERSON>Lanusse</PERSON> described himself as a military man with " democratic ideas . "</S>
<S>He was born in <LOCATION>Buenos Aires</LOCATION> in 1918 and married <PERSON>Ileana Bell</PERSON> with whom he had nine children .</S>
<S>He entered the <ORGANIZATION>Military College</ORGANIZATION> in 1935 .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S>" The <ORGANIZATION>United Nations</ORGANIZATION> would like to employ hundreds of foreign monitors .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Baghdad</LOCATION> says it can only accept a few dozens , " said the diplomat .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Baghdad</LOCATION> holds that the Iraq-U.N. memorandum of understanding on partial oil sales signed last June does not specify how many foreign observers should be stationed in <LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" Observation of food supplies and their distribution are still a major issue and seems the two sides have not yet filled the gap separating them , " said another diplomat .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION>'s partial oil sales pact with <ORGANIZATION>U.N.</ORGANIZATION> , allowing crude exports worth $ 2 billion every six months , gives <ORGANIZATION>U.N.</ORGANIZATION> the right to supervise the purchase and distribution of food supplies in the country .</S>
<S>The deal is a humanitarian exception to the <ORGANIZATION>U.N.</ORGANIZATION> sanctions imposed on <LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION> for invading <LOCATION>Kuwait</LOCATION> in 1990 which include a ban on its oil exports .</S>
<S><PERSON>Fulcheri</PERSON> declined comment on the differences between the <ORGANIZATION>U.N.</ORGANIZATION> and <LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION> , saying only : " There are several different things which still need to be done . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Fulcheri</PERSON> started his <ORGANIZATION>U.N.</ORGANIZATION> career in 1960 and has long experience in <ORGANIZATION>U.N.</ORGANIZATION> emergency relief in <LOCATION>Congo</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Angola</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Sudan</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Somalia</LOCATION> .</S>

<S>" There's too much nearby wheat coming into the market so we're backing off the basis to slow it down , " a <LOCATION>Montana</LOCATION> dealer said .</S>
<S>Bids there dropped 10 cents per bushel .</S>
<S>Harvest was also progressing well in parts of <LOCATION>North Dakota</LOCATION> , but one dealer there said new crop movement remained limited to a steady trickle . "</S>
<S>We're seeing some new crop coming in now but it's slow going , " the dealer said .</S>
<S>Elsewhere , basis values were mostly steady in quiet conditions with little noteworty domestic or export business , dealers said .</S>
<S>Durum bids were steady after jumping 50 cents per bushel in some areas on Monday .</S>

<S>Flour mills sold much of their production through September leaving little available for prompt shipment .</S>

<S>In the southeast <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> , dealers said feed mixers continued to be steady buyers with demand increasing for October to March positions .</S>

<S><LOCATION>PHILADELPHIA</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>A two-year old Puerto Rican girl began surgical treatment on Tuesday for a rare condition that has left half of her face covered with a hairy , dark-brown patch of skin .</S>
<S>The girl , <PERSON>Abyss DeJesus</PERSON> , suffers from a " hairy nevus " on the right side of her face , a condition that has only been reported a few times in medical journals , the <LOCATION>St. Christopher Children's Hospital</LOCATION> said .</S>
<S>In addition to social ostracism , the condition also carries a high risk of cancer .</S>
<S>It will be corrected by gradually expanding healthy skin with a surgical balloon , then transplanting that skin to the afflicted side of her face .</S>
<S>" She is doing well , " hospital spokeswoman <PERSON>Carol Norris</PERSON> said . "</S>
<S>The surgery is under way . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Norris</PERSON> said Tuesday's surgery involved placing five balloons in <PERSON>DeJesus</PERSON>'s forehead , shoulders and the back of her neck and partially filling them with a saline solution .</S>
<S>More saline solution will be inserted in 16 weekly treatments .</S>
<S>The girl , who was accompanied to <LOCATION>Philadelphia</LOCATION> by her parents , will need more surgery later to correct the condition on her chest , back and legs , the hospital said .</S>

<S><LOCATION>BOSTON</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>Home sales across <LOCATION>Massachusetts</LOCATION> were down 2.3 percent in July , compared to a month earlier , but up 21 percent for the year , according to the <ORGANIZATION>Massachusetts Association of Realtors</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>The association said a total of 4,464 single-family homes were sold in July , compared to 4,570 in June .</S>
<S>The average selling price , $ 206,464 , was up 10.6 percent over July 1995 .</S>
<S>Condominium sales edged up 6.0 percent for July and 24.8 percent for the year , the group said , while prices for condos nudged up less than 1.0 percent to an average of $ 123,394 .</S>
<S>In July , the average rate on a 30-year fixed rate mortgage was 8.25 percent , below June's 8.32 percent but still higher than February's 7.03 percent , the report noted .</S>

<S><LOCATION>MONTPELIER</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Vt</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>At least three people were injured when an <ORGANIZATION>Amtrak</ORGANIZATION> passenger train slammed into an empty logging truck and derailed Tuesday , officials said .</S>
<S>The Vermonter , which runs between <LOCATION>St. Albans</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Vermont</LOCATION> , near the Canadian border and <LOCATION>Washington , D.C.</LOCATION> , collided with the truck at 7:51 a.m. EDT near the rural town of <LOCATION>Roxbury</LOCATION> some 15 miles southeast of the state capital <LOCATION>Montpelier</LOCATION> , <ORGANIZATION>Amtrak</ORGANIZATION> spokeswoman <PERSON>Maureen Garrity</PERSON> said .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Vermont Central Hospital</LOCATION> spokesman <PERSON>Dan Pudvah</PERSON> said two of the injured were treated there -- the truck driver , who was suffering from multiple trauma injuries , and a passenger .</S>
<S><PERSON>Pudvah</PERSON> said he understood other people with minor injuries were being treated at the scene .</S>
<S><PERSON>Garrity</PERSON> said a train conductor was also injured .</S>
<S>The train's engine and its six cars derailed but were still standing , state police said .</S>
<S>The exact number of passangers on the train was not known . "</S>
<S>We had 70 reservations for the train , but that doesn't mean there were 70 passengers aboard , " <PERSON>Garrity</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>Uninjured passengers were to be taken by bus to <LOCATION>Springfield</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Massachusetts</LOCATION> , where they will be put aboard another train to continue their journey to <LOCATION>New York City</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Washington</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Garrity</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>She said the train was travelling at 54 mph when it crashed into the truck , which was crossing the tracks onto a dirt road in the rural area bordering the <LOCATION>Northfield Mountains</LOCATION> .</S>

<S><LOCATION>PARIS</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>Prime Minister <PERSON>Alain Juppe</PERSON> on Tuesday hailed handicapped athletes who took part in <LOCATION>Atlanta</LOCATION>'s Paralympic Games as an example for gloom-stricken <LOCATION>France</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" What we hear every morning is gloom , resignation and scepticism ...</S>
<S>You are the opposite , " <PERSON>Juppe</PERSON> told a successful French team at <LOCATION>Paris</LOCATION> airport as he welcomed them back from the games which followed the July-August Olympics .</S>
<S>" If you had been struck ...</S>
<S>by the disease of scepticism , gloom and resignation , you would not be here .</S>
<S>You are a true example for the nation , " he said .</S>
<S>The French team won 95 medals in <LOCATION>Atlanta</LOCATION> , 35 of them gold .</S>
<S>Opinion polls consistently show French voters pessimistic and fed up as the economy stagnates and unemployement lingers at near-record levels .</S>

<S><LOCATION>PARIS</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>French shares ended fractionally weaker as unease about union unrest slated for the autumn and a weaker franc got the better of a slight rise on <LOCATION>Wall Street</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>The blue-chip CAC-40 index ended 2.43 points or 0.12 percent lower at 2,017.99 points after a brief foray into positive territory when the <LOCATION>New York</LOCATION> stock market opened higher .</S>
<S>The broader SBF-120 index closed 1.19 points or 0.08 percent lower at 1,421.90 points .</S>
<S>Market turnover was 3.8 billion francs , about average for the quiet August period , including 2.6 billion on the most actively traded CAC-40 shares .</S>
<S>The Socialist <ORGANIZATION>CFDT</ORGANIZATION> union warned of " tension and conflict " when <LOCATION>France</LOCATION> returns to work after the summer break and called for a drive to create up to 500,000 jobs in nine months .</S>

<S>Anxieties over the budget niggled the currency markets where the franc lost around half a centime from Monday's late European levels to 3.4211 per mark .</S>

<S>" People are morose and it's not the post-holiday period or the budget or company results that are going to lift anyone's spirits , " a broker said .</S>
<S>* <ORGANIZATION>UIC</ORGANIZATION> , part of insurer <ORGANIZATION>GAN</ORGANIZATION> , slid 12.19 percent to 55.1 francs after reporting a net attributable first-half loss of 758 million francs after the close on Monday .</S>

<DOCUMENT>
<S><PERSON>Mother Teresa</PERSON> turns 86 but still in danger .</S>
<S><PERSON>Rupam Banerjee</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>CALCUTTA</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S><PERSON>Mother Teresa</PERSON> spent her 86th birthday in a <LOCATION>Calcutta</LOCATION> hospital bed on Tuesday as tributes to the legendary missionary poured in from around the world .</S>
<S>Doctors said that later in the day they would try to wean the Nobel Peace Prize laureate from the respirator that has aided her breathing for the past six days .</S>
<S>" Her condition seems to be better , but the danger remains as long as she is on respirator , " an official at <LOCATION>Woodlands Nursing Home</LOCATION> said . "</S>
<S>She is conscious but her breathing is irregular . "</S>
<S>The revered Roman Catholic nun was admitted to the <LOCATION>Calcutta hospital</LOCATION> a week ago with high fever and severe vomiting .</S>
<S>She later suffered heart failure and was diagnosed with malaria .</S>
<S>Her fever has since abated and the heart failure has been brought under control , but her heart continues to beat irregularly , doctors said .</S>
<S>" Unless she breathes on her own , I would advise you to keep your fingers crossed , " said a doctor who was familiar with her case but not part of the six-member team treating <PERSON>Mother Teresa</PERSON> .</S>
<S>The nun's birthday prompted greetings , bouquets and prayers from around the world .</S>
<S><PERSON>Pope John Paul</PERSON> II and Israeli Foreign Minister <PERSON>David Levy</PERSON> sent her get-well messages , the <ORGANIZATION>Press Trust of India</ORGANIZATION> said .</S>
<S>" Ask for a miracle .</S>
<S>Happy Birthday to our Dearest Mother , " read a placard at the <ORGANIZATION>Shishu Bhavan</ORGANIZATION> children's home in central <LOCATION>Calcutta</LOCATION> run by <PERSON>Mother Teresa</PERSON>'s <ORGANIZATION>Missionaries of Charity</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>On Monday , both houses of <LOCATION>India</LOCATION>'s parliament wished the nation's adopted sister a happy birthday and speedy recovery from her illness .</S>
<S>Prayers continued in <LOCATION>Calcutta</LOCATION> , one of the world's poorest cities , where <PERSON>Mother Teresa</PERSON>'s <ORGANIZATION>Missionaries of Charity</ORGANIZATION> runs several homes for the poor and destitute .</S>
<S>Street children , some of them born to prostitutes , held prayers on the street . "</S>
<S>All of us know about her .</S>
<S>She is like a goddess , " said Raju , 8 , who has a mother but no father .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>The Statesman</ORGANIZATION> newspaper quoted 40-year-old <PERSON>Mangala Das</PERSON> , paralysed from her waist down and a resident of the <ORGANIZATION>Prem Dan</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>Gift of Love</ORGANIZATION> ) home for the destitute , as saying she and her friends had been praying incessantly for <PERSON>Mother Teresa</PERSON>'s recovery .</S>
<S><PERSON>Tarak Das</PERSON> , 70 , was picked up from a <LOCATION>Calcutta</LOCATION> footpath a week ago by passers-by who took pity on him and brought him to <LOCATION>Nirmal Hriday</LOCATION> ( Immaculate Home ) .</S>
<S>" I do not know who she is .</S>
<S>I have never seen her , but I can only bless her for what she has done for people like me , " <PERSON>Das</PERSON> told <ORGANIZATION>The Statesman</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Mother Teresa</PERSON>'s condition improved on Sunday as her fever abated , and on Monday she was able to scribble notes to doctors and nuns .</S>
<S>Thousands in <LOCATION>Calcutta</LOCATION> , where she founded her <ORGANIZATION>Missionaries of Charity</ORGANIZATION> religious order in 1949 , prayed for her recovery .</S>
<S>Ministers of the communist government of <LOCATION>West Bengal</LOCATION> state and people of different religions joined Catholics to pray for <PERSON>Mother Teresa</PERSON>'s recovery at <LOCATION>Mother House</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" We joined the prayer to express our solidarity with her work for the cause of the poor and downtrodden , " said <PERSON>Nanda Gopal Bhattacharya</PERSON> , a communist minister in <LOCATION>West Bengal</LOCATION> .</S>

<S>Islamists can meet in <LOCATION>London</LOCATION> , minister .</S>
<S><LOCATION>ISLAMABAD</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>British Foreign Secretary <PERSON>Malcolm Rifkind</PERSON> said on Tuesday that his government would only take action against a planned conference of Islamist groups in <LOCATION>London</LOCATION> if British law was broken .</S>
<S>" People who wish to hold conferences of course don't need to seek permission from the government in <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> , " <PERSON>Rifkind</PERSON> , in <LOCATION>Pakistan</LOCATION> for a visit , told <ORGANIZATION>Reuters</ORGANIZATION> . "</S>
<S>As long as they obey our laws then that is not something the government would normally interfere with . "</S>
<S>The Islamist conference , due to be held in <LOCATION>London</LOCATION> on September 8 , has caused concern in countries such as <LOCATION>Algeria</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Egypt</LOCATION> , which are fighting armed Islamic militants .</S>
<S>British Jewish groups have also protested because they say members of <LOCATION>Algeria</LOCATION>'s <ORGANIZATION>Islamic Salvation Front</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>FIS</ORGANIZATION> ) and the Palestinian Islamic group <ORGANIZATION>Hamas</ORGANIZATION> are on the guest list .</S>
<S><PERSON>Rifkind</PERSON> said it was for the home secretary ( interior minister ) to act by denying visas to participants if he felt there was reason to believe that they might break the law .</S>
<S>" Our policy has to be fundamentally based on respect for the rule of law and insistence that it be observed , " he said .</S>
<S><PERSON>Rifkind</PERSON> was in <LOCATION>Pakistan</LOCATION> at the start of an Asian tour that will also take him to <LOCATION>India</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Sri Lanka</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Japan</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Mongolia</LOCATION> .</S>

<S>A spokesman for <PERSON>Masood</PERSON> said he had told the <LOCATION>California</LOCATION> Republican at a meeting in northern <LOCATION>Kabul</LOCATION> that President <PERSON>Burhanuddin Rabbani</PERSON>'s government favoured talks with all Afghan factions to set up an interim government .</S>
<S>The factions should agree to appoint a transitional leader , draft a new constitution , collect heavy weapons , create a national army and hold free elections in which the transitional leader would be barred from standing , he added .</S>
<S><PERSON>Rohrabacher</PERSON> flew into <LOCATION>Bagram</LOCATION> military airbase north of <LOCATION>Kabul</LOCATION> in a <ORGANIZATION>Red Cross</ORGANIZATION> plane on Tuesday after meeting northern opposition militia leader General <PERSON>Abdul Rashid Dostum</PERSON> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Masood</PERSON>'s spokesman <PERSON>Amrollah</PERSON> ( one name ) said <PERSON>Rohrabacher</PERSON> had recently visited <LOCATION>Italy</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Saudi Arabia</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Pakistan</LOCATION> as part of a mission to promote peace in <LOCATION>Afghanistan</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" We are certainly serious more than before to find a solution to the Afghan problem and support every <ORGANIZATION>U.N.</ORGANIZATION> plan , " <PERSON>Amrollah</PERSON> quoted <PERSON>Rohrabacher</PERSON> as saying .</S>
<S>However , a spokesman for Prime Minister <PERSON>Gulbuddin Hekmatyar</PERSON> , a long-time rival of <PERSON>Masood</PERSON> , expressed concern at signs of renewed <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> interest in <LOCATION>Afghanistan</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" <LOCATION>America</LOCATION> wants to block the establishment of a strong Islamic government in <LOCATION>Afghanistan</LOCATION> and the <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> intends to neutralise the Afghan peace process initiated by the Afghans themselves , " said the spokesman , <PERSON>Hamid Ibrahimi</PERSON> .</S>
<S>" A great game has been started in <LOCATION>Afghanistan</LOCATION> as <LOCATION>America</LOCATION> feels that <LOCATION>Tehran</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Moscow</LOCATION> have got stronger in the Afghan picture -- something <LOCATION>Washington</LOCATION> wants to change , " he said .</S>
<S><PERSON>Rohrabacher</PERSON> was expected to visit neutral faction leaders in the eastern city of <LOCATION>Jalalabad</LOCATION> and meet leaders of the rebel Islamic Taleban militia in the southern city of <LOCATION>Kandahar</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>Afghan guerrilla factions have been locked in a bloody power struggle since the fall of the communist government in April 1992 .</S>
<S><PERSON>Hekmatyar</PERSON> , once <PERSON>Rabbani</PERSON>'s main rival , made a peace pact with him and rejoined the government as prime minister in June .</S>

<S><LOCATION>KATHMANDU</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S><LOCATION>Nepal</LOCATION>'s centre-right coalition government has offered to meet the country's hardline Maoist communists for talks in a bid to end an insurgency in <LOCATION>Nepal</LOCATION>'s western districts , officials said on Tuesday .</S>
<S>The Maoists oppose multi-party democracy and want to establish a communist state .</S>
<S>But the Nepali government said the insurgents must give up violence before it negotiates with them .</S>
<S>" They ( the insurgents ) should first give up their violent activities , " Home ( Interior ) Minister <PERSON>Khum Bahadur Khadga</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>About 54 people have died in Maoist insurgent activity and in police action against them since February , officials said .</S>
<S>Nepali opposition parties have accused the police of having killed more people than the insurgents .</S>
<S>Some human rights groups have criticised the government's handling of the situation .</S>
<S>In a speech in parliament on Tuesday , <PERSON>Khadga</PERSON> challenged the Maoist communists to " win the people's confidence " and win election to parliament .</S>
<S>On Monday , he had offered to talk to leaders of the <ORGANIZATION>United People's Front Nepal</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>Bhattarai</ORGANIZATION> ) , the Maoist faction which leads the insurgency .</S>
<S>" The government is ready to guarantee security of the Maoist representatives who want to take part in peaceful dialogue , " <PERSON>Khadga</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>A multi-party democracy was set up in <LOCATION>Nepal</LOCATION> six years ago , after a popular movement by the centrist <ORGANIZATION>Nepali Congress</ORGANIZATION> party jointly with the <ORGANIZATION>Communist United Marxist-Leninist</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>UML</ORGANIZATION> ) party .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Nepali Congress</ORGANIZATION> leads the three-party coalition government while the <ORGANIZATION>UML</ORGANIZATION> is the main opposition party .</S>

<S><LOCATION>Bangladesh</LOCATION> Speaker says he received death threats .</S>
<S><LOCATION>DHAKA</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>The Speaker of <LOCATION>Bangladesh</LOCATION>'s parliament , <PERSON>Humayun Rasheed Choudhury</PERSON> , said he had received death threats from anonymous callers after opposition parties threatened to boycott proceedings chaired by him .</S>
<S>He told the Bengali newspaper <ORGANIZATION>Banglabazar Patrika</ORGANIZATION> on Tuesday that such threats were possibly coming from " those who want to push the country into chaos and unrest . "</S>
<S>The callers said his life could be cut short , the newspaper said .</S>
<S>The speaker was not immediately available for comment .</S>
<S><PERSON>Choudhury</PERSON> , a former foreign minister and veteran diplomat , was appointed speaker of the 330-member parliament on July 13 , a month after general elections returned the <ORGANIZATION>Awami League</ORGANIZATION> of Prime Minister Sheikh <PERSON>Hasina</PERSON> to power after 21 years .</S>
<S><PERSON>Choudhury</PERSON> also was president of the 41st session of the <ORGANIZATION>U.N. General Assembly</ORGANIZATION> in 1986-87 .</S>
<S>Former prime minister <PERSON>Begum Khaleda Zia</PERSON> , now the opposition leader in parliament and head of the <ORGANIZATION>Bangladesh Nationalist Party</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>BNP</ORGANIZATION> ) , said her followers might boycott assemby sessions chaired by the " partisan " speaker .</S>
<S>" The ruling Awami league is making parliament ineffective and the speaker is contributing to that by not allowing the opposition MPs enough time to speak , " she told a rally in northern district of <LOCATION>Bogra</LOCATION> on Monday .</S>
<S><PERSON>Hasina</PERSON> , speaking to a group of engineers in <LOCATION>Dhaka</LOCATION> on Monday , accused the <ORGANIZATION>BNP</ORGANIZATION> of resorting to " terrorism " as part of its plan to create instability and chaos in the country .</S>
<S>" This is not desireable ...</S>
<S>and we will deal with such designs sternly , " the prime minister said .</S>

<S>The year-on-year rise was 8.2 percent to June , 1996 .</S>

<S><ORGANIZATION>Barrick Gold Corp</ORGANIZATION> said on Tuesday its takeover offer for <ORGANIZATION>Arequipa Resources Ltd</ORGANIZATION> was successful , with 93 percent of the 36.3 million shares not already owned tendered under the bid , which expired overnight .</S>
<S>" We are pleased that <ORGANIZATION>Arequipa</ORGANIZATION> shareholders ahave chosen so overwhelmingly to accept this offer .</S>
<S>We now have the opportunity to realize the potential of <ORGANIZATION>Arequipa</ORGANIZATION>'s excellent assets , " <ORGANIZATION>Barrick</ORGANIZATION> chairman and chief executive <PERSON>Peter Munk</PERSON> said in a statement .</S>
<S>The C$ 30-a-share deal means <ORGANIZATION>Barrick</ORGANIZATION> will own <ORGANIZATION>Arequipa</ORGANIZATION>'s attractive <LOCATION>Pierina</LOCATION> gold deposit in <LOCATION>Peru</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Barrick</ORGANIZATION> said details involving the allocation between <ORGANIZATION>Barrick</ORGANIZATION> shares and cash will be available shortly .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Barrick</ORGANIZATION>'s offer of C$ 30 a share or part cash , part share offer was <ORGANIZATION>Barrick</ORGANIZATION>'s second attempt to swallow the small Vancouver-based gold prospector .</S>
<S>Toronto-based <ORGANIZATION>Barrick</ORGANIZATION> , the world's third largest gold producer , sweetened its July 11 bid to C$ 30 a share from C$ 27 on August 16 after a fresh batch of drill results from the <LOCATION>Pierina</LOCATION> deposit .</S>
<S>Experts have speculated the deposit has potential reserves of up to 12 million ounces .</S>
<S>More drilling results are expected soon .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Barrick</ORGANIZATION> bid took observers by surprise , since <ORGANIZATION>Arequipa</ORGANIZATION>'s exploration was still in its early stages .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Arequipa</ORGANIZATION> shareholders had the option to choose C$ 30 cash or 0.79 <ORGANIZATION>Barrick</ORGANIZATION> shares plus 50 cents for each <ORGANIZATION>Arequipa</ORGANIZATION> share .</S>
<S>Shares were to be pro-rated if more than 14.4 million were requested .</S>

<S>They told reporters a group of <ORGANIZATION>Kurdistan Workers Party</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>PKK</ORGANIZATION> ) guerrillas stopped the buses at a roadblock on the road linking the eastern provinces of <LOCATION>Erzincan</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Sivas</LOCATION> on Monday night and forced the passengers to get out .</S>
<S>The rebels killed one of the drivers and a passenger after checking the identities of the passengers , they said .</S>
<S>The officials said the rebels set ablaze two buses and released all but three passengers .</S>

<S><LOCATION>CHICAGO</LOCATION> 1996-08-26</S>
<S><PERSON>Sarah Brady</PERSON> , whose Republican husband was severely disabled in an assassination attempt on President <PERSON>Ronald Reagan</PERSON> , took centre stage at the Democratic National convention on Monday night to praise President <PERSON>Bill Clinton</PERSON>'s gun control efforts .</S>
<S>With her husband <PERSON>James</PERSON> sitting in a wheelchair to the side of the podium , Mrs. <PERSON>Brady</PERSON> called the handgun control bill that a Democratic <ORGANIZATION>Congress</ORGANIZATION> passed and <PERSON>Clinton</PERSON> signed in 1994 a major step in controlling firearm violence in the <LOCATION>United States</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>But she said more had to be done .</S>
<S>The <PERSON>Bradys</PERSON> walked on to the stage , he on her arm and with the aid of a cane , to a rousing reception from the convention .</S>
<S>Their teenaged son sat in a VIP box with first lady <PERSON>Hillary Rodham Clinton</PERSON> and watched as his father returned to his wheelchair .</S>
<S>" <PERSON>Jim</PERSON> , we must have made a wrong turn .</S>
<S>This isn't <LOCATION>San Diego</LOCATION> ( site of the Republican convention ) , " Mrs. <PERSON>Brady</PERSON> joked to her husband , who was serving as <PERSON>Reagan</PERSON>'s press secretary when he was shot .</S>
<S>" <PERSON>Sarah</PERSON> , I told you this is the Democratic convention , " he responded to his wife , who before the shooting had worked for two Republican congressmen and the Republican national party .</S>
<S>" Since the Brady Law went into effect on February 28 , 1994 ( it ) has stopped more than 100,000 convicted felons and other prohibited purchasers from buying a handgun .</S>
<S>Today , and every day , the Brady Law is stopping an estimated 85 felons from buying a handgun , " Mrs. <PERSON>Brady</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>She added , " But we need to do more .</S>
<S>We should , as President <PERSON>Clinton</PERSON> proposed today , stop people convicted of domestic violence from buying a handgun .</S>
<S><PERSON>Jim</PERSON> and I join with you tonight in saluting the great job that President <PERSON>Clinton</PERSON> has done in fighting crime and gun violence . "</S>
<S>" He's a hunter and a sportsman , but he understands the difference between a Remington rifle and an AK47 .</S>
<S>And he knows that you don't go hunting with an Uzi .</S>
<S>Mr. President you deserve our thanks . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Jim Brady</PERSON> then gave a big thumbs to the audience .</S>
<S><PERSON>Brady</PERSON></S>
<S>was shot in the head in 1981 by gunman <PERSON>John Hinckley</PERSON> , who tried to kill <PERSON>Reagan</PERSON> in a deranged bid to impress <PERSON>Jodie Foster</PERSON> , an actress he never met but with whom he was obsessed .</S>
<S>The <PERSON>Brady</PERSON> bill , calling for a waiting period before someone could buy a gun so a background check could be made , was first introduced in <ORGANIZATION>Congress</ORGANIZATION> in 1987 but it took seven years to pass because of opposition from the <ORGANIZATION>National Rifle Association</ORGANIZATION> gun lobby .</S>

<S>A hijacked <ORGANIZATION>Sudan Airways</ORGANIZATION> plane carrying 199 passengers and crew landed at <LOCATION>Stansted</LOCATION> airport just outside <LOCATION>London</LOCATION> early on Tuesday morning after flying from <LOCATION>Cyprus</LOCATION> , eyewitnesses said .</S>
<S>The Airbus 310 Flight 150 , which was hijacked on Monday evening on its way from <LOCATION>Khartoum</LOCATION> to the Jordanian capital <LOCATION>Amman</LOCATION> , landed at 4.30 a.m. ( 0330 GMT ) after a flight of more than four hours .</S>
<S>At least one of the unidentified hijackers was apparently armed with grenades and TNT and threatened to blow the plane up in <LOCATION>Cyprus</LOCATION> unless it was refuelled so they could fly to <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> to claim political asylum .</S>
<S>" They will surrender the passengers there and surrender themselves , " police spokesman <PERSON>Glafcos Xenos</PERSON> told reporters at <LOCATION>Cyprus</LOCATION>'s <LOCATION>Larnaca</LOCATION> airport .</S>
<S>Security was tight at <LOCATION>Stansted</LOCATION> airport , which is about 30 miles ( 50 km ) northeast of the capital .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Stansted</LOCATION> has been designated as the preferred option for handling hijackings in southern <LOCATION>England</LOCATION> because it is more remote than <LOCATION>Heathrow</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Gatwick</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>London</LOCATION>'s two major airports , and handles less air traffic .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>

<S><LOCATION>LONDON</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>A hijacked <ORGANIZATION>Sudan Airways</ORGANIZATION> plane with 199 passengers and crew on board was expected to land at <LOCATION>London</LOCATION>'s <LOCATION>Stansted</LOCATION> airport later on Tuesday morning , a police spokeswoman said .</S>
<S>" That is the plan at the moment .</S>
<S>That is where the plane is being directed to , " <PERSON>Ruth Collin</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Essex</LOCATION> police , the force responsible for <LOCATION>Stansted</LOCATION> , said .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Stansted</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>London</LOCATION>'s third-busiest airport after <LOCATION>Heathrow</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Gatwick</LOCATION> , is located about 30 miles ( 48 km ) northeast of the capital .</S>
<S>British officials said they would much prefer to deal with a hijacking at <LOCATION>Stansted</LOCATION> because of its relatively remote location and because air traffic would be less badly disrupted there than at <LOCATION>Heathrow</LOCATION> or <LOCATION>Gatwick</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>They said police and the emergency services were implementing a well-rehearsed contingency plan to handle the hijacking .</S>
<S>The armed hijackers of the Airbus 310 Flight 150 , which is expected to arrive about 4 a.m. ( 0300 GMT ) , have said they intend to surrender and seek political asylum in <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> .</S>

<S>Painted parrot scam lands Australian in jail .</S>
<S><LOCATION>PERTH</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Australia</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S>A conman who painted common Australian parrots with dye to make them look like rare birds worth thousands of dollars was jailed for fraud on Tuesday .</S>
<S><PERSON>Denham Peiris</PERSON> painted six green parrots , worth about A$ 100 ( US$ 79 ) a pair , with a cinnamon hair dye and traded them as Indian Ringneck Parrots , valued at A$ 14,000 a pair .</S>
<S><PERSON>Peiris</PERSON> , 32 , of <LOCATION>Perth</LOCATION> , was sentenced in the Western Australian District Court to two years in jail for fraud after trading three pairs of impostor birds for 21 parrots worth a total of A$ 28,000 .</S>
<S>" Everyone was fooled , " said pet shop owner <PERSON>Shane Drew</PERSON> , who unknowingly traded the disguised birds .</S>
<S>" I'd already had three local breeders have a look at them and sent photos and videos of the birds to the eastern states for authentication -- they said they're nice birds , " <PERSON>Drew</PERSON> told reporters outside court .</S>
<S>" After I was told they were dyed , I checked them over again .</S>
<S>It was a perfect paint job except for one feather under a wing of one bird that was only half dyed , " <PERSON>Drew</PERSON> said .</S>
<S><PERSON>Drew</PERSON> said <PERSON>Peiris</PERSON> , a bird enthusiast , would have succeeded with the fraud if he had not tried to trade a fourth pair of bogus birds after an associate had told police of the scam .</S>
<S>If not for the informant , the painted parrots ' true colours would not have been known for six months , he said .</S>
<S>" They moult in the summer , so five or six months down the track , I would have looked like the guilty party , " <PERSON>Drew</PERSON> said .</S>

<S><LOCATION>BEIJING</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S><LOCATION>China</LOCATION> on Tuesday reaffirmed its support for a global nuclear test ban treaty blocked by <LOCATION>India</LOCATION> last week , saying the pact would be an important step in achieving total nuclear disarmament .</S>
<S>" Although the final draft of the treaty probably didn't totally satisfy any country , it was in general balanced , " the official <ORGANIZATION>People's Daily</ORGANIZATION> newspaper said in a commentary .</S>
<S><LOCATION>India</LOCATION> blocked the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty ( CTBT ) at the Conference on Disarmament in <LOCATION>Geneva</LOCATION> , saying the pact did not contain a clause committing the five declared nuclear powers to a timetable for nuclear disarmament .</S>
<S><LOCATION>New Delhi</LOCATION>'s stance , which was seen as effectively thwarting 2-1/2 years of negotiations at the Conference on Disarmament , drew widespread but generally muted foreign criticism .</S>
<S><LOCATION>India</LOCATION> has also pledged to oppose any forwarding of the draft treaty to the <ORGANIZATION>United Nations General Assembly</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><LOCATION>China</LOCATION> said many countries had compromised to complete the treaty and that the issue of a disarmament schedule could be discussed in future negotiations .</S>
<S>" The completion of the test ban treaty would be an important and practical step in the gradual process of achieving total nuclear disarmament , " it said .</S>
<S><LOCATION>China</LOCATION> has pledged support for the pact since reaching a deal with the <LOCATION>United States</LOCATION> that made international inspections of nuclear sites more difficult than in earlier drafts of the accord .</S>
<S>The newspaper said <LOCATION>China</LOCATION> advocated the complete ban and destruction of nuclear weapons but that there was little hope other nuclear powers would soon adopt the same stance .</S>
<S>" Some nuclear powers stubbornly uphold policies of nuclear deterrence based on first use of nuclear weapons , " it said .</S>
<S><LOCATION>China</LOCATION> held on July 29 what it said would be its last nuclear test before a self-imposed moratorium that took effect the following day .</S>
<S><LOCATION>China</LOCATION> was the last declared nuclear power to announce a halt to testing .</S>
