<S><LOCATION>Costa Rica</LOCATION> says Dutch pair kidnapped by Nicaraguans .</S>
<S><LOCATION>SAN JOSE</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Costa Rica</LOCATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S>The Costa Rican government said on Wednesday that a Dutch couple abducted over the weekend from a tree farm in northern <LOCATION>Costa Rica</LOCATION> was kidnapped by former Nicaraguan guerrillas .</S>
<S>" Even though it's an act of common delinquency , the case could take a difficult turn because former Nicaraguan guerrillas are involved , " Security Minister <PERSON>Bernardo Arce</PERSON> told reporters .</S>
<S>Earlier this year , a German tourist and a Swiss tour guide were kidnapped from the same general area in northern <LOCATION>Costa Rica</LOCATION> near the Nicaraguan border .</S>
<S>They were held for 71 days before relatives paid a ransom to free them .</S>
<S>Two Nicaraguan former guerrillas have been arrested in the case .</S>
<S>Because of the apparent threat to foreigners in <LOCATION>Costa Rica</LOCATION> near the Nicaraguan border , <PERSON>Arce</PERSON> said the government has advised many to take additional security measures on their own .</S>
<S><PERSON>Hurte Sierd Zylstra</PERSON> and his wife , <PERSON>Jetsi Hendrika Coers</PERSON> , both 50 years old , were seized late on Saturday or early on Sunday from a teak tree plantation they manage by at least two heavily armed men who took the two off in their own car , leaving behind a ransom note demanding $ 1.5 million .</S>
<S>The plantation is owned by Dutch citizen <PERSON>Ebe Huizinga</PERSON> , who has since arrived in <LOCATION>Costa Rica</LOCATION> to deal with the matter .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>Gov't dodging extradition , Colombian official says .</S>
<S><LOCATION>BOGOTA</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Colombia</LOCATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S>A top judicial official and critic of President <PERSON>Ernesto Samper</PERSON> accused the government of indifference on Wednesday over efforts to lift <LOCATION>Colombia</LOCATION>'s five-year-old ban on extradition .</S>
<S>" It would seem that the subject of extradition is unworthy of an opinion from the government , " Deputy Prosecutor-General <PERSON>Adolfo</PERSON> <LOCATION>Salamanca</LOCATION> said .</S>
<S>Constitutional reforms were proposed on Tuesday by two senators , one of them a member of <PERSON>Samper</PERSON>'s own <ORGANIZATION>Liberal Party</ORGANIZATION> , aimed at lifting the ban on extradition introduced in 1991 .</S>
<S><LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> Ambassador <PERSON>Myles Frechette</PERSON> applauded the move , saying it could prompt the <PERSON>Clinton</PERSON> administration to remove <LOCATION>Colombia</LOCATION> from a list of outcast nations that have failed to cooperate in <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> counternarcotics efforts .</S>
<S><PERSON>Samper</PERSON> -- who weathered a year-old crisis stemming from charges he financed his 1994 election campaign with drug money -- appeared less than enthusiastic , however .</S>
<S>" Extradition is not on the government's legislative agenda , " he told reporters on Tuesday .</S>
<S>He added that he did not oppose the idea of opening a public debate over the issue .</S>
<S>But he fell far short of endorsing the idea of putting Colombian drug lords onto U.S.-bound flights to serve stiff penalities in American prisons .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Salamanca</LOCATION> , who spoke at a meeting on kidnapping in <LOCATION>Colombia</LOCATION> , has said in the past that there was ample evidence to prove that <PERSON>Samper</PERSON>'s campaign received millions of dollars in contributions from the country's top drug lords .</S>

<S><LOCATION>SAN JOSE</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Costa Rica</LOCATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S>A moderate earthquake measuring 5.0 on the <PERSON>Richter</PERSON> scale shook <LOCATION>Costa Rica</LOCATION> on Wednesday during a visit by Japanese Prime Minister <PERSON>Ryutaro Hashimoto</PERSON> , but there were no reports of casualties or damage , officials said .</S>
<S>The quake struck at 11.16 a.m. ( 1716 GMT ) and was centred 10 miles ( 16 km ) south of the port of <LOCATION>Quepos</LOCATION> , which is 90 miles ( 140 km ) south of the capital <LOCATION>San Jose</LOCATION> , the <ORGANIZATION>Costa Rican Volcanic and Seismologicial Observatory</ORGANIZATION> said .</S>
<S>The quake was felt for about seven seconds in most of the country but preliminary reports said no one was hurt , it added .</S>
<S>The quake took place a few minutes before the end of a welcoming ceremony at <LOCATION>Juan Santamaria</LOCATION> airport for <PERSON>Hashimoto</PERSON> , who was starting a three-hour visit as part of a Latin American tour .</S>
<S><PERSON>Hashimoto</PERSON> , who arrived at 11 a.m. ( 1700 GMT ) , showed no sign of having felt the quake , witnesses said .</S>

<S>Police said <PERSON>James Lee Williams</PERSON> , 28 , was stopped at a <LOCATION>Bangkok</LOCATION> airport departure lounge on Monday after officials found the drug in a bag that <PERSON>Williams</PERSON> planned to carry onto the plane .</S>
<S><PERSON>Williams</PERSON> ' hometown was not immediately available .</S>

<S><LOCATION>RAMALLAH</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>West Bank</LOCATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Palestinian Legislative Council</ORGANIZATION> on Wednesday called for a halt to contacts with <LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION> , just hours after President <PERSON>Yasser Arafat</PERSON> said the Jewish state had effectively declared war on the Palestinians by pursuing its hardline policies .</S>
<S>A resolution released by the council called for " halting contacts with the Israeli side and leaving the mechanism to carry out this to Palestinian President <PERSON>Yasser Arafat</PERSON> " .</S>
<S>The council was meeting in <LOCATION>Ramallah</LOCATION> to discuss <LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION>'s new policy of Jewish settlement expansion and its uncompromising line on <LOCATION>Jerusalem</LOCATION> since Prime Minister <PERSON>Benjamin Netanyahu</PERSON> took office in June .</S>
<S>Council resolutions are not necessarily binding .</S>
<S><PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> had earlier blasted <LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION> saying its policies amounted to a declaration of war against the Palestinian people .</S>
<S>He also called for the first general strike in two years in the <LOCATION>West Bank</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Gaza</LOCATION> on Thursday .</S>
<S>" What happened concerning continuous violations and crimes from this new Israeli leadership means they are declaring a state of war against the Palestinian people , " <PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> told the council .</S>
<S>Council speaker <PERSON>Ahmed Korei</PERSON> said the decision was part of a comprehensive plan to confront Israeli settlement policy , land confiscation and what he termed other violations of the Israeli-PLO peace deals .</S>

<S>Iraqi Kurd group says agrees new ceasefire .</S>
<S><LOCATION>ANKARA</LOCATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S>An Iraqi Kurdish group on Wednesday said it had agreed a new U.S.-brokered ceasefire with a rival faction after a previous accord was shattered by sporadic fighting between the groups in recent days .</S>
<S>" The <ORGANIZATION>Patriotic Union of Kurdistan</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>PUK</ORGANIZATION> ) leadership declares its endorsement for a ceasefire arrangement with the <ORGANIZATION>KDP</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>Kurdistan Democratic Party</ORGANIZATION> ) to take effect as of 8:00 a.m. on August 28 , " the <ORGANIZATION>PUK</ORGANIZATION> said in a statement .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>PUK</ORGANIZATION> said the ceasefire was agreed after talks between <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> Assistant Secretary for <LOCATION>Near East</LOCATION> Affairs <PERSON>Robert Pelletreau</PERSON> and <ORGANIZATION>PUK</ORGANIZATION> leader <PERSON>Jalal Talabani</PERSON> .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>KDP</ORGANIZATION> , led by <PERSON>Massoud Barzani</PERSON> , had said a previous ceasefire negotiated by <PERSON>Pelletreau</PERSON> last Friday was broken by the <ORGANIZATION>PUK</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Talabani</PERSON> has agreed to take part in talks in <LOCATION>London</LOCATION> on reaching a comprehensive settlement for the PUK-KDP conflict , the <ORGANIZATION>PUK</ORGANIZATION> statement said .</S>
<S>It said the <ORGANIZATION>KDP</ORGANIZATION> was responsible for breaking the previous ceasefire by refusing to endorse it publicly .</S>

<S>Kurd group says Iraqi troops massing near north .</S>
<S><LOCATION>ANKARA</LOCATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S>An Iraqi Kurdish group on Wednesday said <LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION> was massing troops near Kurdish regions in the north , where a U.S.-led allied air force protects the local population against attacks from <LOCATION>Baghdad</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" The Iraqi regime has started threatening the Kurdish population by massing troops in preparation to attack Kurdish towns and population centres , " the <ORGANIZATION>Patriotic Union of Kurdistan</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>PUK</ORGANIZATION> ) said in a statement .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>PUK</ORGANIZATION> said it had received confirmed reports that Iraqi troops , supported by tanks , artillery and armoured vehicles , have already penetrated some Kurdish areas .</S>
<S>It said the military presence reflects cooperation between President <PERSON>Saddam Hussein</PERSON> and the <ORGANIZATION>PUK</ORGANIZATION>'s rival , the <ORGANIZATION>Kurdistan Democratic Party</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>KDP</ORGANIZATION> ) .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>PUK</ORGANIZATION> statement follows <ORGANIZATION>KDP</ORGANIZATION> assertions that the <ORGANIZATION>PUK</ORGANIZATION> is receiving military support from <LOCATION>Iran</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>Hostilities between the two warring Iraqi Kurdish factions have continued in the last few days despite a U.S.-brokered ceasefire last Friday .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>PUK</ORGANIZATION> called on the <ORGANIZATION>United Nations</ORGANIZATION> and allied forces to halt the Iraqi aggression .</S>
<S><LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> , French and British aircraft have safeguarded the Iraqi Kurdish population against aggression from <LOCATION>Baghdad</LOCATION> since shortly after the Gulf War in 1991 .</S>
<S>The allied force , known as Operation Provide Comfort , is based in southern <LOCATION>Turkey</LOCATION> .</S>

<S><LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION> says hijackers were not diplomats .</S>
<S><LOCATION>BAGHDAD</LOCATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S><LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION> on Wednesday said the hijackers of a Sudanese airliner were not Iraqi diplomats and added that " noble Iraqis " would never contemplate such an action .</S>
<S>The official <ORGANIZATION>Iraqi News Agency</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>INA</ORGANIZATION> ) quoted <LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION>'s ambassador in <LOCATION>Khartoum</LOCATION> as saying that <LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION>'s embassy in the Sudanese capital had nothing to do with the Monday night hijacking .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION>'s ambassador in <LOCATION>Khartoum</LOCATION> denounced the hijacking and described it as a terrorist act which had nothing to do " with the morals and values of noble Iraqis , " <ORGANIZATION>INA</ORGANIZATION> said .</S>
<S>Ambassador <PERSON>Abdulsamad Hameed Ali</PERSON> told <ORGANIZATION>INA</ORGANIZATION> there was only one diplomat among the 199 passengers and crew on the <ORGANIZATION>Sudan Airways</ORGANIZATION> Airbus .</S>
<S>" He was not involved ...</S>
<S>on the contrary he was harassed by the elements which carried out the hijacking , " he said .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>INA</ORGANIZATION> did not say the hijackers were Iraqis .</S>
<S>The hijack started when the flight left <LOCATION>Khartoum</LOCATION> for <LOCATION>Amman</LOCATION> on Monday night .</S>
<S>The hijackers told the crew they had grenades and other explosives and threatened to blow up the plane if they were not taken to <LOCATION>London</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>The airliner refuelled at <LOCATION>Larnaca</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Cyprus</LOCATION> and landed at <LOCATION>London</LOCATION>'s <LOCATION>Stansted</LOCATION> airport in the early hours of Tuesday .</S>
<S>Seven Iraqi suspected hijackers surrendered and British police said they had apparently asked for political asylum .</S>
<S>Several had brought their families along , including children .</S>

<DOCUMENT>
<S><PERSON>Dole</PERSON> blasts <PERSON>Clinton</PERSON> for ignoring teen drug use .</S>
<S><PERSON>Judith Crosson</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>VENTURA</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Calif.</LOCATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S>Republican presidential candidate <PERSON>Bob Dole</PERSON> Wednesday accused the <PERSON>Clinton</PERSON> administration of ignoring drug use among teenagers and said if elected he would use the <ORGANIZATION>National Guard</ORGANIZATION> to stop drugs from entering the <LOCATION>United States</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" He'll probably mention his war on drugs , which he's going to start like everything else -- next year .</S>
<S>It's too late , Mr. President , " <PERSON>Dole</PERSON> told an outdoor crowd of several hundred at a private religious school .</S>
<S>He also commented briefly on published reports that the administration was planning to announce a plan to lower capital gains taxes for home sales . "</S>
<S>Welcome to the club .</S>
<S>We've had it out there for weeks and weeks and weeks , " <PERSON>Dole</PERSON> said .</S>
<S><PERSON>Dole</PERSON> said former first lady <PERSON>Nancy Reagan</PERSON> was laughed at with her " just say no " anti-drug message . "</S>
<S>But it worked , " <PERSON>Dole</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>Meanwhile , in <LOCATION>Los Angeles</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Dole</PERSON>'s running mate , <PERSON>Jack Kemp</PERSON> , campaigned aggressively for the black vote in an area that was the flashpoint of the 1992 <LOCATION>Los Angeles</LOCATION> riots .</S>
<S><PERSON>Kemp</PERSON> told a crowd of about 300 African Americans in south central <LOCATION>Los Angeles</LOCATION> , " Keep your eyes open , keep your ears open , keep your heart open .</S>
<S>I want to tell you with all my heart that we want to win your vote . "</S>
<S>In <PERSON>Dole</PERSON>'s address to a group that was largely white , the presidential nominee likened the stream of illegal drugs into the <LOCATION>United States</LOCATION> to missiles aimed at American children and promised to appoint federal judges who would be tough on illegal drug use .</S>
<S>" They're aiming millions and millions of missiles right at these young people , whether it's a needle , whether it's a cigarette , whatever the delivery system is -- it's poison and it's got to stop in <LOCATION>America</LOCATION> . "</S>
<S>he said .</S>
<S><PERSON>Dole</PERSON> said 70 percent of the cocaine that entered the <LOCATION>United States</LOCATION> and 40 percent of the marijuana came from <LOCATION>Mexico</LOCATION> . "</S>
<S>We've got an international problem and I'm prepared to use our military might .</S>
<S>We want to stop drugs at the border , " he said .</S>
<S><PERSON>Dole</PERSON>'s remarks prompted questions about whether he was seeking a ban on cigarettes . "</S>
<S>I didn't say anything about cigarettes .</S>
<S>I was talking about drugs .</S>
<S>I said you shouldn't smoke either .</S>
<S>That's all I said , " he replied as he was shaking hands with well-wishers .</S>
<S>When asked specifically if he was suggesting a ban on cigarettes , <PERSON>Dole</PERSON> replied : " Oh no .</S>
<S>Come on , you know better than that . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Dole</PERSON> campaign aides said the candidate was telling young people not to smoke .</S>
<S><PERSON>Dole</PERSON> also said he opposed California Proposition 215 which , if approved by voters , would allow the cultivation of marijuana plants for medicinal uses .</S>
<S><PERSON>Dole</PERSON> said the initiative would allow marijuana to be used for anything from a headache to an ingrown toenail .</S>
<S>In an effort to paint the drug issue in non-political terms , <PERSON>Dole</PERSON> said three times during his 20-minute address that illegal drug use was neither a Democratic nor a Republican issue but one that involves all people .</S>
<S>The anti-drug message is a theme <PERSON>Dole</PERSON> feels has strong voter appeal .</S>
<S>On Sunday near <LOCATION>Chicago</LOCATION> he accused President <PERSON>Bill Clinton</PERSON> of " raising the white flag " in the war on drugs .</S>
<S>A recent survey showed that illegal drug use among 12-17 year-olds had doubled in the past four years .</S>
<S><PERSON>Dole</PERSON> was flanked by several <LOCATION>California</LOCATION> Republican politicians including Gov .</S>
<S><PERSON>Pete Wilson</PERSON> , who said local and state governments cannot fight illegal drugs alone .</S>
<S>" We need all the help we can get .</S>
<S>We need to get the kind of help we used to get when <PERSON>Ronald Reagan</PERSON> and <PERSON>George Bush</PERSON> were in the <LOCATION>White House</LOCATION> , " <PERSON>Wilson</PERSON> said .</S>

<S><ORGANIZATION>CME</ORGANIZATION> lumber futures close lower on profit taking .</S>
<S><LOCATION>CHICAGO</LOCATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S>Profit taking continued to weigh on <ORGANIZATION>CME</ORGANIZATION> lumber futures but prices ended only slightly lower as strong cash markets underpinned futures , traders said .</S>
<S>The same pattern of the past few days persisted with futures declining early on the profit taking before firming late .</S>
<S>There was cash-related buying late from people who want to take delivery of the September contract , they said .</S>
<S>Cash sources noted that although the cash market is generally quiet , prices remain firm on demand for prompt delivery wood , they added .</S>
<S>Random Lengths quoted cash spruce at $ 419 per tbf , up $ 5 from last Friday and $ 7 over the last midweek quote .</S>
<S>Reduced concern over Hurricane Edouard prompted some of the early profit taking .</S>
<S>Expectations the storm would turn more to the north partly eased concerns , they said .</S>
<S>Lumber closed $ 2.20 to $ 0.20 per tbf lower with September off $ 0.70 at $ 413.20 and November off most at $ 369.00 per tbf .</S>
<S>-- <PERSON>Jerry Bieszk</PERSON> 312-408-8725</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>WHEAT--Rains boost <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> HRW planting prospects .</S>
<S><PERSON>Greg Frost</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>KANSAS CITY</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Mo</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>Above-normal summer rainfall in the <LOCATION>U.S. High Plains</LOCATION> has produced near-ideal conditions for planting the 1997 hard red winter wheat crop , analysts said Wednesday .</S>
<S>From central <LOCATION>Texas</LOCATION> north to <LOCATION>Kansas</LOCATION> , rains throughout July and August have relieved most of the drought conditions that plagued the region earlier this year .</S>
<S>" Our moisture situation is excellent , especially for fall planting of winter wheat , " said <PERSON>Kim Anderson</PERSON> , extension wheat marketing economist at <ORGANIZATION>Oklahoma State University</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>The irony of the above-average summer rainfall was not lost on <LOCATION>High Plains</LOCATION> wheat producers , who only three months ago were caught in a drought so severe that old-timers likened conditions to the " Dust Bowl " days of the 1930s .</S>
<S>" It's definitely a turnabout from this past year , but you know last year we had pretty good moisture about this time of year , and then about October 1 it quit , " said <PERSON>Mark Hodges</PERSON> , executive director of the <ORGANIZATION>Oklahoma Wheat Commission</ORGANIZATION> . "</S>
<S>Hopefully that's not going to happen this year . "</S>
<S>According to figures released by the Oklahoma Climatological Survey , an average of 20.19 inches fell across the state between March 1 and August 26 , 1996 .</S>
<S>That's about 1/2 inch above the average for the same time period , according to <PERSON>Howard Johnson</PERSON> , associate state climatologist at the <ORGANIZATION>University of Oklahoma</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>He noted that the majority of that 20.19 inches had fallen since July .</S>
<S>As an example of just how dry it was , data showed that between October 1 , 1995 and March 1 , 1996 , the state received an average of only 4.6 inches of rainfall .</S>
<S>In northern <LOCATION>Texas</LOCATION> , the current rainfall situation was similar to most of <LOCATION>Oklahoma</LOCATION> , said <PERSON>Rodney Mosier</PERSON> , executive assistant for the <ORGANIZATION>Texas Wheat Producers</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>" Up here in the <LOCATION>Texas Panhandle</LOCATION> , we've had some extremely beneficial rains that came through within the last several days and are really setting us up for ideal conditions for planting wheat , " <PERSON>Mosier</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>But he warned that the situation was not as ideal in central and southern <LOCATION>Texas</LOCATION> , where mositure levels were still short despite the rains brought by Hurricane Dolly last week .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Kansas</LOCATION> , typically the number one <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> hard red winter wheat producer , topsoil moisture levels were rated mostly adequate during the week ended Sunday , according to the state's agricultural statistics service .</S>
<S>In its weekly report released Monday , the service said <LOCATION>Kansas</LOCATION> topsoil moisture was rated eight percent surplus , 77 percent adequate and 15 percent short to very short .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Oklahoma</LOCATION>'s <ORGANIZATION>Agricultural Statistics Service</ORGANIZATION> showed similar conditions , rating topsoil moisture levels as seven percent surplus , 81 percent adequate and 12 percent short to very short .</S>
<S>Data on topsoil moisture ratings were not released by the <ORGANIZATION>Texas Agricultural Statistics Service</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>-- <PERSON>Greg Frost</PERSON> , 816 561-8671</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S><ORGANIZATION>First Union National Bank of Fla.</ORGANIZATION> settles suit .</S>
<S><LOCATION>JACKSONVILLE</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Fla.</LOCATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>First Union National Bank of Florida</ORGANIZATION> said on Wednesday it agreed to settle a class action law suit involving its collateral protection insurance ( CPI ) program .</S>
<S>To provide for the settlements , <ORGANIZATION>First Union</ORGANIZATION> has established a common fund of $ 4.7 million for cash refunds and $ 19.4 million in credit refunds for outstanding CPI balances .</S>
<S>The bank is a division of <ORGANIZATION>First Union Corp</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>The bank said most of the charges resulted from loan portfolios from banks and thrifts that were acquired in the 1980s .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>First Union</ORGANIZATION> said it has discontinued CPI as an element of its motor vehicle or boat installment loan contracts .</S>
<S>As part of the settlement agreement , customers who had CPI placed on loans from January 1 , 1986 to September 31 , 1996 , will receive cash or credit refunds , the bank said .</S>
<S>Cash refunds will go to those who paid their loans to <ORGANIZATION>First Union</ORGANIZATION> while credit refunds will go to those who have existing loan balances , the bank said .</S>

<S><LOCATION>Burundi</LOCATION> defends military regime to hostile <ORGANIZATION>UN</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Evelyn Leopold</PERSON></S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>UNITED NATIONS</ORGANIZATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S><LOCATION>Burundi</LOCATION>'s ambassador on Wednesday lashed out at economic sanctions imposed by African states and said any thought of an arms embargo would be a windfall for guerrillas fighting his army-run government .</S>
<S>In a lengthy debate on <LOCATION>Burundi</LOCATION> before the <ORGANIZATION>U.N. Security Council</ORGANIZATION> , Ambassador <PERSON>Nsanze Terence</PERSON> said the new military government took over to stabilise the country and wanted negotiations under former Tanzanian President <PERSON>Julius Nyrere</PERSON> .</S>
<S>Nearly every African member who spoke , as well as most <ORGANIZATION>Security Council</ORGANIZATION> members , however , were unsympathetic towards the government of President <PERSON>Pierre Buyoya</PERSON> , an army major put in power in a July coup by the Tutsi-run military , which is locked in a guerrilla war with the majority Hutus .</S>
<S>" These ( African ) brothers should have been the first to bind the wounds of <LOCATION>Burundi</LOCATION> , " <PERSON>Terence</PERSON> said of the economic embargo . "</S>
<S>Quite the contrary , <LOCATION>Burundi</LOCATION> has seen economic war declared against it by fellow African people ... a gratuitous immolation of the people of <LOCATION>Burundi</LOCATION> . "</S>
<S>He said his government had just asked <ORGANIZATION>U.N.</ORGANIZATION> human rights monitors to increase their numbers in <LOCATION>Burundi</LOCATION> in an effort " to put an end to this vicious circle of violence . "</S>
<S>More than 150,000 people have been killed in violence between the minority Tutsis and the majority Hutus since 1993 .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Botswana</LOCATION>'s envoy , <PERSON>Mothusi Nkgowe</PERSON> , said coups should be relegated " to the dump heap of history " as there could be no justification for the overthrow of a legitimate government .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Chile</LOCATION> has proposed a resolution , still under discussion , that would impose an immediate arms embargo on <LOCATION>Burundi</LOCATION> and call for negotiations .</S>
<S>The draft suggests further sanctions against those who impede a political solution .</S>
<S>Among the council's five permanent members , <LOCATION>Russia</LOCATION> and the <LOCATION>United States</LOCATION> appeared to support most elements of the Chilean proposal , while <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>France</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>China</LOCATION> were cautious .</S>
<S><PERSON>Terence</PERSON> , a Tutsi , said any arms embargo would leave the army unable to defend itself against Hutu guerrillas and leave the population exposed to " armed terroritsts . "</S>
<S>But Chilean Ambassador <PERSON>Juan Somavia</PERSON> said : " Every weapon that reached <LOCATION>Burundi</LOCATION> is a weapon aimed mainly at killing an unarmed civilian .</S>
<S>We must not send a signal different from the African leaders themselves .</S>
<S>Inaction is becoming the worst possible course of action . "</S>
<S><LOCATION>Burundi</LOCATION>'s parliament has been suspended and political parties are banned but <PERSON>Terence</PERSON> told reporters <PERSON>Buyoya</PERSON> would reconvene a new type of national assembly in October .</S>
<S>The <LOCATION>United States</LOCATION> said the coup leaders had taken no steps to restore democracy and indiscriminate killings continued .</S>
<S>Ambassador <PERSON>Karl Inderfurth</PERSON> said the new government should have " unconditional " negotiations with all parties inside and outside of the country .</S>
<S>He said <LOCATION>Washington</LOCATION> strongly supported the economic sanctions imposed already and if these did not work the council would consider " an arms embargo or targeted sanctions against faction leaders . "</S>
<S>But he said the international community had to be prepared for the worst and avoid a replay of the horrors in neighbouring <LOCATION>Rwanda</LOCATION> , where widespread genocide broke out against the Tutsis two years ago .</S>
<S>He again said the <ORGANIZATION>United Nations</ORGANIZATION> should draw up contingency plans for a rapid humanitarian intervention .</S>

<S>" The industry saw capacity expansion of about 13 percent over 1994/95 from 77.79 million tonnes to 87.45 million tonnes , " <PERSON>Palkhivala</PERSON> told shareholders .</S>
<S>He said Indian cement exports dropped about eight percent from the previous year because of stiff international competition and inadequate infrastructural facilities .</S>

<S>Despite power shortages , <ORGANIZATION>ACC</ORGANIZATION> achieved a satisfactory growth in production during the year with the help of its power plants .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>ACC</ORGANIZATION> sold 9.4 million tonnes in 1995/96 , retaining its top position in the Indian cement industry , <PERSON>Palkhivala</PERSON> said .</S>

<S>The <ORGANIZATION>LTTE</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam</ORGANIZATION> ) accosts us and , at the point of a gun , forces us to take refugees , " said senior fishermen leader <PERSON>P. Arulanandam</PERSON> .</S>
<S>Some 850 refugees have landed in recent weeks at the port of <LOCATION>Rameswaram</LOCATION> in the southern Indian state of <LOCATION>Tamil Nadu</LOCATION> , home to 50 million Tamil-speaking people , port officials say .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Rameswaram</LOCATION> is 15 km ( 10 miles ) off the coast of <LOCATION>Sri Lanka</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>State chief minister <PERSON>M. Karunanidhi</PERSON> has publicly welcomed the refugees , who are fleeing the 13-year war between Tamil separatists and government troops that <LOCATION>Colombo</LOCATION> says has cost 50,000 lives .</S>
<S>But the influx has triggered fears of a repeat of the 1980s when some 200,000 refugees landed in <LOCATION>Tamil Nadu</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>Intelligence officals said more than 5,000 Tamils were waiting on the western coast of <LOCATION>Sri Lanka</LOCATION> to cross into <LOCATION>India</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>The Indian government has warned its fishermen that their boats would be impounded if they were caught ferrying refugees .</S>
<S>The fishermen went on strike last week to protest the government's cancellation of three trawlers ' fishing licenses after the boats were caught carrying Tamil refugees .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>All Fishermen's Association</ORGANIZATION> secretary <PERSON>N.J. Bose</PERSON> said the strike would continue indefinitely and the fishermen would block road and rail traffic if their demands were not met .</S>
<S>" Until the government releases our boats from naval custody and Sri Lankan naval custody , and gives us assurance ( it will not revoke licences of boats ferrying refugees ) , we will not call off our strike , " <PERSON>Bose</PERSON> said .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>LTTE</ORGANIZATION> spokesmen could not immediately be reached for comment , but Sri Lankan fishermen denied that Indians were being coerced into carrying refugees across the <LOCATION>Palk Strait</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" Indian fishermen come right up to <LOCATION>Pesalai</LOCATION> to fish , and when refugees request them to ferry them across , they readily oblige .</S>
<S>Only some take money , " Sri Lankan boatman <PERSON>Chinnathambi</PERSON> said .</S>
<S><PERSON>Arulanandam</PERSON> denied the fishermen charged the refugees for passage to <LOCATION>India</LOCATION> and said it was unfair to penalise them for the refugees ' arrival .</S>
<S>" We have not gone to sea since August 19 , but refugees are arriving daily nevertheless .</S>
<S>How could we alone be held responsible for the influx ? "</S>
<S>he said .</S>
<S>An <ORGANIZATION>Indian Fisheries Department</ORGANIZATION> official said the government planned to urge fishermen not to cross the international boundary between <LOCATION>India</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Sri Lanka</LOCATION> , but admitted this would be hard to enforce because of <LOCATION>Sri Lanka</LOCATION>'s pomfret-rich waters .</S>

<S><PERSON>Peter Griffiths</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>LONDON</LOCATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S>A firm start on <LOCATION>Wall Street</LOCATION> helped push leading <LOCATION>London</LOCATION> shares to a new record high on Wednesday and German stocks closed floor trading up but the <LOCATION>Paris</LOCATION> bourse slipped sharply , hit by a weakening franc and fears of industrial unrest .</S>
<S>On the foreign exchange markets , a survey indicating weaker than expected Japanese business sentiment boosted the dollar in early trading but it failed to build on its gains against the yen and slipped lower against the mark in quiet afternoon trade .</S>
<S><LOCATION>London</LOCATION> shares , boosted by <LOCATION>Wall Street</LOCATION> , added to early gains with the blue chip FTSE 100 index hitting a new peak of 3921.8 before dropping back slightly .</S>
<S>One focus was <ORGANIZATION>British Airways</ORGANIZATION> , which rebounded after fears faded that the cancellation of " open skies " talks between the <ORGANIZATION>U.S. Transportation Department</ORGANIZATION> and the British government may jeopardise its tie-up with <ORGANIZATION>American Airlines</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>The conclusion of an open skies agreement had been made a prerequisite of the proposed link-up by the <LOCATION>U.S</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>Better-than-expected British trade figures had little impact on equities .</S>
<S>The non-EU July trade deficit totalled 506 million sterling ( $ 788 million ) while June's world deficit was 1.12 billion pounds .</S>
<S>Forecasts were for deficits of 900 million sterling and 1.4 billion sterling .</S>
<S>German shares shed some gains on profit-taking but nonetheless ended the floor session higher buoyed by demand for chemical stocks and a stable dollar .</S>
<S>The 30-share DAX index closed at 2,563.16 points , up 4.32 .</S>
<S>However , French stocks extended opening losses to more than one percent in morning trading , falling through the 2000 point resistance level on the main CAC-40 index .</S>
<S>Dealers blamed a weakening franc and worries about the 1997 budget and possible autumn strikes</S>
<S><PERSON>Louis Viannet</PERSON> , leader of <LOCATION>France</LOCATION>'s Communist-led <ORGANIZATION>CGT</ORGANIZATION> union , criticised government plans for spending cuts in the 1997 budget on Wednesday and warned of labour unrest as <LOCATION>France</LOCATION> gets back to work after the holidays .</S>
<S>Later in the day , helped by the firmer <LOCATION>Wall Street</LOCATION> opening , <LOCATION>Paris</LOCATION> climbed back to the 2000 level but still remained well into negative territory .</S>
<S>In foreign exchange the dollar was trading at around 108.40 yen in the European afternoon , up from its European close on Tuesday of 107.55 but off the day's highs .</S>
<S>It had been boosted overnight by the <ORGANIZATION>Bank of Japan</ORGANIZATION>'s quarterly corporate survey , or " tankan " , of major manufacturers -- an important gauge of business sentiment .</S>
<S>The unexpectedly weak figures convinced markets that Japanese interest rates would stay at rock-bottom levels -- weakening the yen .</S>
<S>The Japanese discount rate is currently at a record low of 0.5 percent .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>BOJ</ORGANIZATION> sought to put the best face on the data which defied economists ' predictions of improving sentiment and was the first decline in business sentiment in a year .</S>
<S>A <ORGANIZATION>BOJ</ORGANIZATION> spokesman said " the doors to the recovery have not been shut ...</S>
<S>the recovery is still continuing . "</S>
<S>These remarks gave the yen some backbone and the dollar failed to progress further .</S>
<S>" The dollar's gains were less than spectacular , suggesting that while it's likely to benefit from revised Japanese rate expectations , a breakout from the established trading range doesn't appear likely , " said currency economist <PERSON>Klaus Baader</PERSON> .</S>
<S>Dealers said shares were also affected by a slippage in bond prices due to lower than expected June industrial production , showing the economy was still faltering .</S>
<S>CURRENCIES AT 1500 GMT</S>
<S>The dollar was at 108.40 yen and 1.4765 marks compared with Tuesday's European close of 107.78 yen and 1.4779 marks</S>
<S>STOCK MARKETS AT 1500 GMT</S>
<S>The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading British shares had risen 15 points to 3,920.7 .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Paris</LOCATION> , the CAC-40 share index dropped 15.09 to 2,002.9 .</S>
<S>The 30-share DAX index in <LOCATION>Frankfurt</LOCATION> closed up 4.32 at 2,563.16 .</S>
<S>PRECIOUS METALS</S>
<S>Gold fixed at $ 388.50 versus Tuesday's <LOCATION>London</LOCATION> close of $ 388.55 .</S>
<S>Silver was at 521.15 cents .</S>
<S>( $ 1=.6421 Sterling )</S>

<S><PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> says <LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION> declares war on Palestinians .</S>
<S><PERSON>Wafa Amr</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>RAMALLAH</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>West Bank</LOCATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S>Palestinian President <PERSON>Yasser Arafat</PERSON> said on Wednesday that <LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION> had declared war on the Palestinians and called for the first general strike in the <LOCATION>West Bank</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Gaza</LOCATION> in two years .</S>
<S>" What happened concerning continuous violations and crimes from this new Israeli leadership means they are declaring a state of war against the Palestinian people , " <PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> told the Palestinian legislature .</S>
<S>Accusing Israeli Prime Minister <PERSON>Benjamin Netanyahu</PERSON> of stupidity , <PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> launched his strongest attack on the right-wing government since its election in May .</S>
<S>The tirade was sparked by <LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION>'s announcement on Tuesday of plans to expand the Jewish settlement of <LOCATION>Kiryat Sefer</LOCATION> and its demolishing of a community centre in <LOCATION>Arab East Jerusalem</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" <LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION> has started the war on <LOCATION>Jerusalem</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>They are idiots to have started the <LOCATION>Jerusalem</LOCATION> battle , " <PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> said in Arabic . "</S>
<S>There will be no Palestinian state without <LOCATION>Jerusalem</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Netanyahu</PERSON> should know he is stupid to have started this battle . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> called for a general strike " for <LOCATION>Jerusalem</LOCATION> " on Thursday in all of the <LOCATION>West Bank</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Gaza Strip</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>There has not been a joint shutdown there since May 1994 when Israeli troops began withdrawing under an interim self-rule agreement signed in 1993 .</S>
<S>The strike will have little effect on the Israeli economy while hurting Palestinian merchants in <LOCATION>East Jerusalem</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Bethlehem</LOCATION> who cater to the tourist trade .</S>
<S>Some 25,000 Palestinian labourers are likely to stay away from their jobs , mainly in construction , in <LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>But Palestinians , once the backbone of the building industry , have been largely replaced by labourers from <LOCATION>Romania</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>China</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" On Friday , all Moslems , including Palestinians in <LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION> ...</S>
<S>will go to ( <LOCATION>Jerusalem</LOCATION>'s ) <LOCATION>Al-Aqsa</LOCATION> mosque and pray .</S>
<S>Jews and Christians who do not pray should accompany them and stand behind them , " <PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>Officials in <PERSON>Netanyahu</PERSON>'s office were not immediately available for comment on <PERSON>Arafat</PERSON>'s remarks .</S>
<S>Israeli travel restrictions , imposed after bombings by Moslem militants in February and March , ban most of the two million Arabs in the <LOCATION>West Bank</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Gaza</LOCATION> from entering <LOCATION>Jerusalem</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Netanyahu</PERSON> , who opposes trading occupied land for peace , made <LOCATION>Jerusalem</LOCATION> a central issue in his election campaign , accusing <ORGANIZATION>Labour</ORGANIZATION> Prime Minister <PERSON>Shimon Peres</PERSON> of planning to hand control of the Arab eastern part of the city to the Palestinians .</S>
<S><LOCATION>Israel</LOCATION> captured <LOCATION>East Jerusalem</LOCATION> in the 1967 <LOCATION>Middle East</LOCATION> war and claims both halves of the city as its capital .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>PLO</ORGANIZATION> wants <LOCATION>East Jerusalem</LOCATION> as the capital of a future Palestinian state .</S>
<S>In his speech to the crowded legislature , <PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> signalled he was not abandoning diplomacy although " alarm bells are ringing " .</S>
<S>He unexpectedly broke off his address to take a telephone call from <LOCATION>U.S. Middle East</LOCATION> envoy <PERSON>Dennis Ross</PERSON> , who held talks in <LOCATION>Paris</LOCATION> on Tuesday with Israeli and Egyptian officials .</S>
<S>When <PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> returned to the podium , he said senior <ORGANIZATION>PLO</ORGANIZATION> negotiator <PERSON>Mahmoud Abbas</PERSON> , better known as <PERSON>Abu Mazen</PERSON> , and <PERSON>Netanyahu</PERSON> aide <PERSON>Dore Gold</PERSON> could meet on Thursday .</S>

<S><PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> said he replied : " is this like their previous promises ? "</S>
<S>" No , they have good intentions , " <PERSON>Arafat</PERSON> quoted <PERSON>Ross</PERSON> as saying .</S>

<S><LOCATION>US</LOCATION> investors mull appeal of <ORGANIZATION>Lloyd's</ORGANIZATION> decision .</S>
<S><PERSON>Patricia Vowinkel</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>NEW YORK</LOCATION> 1996-08-27</S>
<S><LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> investors in troubled <ORGANIZATION>Lloyd's of London</ORGANIZATION> were considering late on Tuesday whether to appeal a <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> court decision in favour of <ORGANIZATION>Lloyd's</ORGANIZATION> and pledged to continue pursuing other legal actions .</S>
<S>A <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> appeals court on Tuesday gave <ORGANIZATION>Lloyd's</ORGANIZATION> a reprieve , throwing out an injunction that the insurance giant said could have led to its collapse .</S>
<S>A lower court issued the injunction on Friday and ordered <ORGANIZATION>Lloyd's</ORGANIZATION> to give investors , known as Names , more information before requiring them to decide whether to accept a settlement offer as part of a reorganisation plan .</S>
<S>" My prediction is that the Names will appeal , " said <PERSON>Kenneth Chiate</PERSON> , a <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> Name and a chief negotiator for the <ORGANIZATION>American Names Association</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>" At this point , it is a sufficiently important decision that I'm confident that they will appeal , " he said . "</S>
<S>But to say that they definitely will would be premature until we determine what the exact basis for the court's ruling is . "</S>
<S>Under the reorganisation plan , <ORGANIZATION>Lloyd's</ORGANIZATION> plans to reinsure its massive liabilities into a new company called <ORGANIZATION>Equitas</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>The arrangement calls for investors to make additional payments to fund <ORGANIZATION>Equitas</ORGANIZATION> but also provides them with 3.2 billion stg in compensation to help reduce their prior outstanding liabilities .</S>
<S>The Names had been scheduled to decide whether to accept or reject the offer by 1100 GMT Wednesday , but <ORGANIZATION>Lloyd's</ORGANIZATION> chairman <PERSON>David Rowland</PERSON> said on Tuesday the offer would be extended .</S>
<S>At least eight <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> states have still some form of litigation pending , said <PERSON>John Head</PERSON> , spokesman for the <ORGANIZATION>Association of Lloyd's</ORGANIZATION> State Chairmen , a group representing <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> Names .</S>
<S>" It goes without saying that we're rather disappointed , " <PERSON>Head</PERSON> said of the decision by the <ORGANIZATION>U.S. Court of Appeals</ORGANIZATION> for the <ORGANIZATION>Fourth Circuit</ORGANIZATION> , sitting in <LOCATION>Baltimore</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>But , he said , " we still have hope that somebody is going to see our point of view in this . "</S>
<S>The <LOCATION>Colorado</LOCATION> attorney general told <ORGANIZATION>Lloyd's</ORGANIZATION> last week it was considering a new legal action against the British insurance market , based on allegations of consumer fraud .</S>
<S>" We have notified them of our concerns and asked them to give us a response , " said <LOCATION>Colorado</LOCATION> attorney general <PERSON>Gale Norton</PERSON> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Norton</PERSON> said she was concerned that the <ORGANIZATION>Lloyd's</ORGANIZATION> agreement immunizes it from future litigation regarding <ORGANIZATION>Equitas</ORGANIZATION> and requires that all legal actions be heard outside of <LOCATION>Colorado</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>In addition , she said she was concerned the plan may not offer investors enough protection from additional , future liabilities .</S>
<S>Meanwhile , an appeal of a lawsuit filed by some 600 Names in <LOCATION>California</LOCATION> is still pending before the <ORGANIZATION>U.S. Court of Appeals</ORGANIZATION> for the <ORGANIZATION>Ninth Circuit</ORGANIZATION> , <PERSON>Chiate</PERSON> of the <ORGANIZATION>American Names Association</ORGANIZATION> said .</S>
<S>That lawsuit , which seeks rescision and restitution , was dismissed in a <LOCATION>U.S.</LOCATION> district court .</S>
<S>That case " is what I call the most significant alternate remedy for us , " <PERSON>Chiate</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>The individual Names , however , now must decide whether to accept <ORGANIZATION>Lloyd's</ORGANIZATION> settlement offer or reject the offer and pursue litigation .</S>
<S><PERSON>Chiate</PERSON> said he has advised Names that " they must make , individually , a risk benefit analysis . "</S>
<S>Rejection involved forfeiting the compensation offer and risking the possibility of owing <ORGANIZATION>Lloyd's</ORGANIZATION> two to three times more than <ORGANIZATION>Lloyd's</ORGANIZATION> is now willing to accept , he said .</S>
<S>But , in rejecting the offer , the Names would retain their rights to pursue litigation , he said .</S>

<S>German prosecutors file sex tourism charges .</S>
<S><LOCATION>BERLIN</LOCATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S><LOCATION>Berlin</LOCATION> prosecutors said on Wednesday they had filed charges against two German men for sexually abusing children in <LOCATION>Thailand</LOCATION> and distributing pornographic films and pictures of their degrading acts .</S>
<S>The case is one of only a handful in which authorities have managed to track down suspects under a law which lets them pursue Germans who commit sex offences abroad .</S>
<S>The pair , identified only as 43-year-old clerk <PERSON>Dieter U</PERSON> and businessman <PERSON>Thomas S</PERSON> , 33 , are alleged to have carried out acts of sexual indecency with children as young as 10 years old between 1994 and 1995 .</S>
<S>Their videos included pictures of one of the accused tying up a Thai boy and performing acts of sadistic torture on him , prosecutors said in a statement .</S>
<S>In another scene , a young girl performed oral sex with an unidentified adult man .</S>
<S>The new law was introduced with much fanfare in 1993 .</S>
<S>But prosecutors face huge difficulties in gathering evidence and bringing witnesses to testify in a German court , and only one person has so far been convicted under the law .</S>
<S>Investigators are probing several other cases .</S>
<S>The <LOCATION>Berlin</LOCATION> prosecutors said they had been alerted to the two men by customs officials who intercepted packages containing pornographic photographs and order forms .</S>

<S><LOCATION>ROME</LOCATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S>Two Italian magazines published pictures on Wednesday of <PERSON>Daniel Ducruet</PERSON> , Princess <PERSON>Stephanie</PERSON> of <LOCATION>Monaco</LOCATION>'s husband and former bodyguard , cavorting naked with another woman by a poolside in <LOCATION>France</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>The magazines , <ORGANIZATION>Eva Tremila</ORGANIZATION> and its sister publication <ORGANIZATION>Gente</ORGANIZATION> , printed up to 26 pages of photos of the woman undressing <PERSON>Ducruet</PERSON> , the pair embracing on a sunbed and finally both naked .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>Eva Tremila</ORGANIZATION> said other even more explicit photos were taken but it did not print them .</S>
<S>The magazines named the woman as <PERSON>Fili Houteman</PERSON> , a 26-year-old French singer and dancer in a Belgian cabaret club .</S>
<S>The photographs , an Italian exclusive , raised eyebrows in the tiny principality , where <PERSON>Stephanie</PERSON>'s father <PERSON>Prince Rainier</PERSON> , had long disapproved of his daughter's choice of husband .</S>
<S><PERSON>Stephanie</PERSON> had two children with <PERSON>Ducruet</PERSON> before their marriage in July last year .</S>
<S><PERSON>Stephanie</PERSON> , <PERSON>Caroline</PERSON> and <PERSON>Albert</PERSON> are the children of <PERSON>Rainier</PERSON> and former <LOCATION>Hollywood</LOCATION> screen goddess <PERSON>Grace Kelly</PERSON> , who was killed in a car crash in 1982 .</S>

<S>The magazines said the photographs were taken in <LOCATION>Cap de Villefranche</LOCATION> , some 15 km ( nine miles ) from <LOCATION>Monte Carlo</LOCATION> .</S>

<S>Spanish tomato warriors paint the town red .</S>
<S><LOCATION>BUNOL</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Spain</LOCATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S>Revellers painted the town red on Wednesday as the 1996 edition of the world's biggest tomato fight began in the eastern Spanish village of <LOCATION>Bunol</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>Thousands of people pelted each other with armfuls of ripe tomatoes as streets , walls and windows were coated in a blood-red wash .</S>
<S>A single firework after midday signalled the start of the fruit-throwing frenzy , during which participants hurl some 100 tonnes of tomatoes trucked in for the occasion .</S>
<S>Local historians say the tradition began in 1945 when disgruntled locals began spontaneously to bombard the priest and mayor at the annual fiesta in <LOCATION>Bunol</LOCATION> ( pronounced <LOCATION>Boo-nee-OL</LOCATION> ) .</S>
<S>The festival's fame has grown and now attracts between 15,000 and 20,000 people , many of them foreigners .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S><LOCATION>NZ</LOCATION> bills gain ground after see-saw session .</S>
<S><LOCATION>WELLINGTON</LOCATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S>0515 GMT</S>
<S>The <LOCATION>New Zealand</LOCATION> money market gained slightly at Wednesday's close after what dealers described as a see-saw trading session .</S>
<S>Ninety-day bank bill rates shed five points to 9.93 percent and September bank bill futures rose four to 90.18 .</S>
<S>However , bonds finished largely flat .</S>
<S>" Our bonds were better bid initially but they sold off on a lack of demand , and the short end went with it too on a lower currency .</S>
<S>" There were big buyers at the base of where the market sold to , and when the currency got bought back on talk of a samurai the market got bought back again , " a dealer said .</S>
<S>Volumes were reasonable in the money market but thin in bonds .</S>
<S>Dealers said the market seemed to be trading a range and would wait for more political polls to provide direction .</S>
<S>They were confident of further eurokiwi issuance but said the timing was less of a certainty .</S>

<S>" We have not had any sightings , but we suspect he is armed , possibly with a .22 rifle and / or a self-loading shotgun .</S>
<S>He is considered extremely dangerous , " he said .</S>
<S>" It's a possibility , not a probability , he may take a hostage , but we have measures in place if that is the case . "</S>

<S>All three wounded are in a satisfactory condition in hospital .</S>

<S><PERSON>Fox</PERSON> is a skilled bushman who knows the area very well , police said .</S>
<S>About 60 police , helicopters and fixed-wing aircraft have maintained an overnight cordon around 15 sq km ( six sq miles ) of bush near <LOCATION>Glenwood</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>The area is littered with caves and police believed <PERSON>Fox</PERSON> has a hideout which has enabled him to evade capture .</S>

<S><LOCATION>Japan</LOCATION>'s Finance Minister <PERSON>Wataru Kubo</PERSON> told a news conference on Wednesday that he believes that the <ORGANIZATION>Bank of Japan</ORGANIZATION>'s ( <ORGANIZATION>BOJ</ORGANIZATION> ) interest rate policy which is geared towards ensuring economic growth has not changed after the release of the central bank's " tankan " survey .</S>

<S>The <ORGANIZATION>BOJ</ORGANIZATION> governor has made it clear that the <ORGANIZATION>BOJ</ORGANIZATION>'s policy is aimed at ensuring basis for economic recovery .</S>
<S>I believe this policy has not changed , " he said .</S>

<S>The economy is not recovering smoothly or at a fast pace . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Kubo</PERSON> said he would make a decision on the need for a supplementary budget after an announcement in mid-September of <LOCATION>Japan</LOCATION>'s gross domestic product for the April-June quarter .</S>

<S><LOCATION>Japan</LOCATION> coalition party leader plans to resign .</S>
<S><LOCATION>TOKYO</LOCATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S>The leader of a junior partner in <LOCATION>Japan</LOCATION>'s three-party ruling coalition plans to resign to quell a political rebellion , party officials said on Wednesday .</S>
<S>The officials said <ORGANIZATION>New Party Sakigake</ORGANIZATION> President <PERSON>Masayoshi Takemura</PERSON> , finance minister until the beginning of this year , promised his resignation in a meeting with the politician who set off the rebellion in the smallest coalition member .</S>
<S>They said the date of <PERSON>Takemura</PERSON>'s resignation would be determined by party officials .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>Sakigake</ORGANIZATION> row has caused jitters in its coalition partners , Prime Minister <PERSON>Ryutaro Hashimoto</PERSON>'s <ORGANIZATION>Liberal Democratic Party</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>LDP</ORGANIZATION> ) , the biggest grouping , and the <ORGANIZATION>Social Democratic Party</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>But analysts said the row was not expected to immediately destabilise the government as even if <ORGANIZATION>Sakigake</ORGANIZATION> splits apart it has so few seats a loss of support would not lead to a general election .</S>
<S>The dispute pits <PERSON>Takemura</PERSON> , who founded <ORGANIZATION>Sakigake</ORGANIZATION> in 1993 as a reform-oriented <ORGANIZATION>LDP</ORGANIZATION> splinter group , against party official <PERSON>Yukio Hatoyama</PERSON> , who says he will leave <ORGANIZATION>Sakigake</ORGANIZATION> to form a reformist political group next month .</S>
<S><PERSON>Hatoyama</PERSON> , the 49-year-old grandson of a 1950s prime minister , on Tuesday quit as <ORGANIZATION>Sakigake</ORGANIZATION> secretary general and has publicly snubbed the 62-year-old <PERSON>Takemura</PERSON> , pointedly ruling his mentor out as a possible member of the new political force .</S>
<S>Marathon talks between the two former allies on Tuesday night and Wednesday morning failed to resolve the dispute over the role of <PERSON>Takemura</PERSON> , seen by <PERSON>Hatoyama</PERSON> backers as tainted by his senior role in the LDP-dominated coalition .</S>
<S>The presence of <PERSON>Takemura</PERSON> , whose role as finance minister in passing an unpopular plan to use taxpayer funds to wind up failed housing loan firms ruined his reputation as a reformer , has stalled <PERSON>Hatoyama</PERSON>'s efforts to attract to his new group defectors from the opposition camp , analysts said .</S>
<S>Media reports say that at most 10 of 23 <ORGANIZATION>Sakigake</ORGANIZATION> members , joined by a handful of Social Democrats , will follow <PERSON>Hatoyama</PERSON> when he bolts -- far short of the 50 lawmakers needed to topple <PERSON>Hashimoto</PERSON>'s eight-month-old government .</S>
<S><PERSON>Hashimoto</PERSON> -- who returns from a 10-day Latin American tour on Saturday -- must call polls by mid-1997 , and has repeatedly said he would not call an early general election .</S>
<S>But many analysts and politicians believe he may dissolve parliament soon after it reconvenes in early October .</S>

<S>An <ORGANIZATION>ISS</ORGANIZATION> statement said that <ORGANIZATION>Aaxis</ORGANIZATION> , with year-end 1996 assets of US$ 10.9 million and equity of $ 10.5 million , would be listed on the <LOCATION>Montreal</LOCATION> stock exchange , but did not say when .</S>

<S>On August 15 , <ORGANIZATION>ISS</ORGANIZATION> published first half 1996 results showing a two billion crown loss caused by falsified accounts in <ORGANIZATION>ISS Inc</ORGANIZATION> and said that charges and provisions earlier estimated at $ 100 million would have to be increased to $ 146 million .</S>

<DOCUMENT>
<S><LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION> balks at <ORGANIZATION>U.N.</ORGANIZATION> staff for oil-for-food deal .</S>
<S><PERSON>Evelyn Leopold</PERSON></S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>UNITED NATIONS</ORGANIZATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S><LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION> has balked at the number of <ORGANIZATION>U.N.</ORGANIZATION> staff needed to implement the oil-for-food deal , blaming the <LOCATION>United States</LOCATION> for insisting on stringent monitoring .</S>
<S>In comments to reporters and a statement on Tuesday , Iraqi diplomats said the cost of the monitors and other staff , which <LOCATION>Baghdad</LOCATION> has to finance , surpasses funds allocated for electricity , water , sewers , education and agriculture .</S>
<S>At issue was a May 20 agreement allowing <LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION> to sell $ 2 billion worth of oil to purchase badly needed food , medicine and other supplies to ease the impact of sanctions in force since its troops invaded <LOCATION>Kuwait</LOCATION> in August 1990 .</S>
<S>The Iraqi statement said the <LOCATION>United States</LOCATION> was " interfering and pressing to augment the number of international staff and this is not legal and not justified . "</S>
<S><LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION>'s deputy ambassador , <PERSON>Saeed Hasan</PERSON> , noted that the May 20 accord said that the number of personnel would be determined by the <ORGANIZATION>United Nations</ORGANIZATION> and that the government of <LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION> would be consulted .</S>
<S><PERSON>Saeed</PERSON> in his comments did not threaten to call off the deal and the <ORGANIZATION>U.N.</ORGANIZATION> officials said they expected it to go into force next month after Secretary-General <PERSON>Boutros Boutros-Ghali</PERSON> reports that arrangements are in place .</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>U.N. Department of Humanitarian Affairs</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>DHA</ORGANIZATION> ) , which has to coordinate the distribution of food , medicine and other goods , increased the number of monitors earlier this month at the insistence of the <LOCATION>United States</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>According to <ORGANIZATION>U.N.</ORGANIZATION> officials and diplomats , <LOCATION>Iraq</LOCATION> would have about $ 1.13 billion to spend for food , medicine and other goods after monies for a reparations fund for Gulf War victims and costs for <ORGANIZATION>U.N.</ORGANIZATION> weapons inspections were deducted .</S>
<S>The cost of the <ORGANIZATION>U.N.</ORGANIZATION> staff overseeing the distribution of food and other supplies was estimated to cost $ 31 million .</S>
<S>In addition another $ 12 million was anticipated to cover other expenses , such as oil experts and administrative costs .</S>
<S>For the distribution and supervision of humanitarian supplies the <ORGANIZATION>United Nations</ORGANIZATION> estimated it needed 1,190 people , including 267 international staff and 923 Iraqi support staff .</S>
<S>Of this number 64 foreign and 598 local staff would be in the northern Kurdish provinces , no longer the direct control of the <LOCATION>Baghdad</LOCATION> government .</S>
<S>Another 203 international staff and 325 Iraqis would run the programme in the central and southern parts of the country .</S>
<S>There are also 14 monitors to watch oil flows , 32 customs experts and four New York-based oil experts or overseers to approve contracts .</S>
<S><PERSON>Yasushi Akashi</PERSON> , the <ORGANIZATION>DHA</ORGANIZATION> undersecretary-general , told the <ORGANIZATION>Security Council</ORGANIZATION> last week that the " financial requirements to support the ( humanitarian ) programme represent a very modest percentile of the total ...</S>
<S>roughly 3 percent . "</S>

<DOCUMENT>
<S><ORGANIZATION>EU Commission</ORGANIZATION> cool on changing beef cull plan .</S>
<S><LOCATION>BRUSSELS</LOCATION> 1996-08-29</S>
<S>The <ORGANIZATION>European Commission</ORGANIZATION> said on Thursday it would study scientific reports saying <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION>'s mad cow epidemic would die out by 2001 but offered little prospect the findings would change an agreed slaughter campaign .</S>
<S>" Obviously we are interested in this research .</S>
<S>We will ask the ( <ORGANIZATION>EU</ORGANIZATION> ) scientific and veterinary committee to examine it , " <ORGANIZATION>Commission</ORGANIZATION> spokesman <PERSON>Gerard Kiely</PERSON> told <ORGANIZATION>Reuters</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>But he added that new research into the dynamics of the bovine spongiform encephalopathy ( BSE ) , a fatal brain-wasting disease suffered by cattle , was unlikely to alter a slaughter plan agreed by <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> and its 14 <ORGANIZATION>EU</ORGANIZATION> partners .</S>
<S>" We agreed that following detailed scientific analysis using a methodology which would take out the maximum number of BSE cases possible .</S>
<S>I think it would be very difficult to sell to the <ORGANIZATION>European Commission</ORGANIZATION> a programme which would involve the elimination of fewer BSE cases , " <PERSON>Kiely</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>" We will look at our approach ( to the plan ) but we won't get involved with the number of animals to be slaughtered , " he said .</S>
<S>" We have always avoided the question of numbers of animals to be slaughtered , that's not the issue .</S>
<S>The issue is the protection of consumers ' health and the rapid eradication of BSE , " he added .</S>
<S>The reaction is likely to disappoint British farmers , who seized on research by <ORGANIZATION>Oxford</ORGANIZATION> scientists in the scientific journal <ORGANIZATION>Nature</ORGANIZATION> saying it would be hard to get rid of the disease any faster than 2001 without killing vast numbers of cattle .</S>
<S>The researchers predicted there would be 340 new infections and 14,000 new cases of BSE before 2001 .</S>
<S>British farmers ' leader called on Wednesday for an urgent meeting with ministers to discuss the report .</S>
<S>" I hope the government will now make it clear they believe there is a better way of dealing with this issue , " <ORGANIZATION>National Farmers Union</ORGANIZATION> president Sir <PERSON>David Naish</PERSON> told <ORGANIZATION>BBC radio</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Naish</PERSON> said there was no need for <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> to carry out a planned cull of some 147,000 cattle to which it had reluctantly agreed to placate its European partners .</S>
<S>" The new evidence to me means some of that proposal should be re-examined because we could get away with considerably less animals being culled if in fact scientists throughout <LOCATION>Europe</LOCATION> accepted this evidence , " <PERSON>Naish</PERSON> said .</S>
<S>The report could well reopen a damaging row between <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> and the <ORGANIZATION>EU</ORGANIZATION> , which slapped a worldwide ban on British beef after the government said there could be a link between BSE and the human form of the disease .</S>
<S>The issue flared in in March when government scientists admitted that people could become infected with Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease ( CJD ) from eating BSE-infected beef .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>French farmers set up blockades in mad cow protest .</S>
<S><LOCATION>PARIS</LOCATION> 1996-08-29</S>
<S>Thousands of farmers threw up roadblocks across <LOCATION>France</LOCATION> overnight , stopping and checking lorries suspected of importing meat from outside the <ORGANIZATION>European Union</ORGANIZATION> , French radios reported on Thursday .</S>
<S>Radio stations said around 15,000 farmers , angered by a fall in beef prices following the mad cow disease crisis , staged protests in many areas and blockaded several main roads and motorways .</S>
<S>By 3 a.m. ( 0100 GMT ) more than 2,000 lorries had been stopped and searched .</S>
<S>European beef sales plunged after <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> announced the discovery of a likely link between bovine spongiform encephalopathy ( BSE ) , or mad cow disease , and its fatal human equivalent Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease ( CJD ) .</S>

<S>CRICKET - <PERSON>CROFT</PERSON> RESTRICTS <LOCATION>PAKISTAN</LOCATION> TO 225-5 .</S>
<S><LOCATION>MANCHESTER</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>England</LOCATION> 1996-08-29</S>
<S>Tight bowling from <ORGANIZATION>Glamorgan</ORGANIZATION> off-spinner <PERSON>Robert Croft</PERSON> helped <LOCATION>England</LOCATION> to restrict <LOCATION>Pakistan</LOCATION> to 225 for five in their 50 overs in the first one-day international at <LOCATION>Old Trafford</LOCATION> on Thursday .</S>
<S><PERSON>Croft</PERSON> , who was one of the few Englishmen to make a good impression in his test debut at <LOCATION>The Oval</LOCATION> last week , showed great control as he first dried up the early flow of <LOCATION>Pakistan</LOCATION> runs and then collected the wickets of <PERSON>Aamir Sohail</PERSON> and <PERSON>Wasim Akram</PERSON> in a spell of 10-1-36-2 .</S>
<S>There was also a wicket each for <PERSON>Ronnie Irani</PERSON> , <PERSON>Allan Mullally</PERSON> and <PERSON>Darren Gough</PERSON> although there was no joy for <PERSON>Dean Headley</PERSON> who , along with <ORGANIZATION>Lancashire</ORGANIZATION> batsman <PERSON>Graham Lloyd</PERSON> , was making his international debut .</S>
<S>After <PERSON>Wasim</PERSON> had won the toss and chosen to bat first , Pakistani made an excellent start as <PERSON>Sohail</PERSON> and <PERSON>Saeed Anwar</PERSON> continued their good form with an opening partnership of 82 .</S>
<S><PERSON>Anwar</PERSON> , who struck a superb 176 at <LOCATION>The Oval</LOCATION> , was the more aggressive as he made 57 from 75 balls before skying a catch off <PERSON>Irani</PERSON> to <PERSON>Mullally</PERSON> at long-on .</S>
<S><PERSON>Sohail</PERSON> and <PERSON>Ijaz Ahmed</PERSON> then added 59 for the second wicket before <LOCATION>England</LOCATION> struck back with three wickets for 19 in the space of five overs .</S>
<S>First , <PERSON>Sohail</PERSON> , after making 48 , was bowled by <PERSON>Croft</PERSON> as he stepped back to try and hit through the off-side .</S>
<S><PERSON>Wasim</PERSON> , who promoted himself to number four in the order , followed for six when <PERSON>Croft</PERSON> drifted another well-flighted delivery behind his legs .</S>
<S>Shortly after <PERSON>Ijaz</PERSON> was also back in the pavilion for 48 after <PERSON>Irani</PERSON> had repaid <PERSON>Mullally</PERSON> with another good catch at long-on .</S>
<S><PERSON>Gough</PERSON> later bowled <PERSON>Moin Khan</PERSON> with an inswinging yorker but <PERSON>Inzamam-ul-Haq</PERSON> , 37 not out , and <PERSON>Salim Malik</PERSON> took <LOCATION>Pakistan</LOCATION> to 225 for five when the overs ran out .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S>ATHLETICS - <PERSON>CHRISTIE</PERSON> TO RUN IN <LOCATION>BERLIN</LOCATION> .</S>
<S><LOCATION>LONDON</LOCATION> 1996-08-29</S>
<S><PERSON>Linford Christie</PERSON> has confirmed he will run in a " <ORGANIZATION>Dream Team</ORGANIZATION> " sprint relay at the <LOCATION>Berlin</LOCATION> grand prix athletics meeting on Friday .</S>
<S>A spokeswoman for <PERSON>Christie</PERSON> said the former Olympic 100 metres champion had agreed to captain a quality quartet which also includes <LOCATION>Canada</LOCATION>'s <PERSON>Donovan Bailey</PERSON> , the current Olympic champion and world record holder , and Namibian <PERSON>Frankie Fredericks</PERSON> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Christie</PERSON> is retiring from international competition at the end of the season , but <LOCATION>Berlin</LOCATION> promoter <PERSON>Rudi Thiel</PERSON> has persuaded him to join what is intended to be a special tribute to <PERSON>Jesse Owens</PERSON> , who won four gold medals 60 years ago at the <LOCATION>Berlin</LOCATION> Olympics .</S>
</DOCUMENT>
<DOCUMENT>
<S>SOCCER - <PERSON>GROBBELAAR</PERSON> NAMED TEMPORARY <LOCATION>ZIMBABWE</LOCATION> COACH .</S>
<S><LOCATION>HARARE</LOCATION> 1996-08-29</S>
<S>England-based goalkeeper <PERSON>Bruce Grobbelaar</PERSON> has been appointed temporary head coach of the <LOCATION>Zimbabwe</LOCATION> national soccer team for two international matches , the <ORGANIZATION>Zimbabwe Football Association</ORGANIZATION> ( <ORGANIZATION>ZIFA</ORGANIZATION> ) said on Thursday .</S>
<S><ORGANIZATION>ZIFA</ORGANIZATION> vice-chairman <PERSON>Vincent Pamire</PERSON> said <PERSON>Grobbelaar</PERSON> would take charge for a match against <LOCATION>Tanzania</LOCATION> in <LOCATION>Harare</LOCATION> on September 29 in the five-nation Castle Cup of Africa tournament and an African Nations ' Cup first round qualifier against <LOCATION>Sudan</LOCATION> in <LOCATION>Khartoum</LOCATION> on October 5 .</S>
<S><PERSON>Grobbelaar</PERSON> takes over until a permanent replacement is appointed for <LOCATION>Zimbabwe</LOCATION>'s previous coach , <LOCATION>Switzerland</LOCATION>'s <PERSON>Marc Duvillard</PERSON> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Grobbelaar</PERSON> now plays for English second division leaders <ORGANIZATION>Plymouth Argyle</ORGANIZATION> after years in the top flight with <ORGANIZATION>Liverpool</ORGANIZATION> and <ORGANIZATION>Southampton</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Grobbelaar</PERSON> , fellow goalkeeper <PERSON>Hans Segers</PERSON> , retired striker <PERSON>John Fashanu</PERSON> and Malaysian businessman <PERSON>Heng Suan Lim</PERSON> pleaded not guilty in May to charges of giving or accepting bribes to fix English premier league matches .</S>
<S>They are due to stand trial next January .</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S>BASEBALL - <ORGANIZATION>YANKEES</ORGANIZATION> BRAWL AND CONTINUE TO SLIDE .</S>
<S><LOCATION>SEATTLE</LOCATION> 1996-08-29</S>
<S><PERSON>Jay Buhner</PERSON> hit a three-run homer and former Yankee <PERSON>Terry Mulholland</PERSON> allowed one run over seven innings as the <ORGANIZATION>Seattle Mariners</ORGANIZATION> completed a sweep of <ORGANIZATION>New York</ORGANIZATION> with a 10-2 victory in a game marred by a bench-clearing brawl .</S>
<S>Including the last three games of last October's Divisional Playoff Series , the <ORGANIZATION>Mariners</ORGANIZATION> have beaten the <ORGANIZATION>Yankees</ORGANIZATION> 12 of the past 15 meetings overall and 14 of the last 16 in the <LOCATION>Kingdome</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>Five players were ejected after <ORGANIZATION>Yankees</ORGANIZATION> ' outfielder <PERSON>Paul O'Neill</PERSON> and <ORGANIZATION>Seattle</ORGANIZATION> catcher <PERSON>John Marzano</PERSON> got into a fight after <PERSON>O'Neill</PERSON> had been brushed back .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Baltimore</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Don Wengert</PERSON> threw a nine-hitter for his first shutout and <PERSON>Jose Herrera</PERSON> had a two-run double in a three-run fifth inning as the <ORGANIZATION>Oakland Athletics</ORGANIZATION> blanked the <ORGANIZATION>Baltimore Orioles</ORGANIZATION> 3-0 .</S>
<S><PERSON>Wengert</PERSON> ( 7-9 ) , who failed to record a shutout in his previous 86 starts in either the minors or majors , did not walk a batter and struck out three for <ORGANIZATION>Oakland</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Chicago</LOCATION> , <PERSON>James Baldwin</PERSON> scattered five hits over seven scoreless innings and <PERSON>Ray Durham</PERSON> and <PERSON>Ozzie Guillen</PERSON> had RBI hits in the second inning as the <ORGANIZATION>Chicago White Sox</ORGANIZATION> blanked the <ORGANIZATION>Milwaukee Brewers</ORGANIZATION> 2-0 .</S>
<S><PERSON>Baldwin</PERSON> ( 10-4 ) struck out four and did not walk a batter for <LOCATION>Chicago</LOCATION> , which won for only the fourth time in 15 games .</S>
<S><PERSON>Dave Nilsson</PERSON> had three hits for the <ORGANIZATION>Brewers</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Kansas City</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Jose Offerman</PERSON>'s single with two out in the 12th inning scored <PERSON>Johnny Damon</PERSON> with the winning run and lifted the <ORGANIZATION>Kansas City Royals</ORGANIZATION> to a 4-3 victory over the <ORGANIZATION>Texas Rangers</ORGANIZATION> .</S>
<S><PERSON>Rick Huisman</PERSON> ( 1-1 ) allowed one hit and a walk in the 12th to post his first major-league win .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Toronto</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Pat Hentgen</PERSON> tossed a five-hitter for his fifth consecutive complete game and three players drove in two runs apiece as the <ORGANIZATION>Toronto Blue Jays</ORGANIZATION> defeated the <ORGANIZATION>Minnesota Twins</ORGANIZATION> 6-1 for their ninth win in 11 games .</S>
<S><PERSON>Hentgen</PERSON> ( 17-7 ) surrendered just three doubles and a pair of singles in tossing his major-league leading ninth complete game .</S>
<S>He walked three and struck out three in winning for the 10th time in his last 11 decisions .</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Detroit</LOCATION> , <PERSON>Orel Hershiser</PERSON> recorded his fourth straight win and <PERSON>Albert Belle</PERSON> snapped a sixth-inning tie with a grand slam as the <ORGANIZATION>Cleveland Indians</ORGANIZATION> completed a season sweep of the <ORGANIZATION>Detroit Tigers</ORGANIZATION> with a 9-3 victory .</S>
<S><PERSON>Hershiser</PERSON> ( 14-7 ) , who allowed three runs , eight hits and one walk with five strikeouts over seven innings , improved to 4-0 in his last six starts , including a pair of wins over <ORGANIZATION>Detroit</ORGANIZATION> in the last 11 days .</S>
<S>At <LOCATION>California</LOCATION> ,</S>
<S>In <LOCATION>Seattle</LOCATION> ,</S>
</DOCUMENT>

<S><PERSON>Larry Fine</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>NEW YORK</LOCATION> 1996-08-28</S>
<S><PERSON>Conchita Martinez</PERSON> decided that when in <LOCATION>New York</LOCATION> , do as the New Yorkers do -- and the Spaniard's new-found aggressiveness seems to have put her in the right frame of mind for the U.S. Open .</S>
<S>The fourth-seeded Spaniard , who is tackling the world class traffic of <LOCATION>New York City</LOCATION> as a warm-up by driving to the tennis centre for her matches , ran over <LOCATION>France</LOCATION>'s <PERSON>Nathalie Tauziat</PERSON> 6-1 6-3 on Wednesday to take her place in the third round .</S>
<S>" I've been trying my whole career to be aggressive , " said the 24-year-old <PERSON>Martinez</PERSON> after crushing <PERSON>Tauziat</PERSON> in just over an hour .</S>
<S>" What I'm trying to do is be aggressive all the time , maybe go up to the net a few times like I did tonight .</S>
<S>That would really help . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Martinez</PERSON> , the 1994 Wimbledon champion , used to struggle at the Open , but has come to terms with the noise , crowds and chaos .</S>
<S>" There is a lot of things that can happen , " <PERSON>Martinez</PERSON> said about her early difficulties adjusting to tennis on the cement at <LOCATION>Flushing Meadows</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>" Like traffic .</S>
<S>We stay in <LOCATION>Manhattan</LOCATION> and it's a long way to come .</S>
<S>The crowds , they speak louder or they move .</S>
<S>That doesn't happen in other Grand Slams .</S>
<S>That's where the real champion wins .</S>
<S>You have to concentrate for these two weeks . "</S>
<S>It took <PERSON>Martinez</PERSON> four Opens to get as far as the quarters , and another four to match that .</S>
<S>Last year , <PERSON>Martinez</PERSON> , who finished 1995 ranked second in the world , reached the semifinals before bowing out to <PERSON>Monica Seles</PERSON> .</S>
<S>Now she feels she is in the swing of things .</S>
<S>" I have my own car now and that helps , " said <PERSON>Martinez</PERSON> .</S>
<S>" Sometimes the transportation they ( the tournament ) provide gets a little messed up .</S>
<S>This time it didn't happen .</S>
<S>I do the driving and I love it .</S>
<S>It gets my adrenalin going , those taxi drivers .</S>
<S>" We change lanes all the time in <LOCATION>Barcelona</LOCATION> .</S>
<S>I'm used to it and I like to drive fast . "</S>

<S>ATHLETICS - <PERSON>JOHNSON</PERSON> , <PERSON>CHRISTIE</PERSON> , <PERSON>BAILEY</PERSON> TO RUN <PERSON>OWENS</PERSON> RELAY .</S>
<S><PERSON>Adrian Warner</PERSON></S>
<S><LOCATION>BERLIN</LOCATION> 1996-08-29</S>
<S>Olympic champions <PERSON>Michael Johnson</PERSON> and <PERSON>Donovan Bailey</PERSON> and former champion <PERSON>Linford Christie</PERSON> will run in a " <ORGANIZATION>Dream Team</ORGANIZATION> " sprint relay squad in honour of <PERSON>Jesse Owens</PERSON> on Friday .</S>
<S><PERSON>Johnson</PERSON> , the 200 metres world record holder , and <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION>'s 1992 Olympic 100 champion <PERSON>Christie</PERSON> confirmed on Thursday that they would join 100 record holder <PERSON>Bailey</PERSON> and <LOCATION>Namibia</LOCATION>'s <PERSON>Frankie Fredericks</PERSON> in one of the greatest 4x100 squads ever assembled .</S>
<S>They will run against quartets from the <LOCATION>United States</LOCATION> , <LOCATION>Europe</LOCATION> and <LOCATION>Africa</LOCATION> in a special race at the <LOCATION>Berlin</LOCATION> Grand Prix meeting to mark the 60th anniversary of <PERSON>Owens</PERSON>'s four gold medals at the 1936 Olympics in the German capital .</S>
<S><PERSON>Christie</PERSON> will run the anchor leg after <LOCATION>Canada</LOCATION>'s <PERSON>Bailey</PERSON> , American <PERSON>Johnson</PERSON> and Olympic silver medallist <PERSON>Fredericks</PERSON> have run the first three stages of the relay .</S>
<S>The participation of <PERSON>Bailey</PERSON> and <PERSON>Fredericks</PERSON> had been known before Thursday .</S>
<S>But <PERSON>Christie</PERSON> did not announce his decision to run until the eve of the meeting when organisers also confirmed <PERSON>Johnson</PERSON> would take part .</S>
<S><PERSON>Christie</PERSON> is due to retire from international competition at the end of the season although he may compete for <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION> in next season's European Cup .</S>
<S>Although <PERSON>Christie</PERSON> , who is not racing the individual 100 metres in <LOCATION>Berlin</LOCATION> , took his time to agree to run , the veteran was clearly delighted to be part of the tribute to the black American .</S>
<S>When five former Olympic 100 champions from 1948 to 1980 , who have been invited to watch the race , turned up at a news conference on Thursday , <PERSON>Christie</PERSON> was quick to put his autograph book in front of the them .</S>
<S>" I don't normally do this but can you please sign , " he said thrusting an ornate white book in front of Americans <PERSON>Harrison Dillard</PERSON> ( 1948 ) , <PERSON>Lindy Remigino</PERSON> ( 1952 ) , <PERSON>Jim Hines</PERSON> ( 1968 ) , <LOCATION>Trinidad</LOCATION>'s <PERSON>Hasely Crawford</PERSON> ( 1976 ) and <LOCATION>Britain</LOCATION>'s <PERSON>Allan Wells</PERSON> ( 1980 ) .</S>
<S>" <PERSON>Jesse Owens</PERSON> inspired everyone here and it is great to have a tribute to him . "</S>
<S><PERSON>Owens</PERSON>'s widow <PERSON>Ruth</PERSON> is not well enough to attend but a message from her will be read out by the sprinter's grand-daughter <PERSON>Gina Tillman</PERSON> during the meeting</S>
<S><LOCATION>Berlin</LOCATION> organisers hoped to have American 1984 and 1988 champion <PERSON>Carl Lewis</PERSON> in the squad but he injured himself in last Friday's <LOCATION>Brussels</LOCATION> meeting .</S>
